01:01:48,458 --> 01:01:53,088
{\an8}- We wonder
what kind of monster

1206
01:01:53,129 --> 01:01:57,384
{\an8}could commit
such a horrible deed.

1207
01:01:57,425 --> 01:02:02,472
- Well over 2,000 people
showed up to her funeral.

1208
01:02:02,514 --> 01:02:05,183
- It was
standing room only.

1209
01:02:05,225 --> 01:02:07,310
There were so many
people there.

1210
01:02:07,352 --> 01:02:09,938
Because this had just
touched a community

1211
01:02:09,979 --> 01:02:12,315
like you can
only imagine.

1212
01:02:12,357 --> 01:02:14,442
- And it's just
so overwhelming.

1213
01:02:14,484 --> 01:02:17,153
And, and as a mom
you're trying to grieve

1214
01:02:17,195 --> 01:02:18,988
{\an8}for your little girl.

1215
01:02:19,030 --> 01:02:28,873
{\an8}**

1216
01:02:28,915 --> 01:02:30,333
{\an8}- Really the last
thing I remember

1217
01:02:30,375 --> 01:02:33,503
{\an8}is just the funeral.

1218
01:02:33,545 --> 01:02:36,297
{\an8}Not really
when they found her body.

1219
01:02:36,339 --> 01:02:38,466
{\an8}Just-- I just remember
the funeral.

1220
01:02:40,593 --> 01:02:44,180
At 5 years old
I didn't know what death was.

1221
01:02:44,222 --> 01:02:47,684
I was telling her,
Wake up, Sissy, wake up.

1222
01:02:47,726 --> 01:02:49,185
It's time to get up.

1223
01:02:52,022 --> 01:02:55,275
- To me, I just wanted
to take my baby and just run.

1224
01:02:55,316 --> 01:02:57,068
You know, I got my kids.

1225
01:02:57,110 --> 01:03:00,113
You know, it--
that little part of me

1226
01:03:00,155 --> 01:03:01,406
wanted to do that.

1227
01:03:07,203 --> 01:03:09,205
{\an8}I attended the funeral.

1228
01:03:09,247 --> 01:03:12,167
{\an8}It was to go to observe
the participants

1229
01:03:12,208 --> 01:03:13,668
{\an8}and see if anything
looked unusual,

1230
01:03:13,710 --> 01:03:15,754
{\an8}if anyone acted
inappropriately,

1231
01:03:15,795 --> 01:03:19,841
{\an8}if someone just looked
out of place.

1232
01:03:19,883 --> 01:03:22,552
- Sometimes a suspect will want
to go to the funeral

1233
01:03:22,594 --> 01:03:24,346
just to see
what's going on.

1234
01:03:24,387 --> 01:03:26,681
Of course the issue
with Amber's funeral

1235
01:03:26,723 --> 01:03:30,018
is there were
lots of people there.

1236
01:03:30,060 --> 01:03:32,395
This wasn't a family affair.

1237
01:03:32,437 --> 01:03:35,357
We put surveillance inside

1238
01:03:35,398 --> 01:03:37,692
and at the graveside
during the services,

1239
01:03:37,734 --> 01:03:40,737
and then we also had people
surveilling

1240
01:03:40,779 --> 01:03:43,698
the outer perimeter
around the area

1241
01:03:43,740 --> 01:03:45,658
to see if someone
was on the outskirts,

1242
01:03:45,700 --> 01:03:47,911
possibly observing
from a distance.

1243
01:03:49,954 --> 01:03:53,583
- We felt like we had to do
anything and everything

1244
01:03:53,625 --> 01:03:56,711
that could possibly
provide new information

1245
01:03:56,753 --> 01:03:58,838
and lead to the suspect
that killed Amber.

1246
01:04:09,557 --> 01:04:23,780
{\an8}**

1247
01:04:23,822 --> 01:04:27,117
{\an8}- My parents were,
with every newscast,

1248
01:04:27,158 --> 01:04:29,244
{\an8}asking for help,
putting out information

1249
01:04:29,285 --> 01:04:31,454
{\an8}to bring justice
to their daughter.

1250
01:04:38,461 --> 01:04:39,671
{\an8}- It makes me mad
because I don't know.

1251
01:04:39,713 --> 01:04:42,424
{\an8}I want to know.
I want to know now.

1252
01:04:42,465 --> 01:04:47,387
{\an8}- Donna had been on camera
with us for a while

1253
01:04:47,429 --> 01:04:50,306
but there was a change
in her demeanor

1254
01:04:50,348 --> 01:04:52,434
as the days wore on.

1255
01:04:52,475 --> 01:04:55,020
- I'm just slowly,
surely losing all my hope

1256
01:04:55,061 --> 01:04:56,604
that they're gonna
find him.

1257
01:05:02,527 --> 01:05:04,029
- We were hopeful
early on of course

1258
01:05:04,070 --> 01:05:05,155
that there were
more witnesses

1259
01:05:05,196 --> 01:05:06,781
and that people
would come forward.

1260
01:05:06,823 --> 01:05:08,450
And we've just been
tremendously frustrated

1261
01:05:08,491 --> 01:05:10,577
by that fact that this,
this abduction

1262
01:05:10,618 --> 01:05:12,454
occurred in broad daylight
on a very busy street

1263
01:05:12,495 --> 01:05:15,915
on a Saturday afternoon
and no one saw anything.

1264
01:05:15,957 --> 01:05:18,293
{\an8}- We would hold two briefings
daily for the press

1265
01:05:18,335 --> 01:05:20,003
{\an8}to keep the information
flowing.

1266
01:05:20,045 --> 01:05:21,171
{\an8}And there were
many times

1267
01:05:21,212 --> 01:05:22,464
{\an8}I didn't haven't
anything new to say

1268
01:05:22,505 --> 01:05:25,050
{\an8}but I went in there
and did it anyway.

1269
01:05:25,091 --> 01:05:27,552
- Okay, describe
the truck to me.

1270
01:05:27,594 --> 01:05:30,638
- We certainly felt like
we had to keep this,

1271
01:05:30,680 --> 01:05:33,475
this case, of all cases,
in the public eye.

1272
01:05:33,516 --> 01:05:35,393
We followed
thousands of leads.

1273
01:05:35,435 --> 01:05:36,936
Not just hundreds
but thousands.

1274
01:05:41,358 --> 01:05:44,361
- We've got a couple
of tips that, uh,

1275
01:05:44,402 --> 01:05:47,072
on vehicular traffic
and some people

1276
01:05:47,113 --> 01:05:49,366
that were seen
in the area.

1277
01:05:49,407 --> 01:05:52,243
- There were calls coming in
on a regular basis

1278
01:05:52,285 --> 01:05:53,495
of people that thought
they'd seen her,

1279
01:05:53,536 --> 01:05:55,663
thought they'd
seen the suspect.

1280
01:05:55,705 --> 01:05:57,499
{\an8}- Now those leads ranged
from everything

1281
01:05:57,540 --> 01:05:59,084
{\an8}from I saw a black pickup

1282
01:05:59,125 --> 01:06:03,254
{\an8}to specific suspects
that were named right away.

1283
01:06:03,296 --> 01:06:06,633
- There was a woman
that came forward

1284
01:06:06,675 --> 01:06:11,179
and said that she had seen
the entire abduction.

1285
01:06:11,221 --> 01:06:14,808
- The witness went so far
as to describe the Ford Splash

1286
01:06:14,849 --> 01:06:17,477
as well as a partial
license plate number

1287
01:06:17,519 --> 01:06:19,187
that she thought
she remembered.

1288
01:06:19,229 --> 01:06:21,356
And she saw Amber

1289
01:06:21,398 --> 01:06:24,401
in the passenger seat
of this truck,

1290
01:06:24,442 --> 01:06:26,528
and Amber was banging
on the back window

1291
01:06:32,992 --> 01:06:33,243
{\an8}**

1292
01:06:37,622 --> 01:06:40,458
{\an8}- We really hadn't had
any good leads

1293
01:06:40,500 --> 01:06:43,461
{\an8}and a woman came forward
though at that point

1294
01:06:43,503 --> 01:06:46,965
{\an8}and said she had
a partial license tag.

1295
01:06:47,007 --> 01:06:48,591
{\an8}- Because she gave a much more
specific description

1296
01:06:48,633 --> 01:06:49,926
{\an8}of the pickup truck,

1297
01:06:49,968 --> 01:06:52,595
{\an8}we developed a whole
investigative strategy

1298
01:06:52,637 --> 01:06:55,974
{\an8}that was kind of based
around what she said.

1299
01:06:56,016 --> 01:06:58,268
{\an8}- Everybody on
the task force is excited.

1300
01:06:58,309 --> 01:07:03,064
{\an8}We finally got the detail that
will lead us to the suspect.

1301
01:07:03,106 --> 01:07:04,774
{\an8}- At that point in time,
we had been working

1302
01:07:04,816 --> 01:07:06,818
{\an8}with the Ford
Motor Company,

1303
01:07:06,860 --> 01:07:10,030
{\an8}and they came up with a list
of potential trucks

1304
01:07:10,071 --> 01:07:12,741
{\an8}with a partial plate
that had been sold

1305
01:07:12,782 --> 01:07:14,617
{\an8}in this geographic area
that matched

1306
01:07:14,659 --> 01:07:18,580
{\an8}that general description
of that truck.

1307
01:07:18,621 --> 01:07:20,832
{\an8}- Detectives end up finding
a potential suspect,

1308
01:07:20,874 --> 01:07:22,667
{\an8}and he actually lives
in Arlington

1309
01:07:22,709 --> 01:07:24,377
{\an8}within the range

1310
01:07:24,419 --> 01:07:27,505
{\an8}of where the suspect
would have gone.

1311
01:07:27,547 --> 01:07:28,923
{\an8}- My hopes
were really up high

1312
01:07:28,965 --> 01:07:31,468
{\an8}and finally we're going
to get justice for Amber

1313
01:07:31,509 --> 01:07:33,011
{\an8}and we can
close this chapter

1314
01:07:33,053 --> 01:07:35,555
{\an8}and it's all
going to be done with.

1315
01:07:39,142 --> 01:07:44,230
- Now we think we've finally
got the break that we need.

1316
01:07:44,731 --> 01:07:46,399
The man cooperated

1317
01:07:46,441 --> 01:07:50,737
and let detectives
search his house

1318
01:07:50,779 --> 01:07:53,823
and there was nothing
whatsoever to indicate

1319
01:07:53,865 --> 01:07:55,575
that he was
a suspect in it.

1320
01:07:57,827 --> 01:08:00,747
After this happened,
the detectives went back

1321
01:08:00,789 --> 01:08:02,832
to contact the witness

1322
01:08:02,874 --> 01:08:05,126
and basically go over
the whole story

1323
01:08:05,168 --> 01:08:07,128
again with her.

1324
01:08:07,170 --> 01:08:09,923
And they started putting
two and two together,

1325
01:08:09,964 --> 01:08:11,675
and it just
wasn't adding up.

1326
01:08:11,716 --> 01:08:13,718
The information that
she was providing us

1327
01:08:13,760 --> 01:08:14,886
really wasn't matching

1328
01:08:14,928 --> 01:08:18,431
what we had been able
to corroborate.

1329
01:08:18,473 --> 01:08:20,392
We interviewed
her again,

1330
01:08:20,433 --> 01:08:22,310
and then she finally
admits to us

1331
01:08:22,352 --> 01:08:23,520
that she didn't
know anything

1332
01:08:23,561 --> 01:08:26,898
and she just made it up.

1333
01:08:26,940 --> 01:08:28,566
She made the story up

1334
01:08:28,608 --> 01:08:30,735
because she felt
so bad for Donna

1335
01:08:30,777 --> 01:08:32,946
and the lack of a break
in the case

1336
01:08:32,987 --> 01:08:35,281
that she just wanted
to do anything

1337
01:08:35,323 --> 01:08:36,908
that she could
to help her.

1338
01:08:36,950 --> 01:08:40,745
And I know how that sounds,
but for some reason,

1339
01:08:40,787 --> 01:08:43,540
this lady thought that this
would be helpful to Donna

1340
01:08:43,581 --> 01:08:45,917
and make Donna
more hopeful

1341
01:08:45,959 --> 01:08:48,336
that a suspect was
gonna be found.

1342
01:08:48,378 --> 01:08:51,756
- She thought that giving us
that type of information

1343
01:08:51,798 --> 01:08:55,802
might spur us on
some sort of renewed energy

1344
01:08:55,844 --> 01:08:57,220
into the investigation.

1345
01:08:57,262 --> 01:08:59,556
But instead what she did
was she cost us time

1346
01:08:59,597 --> 01:09:01,599
and she cost us
man-hours.

1347
01:09:01,641 --> 01:09:03,685
And quite frankly,
she pissed me off.

1348
01:09:06,730 --> 01:09:08,523
We had a lot of people

1349
01:09:08,565 --> 01:09:10,984
that would come up
with false information

1350
01:09:11,026 --> 01:09:14,112
just to bring Amber's
case back up.

1351
01:09:14,154 --> 01:09:17,198
It was very frustrating,
not just for me,

1352
01:09:17,240 --> 01:09:19,075
for the police
as well.

1353
01:09:19,117 --> 01:09:21,619
- Prosecuting her
for making a false statement

1354
01:09:21,661 --> 01:09:23,329
wasn't going to
help us any.

1355
01:09:23,371 --> 01:09:27,792
I wanted to keep everybody
focused on Amber.

1356
01:09:27,834 --> 01:09:30,128
{\an8}- We felt
very early on

1357
01:09:30,170 --> 01:09:31,629
{\an8}that it was
a stranger abduction.

1358
01:09:31,671 --> 01:09:33,465
{\an8}You know, every sign
pointed to that.

1359
01:09:33,506 --> 01:09:36,009
{\an8}We'd beg for someone to come
forward that knew anything.

1360
01:09:36,051 --> 01:09:37,886
{\an8}Just another tool
in the toolbox

1361
01:09:37,927 --> 01:09:41,222
{\an8}trying to use it
to get some help.

1362
01:09:41,264 --> 01:09:42,766
Everything that happened
along the way

1363
01:09:42,807 --> 01:09:44,893
was just a step-by-step
situation

1364
01:09:44,934 --> 01:09:48,521
where we were just
frustrated at every turn.

1365
01:09:48,563 --> 01:09:50,815
And it-it was tough.
It was very tough.

1366
01:09:53,651 --> 01:09:56,738
- A couple of weeks
after I buried Amber,

1367
01:09:56,780 --> 01:09:59,366
I just assumed, you know,
You're the police.

1368
01:09:59,407 --> 01:10:00,867
You're going
to solve this.

1369
01:10:00,909 --> 01:10:03,119
You're going to be able
to come and tell me

1370
01:10:03,161 --> 01:10:06,790
who murdered--
who butchered my little girl.

1371
01:10:06,831 --> 01:10:09,793
And there was
just no evidence.

1372
01:10:21,471 --> 01:10:22,597
- How do you feel
about the fact

1373
01:10:22,639 --> 01:10:24,849
that they haven't
found somebody?

1374
01:10:24,891 --> 01:10:27,727
- I'm frustrated.
Angry.

1375
01:10:27,769 --> 01:10:29,437
You know, why can't
they find this man?

1376
01:10:29,479 --> 01:10:32,816
How hard can this be,
you know?

1377
01:10:32,857 --> 01:10:34,275
'Course I was
frustrated, angry,

1378
01:10:34,317 --> 01:10:36,027
'cause they couldn't
find my little girl.

1379
01:10:36,069 --> 01:10:38,363
And, now I'm frustrated
and angry

1380
01:10:38,405 --> 01:10:42,200
'cause they can't find him
that did this to her.

1381
01:10:42,242 --> 01:10:47,205
- Donna became convinced
that whoever took Amber

1382
01:10:47,247 --> 01:10:52,168
had done something like this
or similar to this before.

1383
01:10:52,210 --> 01:10:56,089
And it just angered her
that they were still out there

1384
01:10:56,131 --> 01:11:01,094
and that they could
have done it again.

1385
01:11:01,136 --> 01:11:03,388
- From the moment
that Amber was abducted

1386
01:11:03,430 --> 01:11:06,433
and the anguish Donna
was going through,

1387
01:11:06,474 --> 01:11:08,018
over the course of time,

1388
01:11:08,059 --> 01:11:10,729
she turned that
into a drive,

1389
01:11:10,770 --> 01:11:13,148
a sense to make
a difference

1390
01:11:13,189 --> 01:11:15,150
and to give the police
greater tools.

1391
01:11:17,277 --> 01:11:21,448
{\an8}Not every family
that has an abducted child

1392
01:11:21,489 --> 01:11:24,951
{\an8}will then turn their energy
into advocacy.

1393
01:11:24,993 --> 01:11:27,954
Donna was going
to fight for Amber

1394
01:11:27,996 --> 01:11:29,956
and she was going
to make sure

1395
01:11:29,998 --> 01:11:34,461
that this would not happen
to any other child.

1396
01:11:34,502 --> 01:11:37,255
{\an8}- City council meetings
were all about Amber.

1397
01:11:37,297 --> 01:11:39,090
{\an8}You would have
hundreds of people

1398
01:11:39,132 --> 01:11:41,009
{\an8}going up there
wanting to talk.

1399
01:11:41,051 --> 01:11:44,262
School board meetings,
the same thing.

1400
01:11:44,304 --> 01:11:46,264
- There are 77 million
parents out there

1401
01:11:46,306 --> 01:11:48,725
who want their children
to be safe.

1402
01:11:48,767 --> 01:11:50,143
All we have to do
is organize.

1403
01:11:50,185 --> 01:11:51,895
All we have to do
is work together.

1404
01:11:51,936 --> 01:11:54,689
All we have to do
is send a message.

1405
01:11:54,731 --> 01:11:57,317
- Donna, her life
is open to the public,

1406
01:11:57,359 --> 01:12:00,111
period, at this point,
because of what happened.

1407
01:12:12,665 --> 01:12:15,043
The important thing

1408
01:12:15,085 --> 01:12:16,836
as we followed
this path

1409
01:12:16,878 --> 01:12:18,463
that really had been
set out for us

1410
01:12:18,505 --> 01:12:22,801
was that we tell what
it was really like

1411
01:12:22,842 --> 01:12:25,887
to live through
something like this.

1412
01:12:25,929 --> 01:12:27,305
It's usually very personal

1413
01:12:27,347 --> 01:12:30,266
but Donna was willing
to share that with everybody.

1414
01:12:39,192 --> 01:12:41,111
- This is
Donna Whitson.

1415
01:12:53,206 --> 01:12:55,250
- When Amber
was abducted,

1416
01:12:55,291 --> 01:12:58,003
I was still going
to medical school

1417
01:12:58,044 --> 01:13:00,046
so I took a leave
of absence.

1418
01:13:04,592 --> 01:13:06,928
I had to finish for her.

1419
01:13:06,970 --> 01:13:10,265
And I did.

1420
01:13:10,306 --> 01:13:13,059
- You see her going
from devastating grief

1421
01:13:13,101 --> 01:13:16,604
of losing that child
and dealing with that reality

1422
01:13:16,646 --> 01:13:18,398
to the other end
of the spectrum

1423
01:13:18,440 --> 01:13:21,985
and was able to
continue on for Amber.

1424
01:13:27,115 --> 01:13:29,117
Why is it taking so long?

1425
01:13:29,159 --> 01:13:31,202
It shouldn't take that long,
you know?

1426
01:13:31,244 --> 01:13:33,413
Why can't you find
this black truck?

1427
01:13:33,455 --> 01:13:35,290
Why can't you find
this monster?

1428
01:13:55,143 --> 01:13:56,936
- The whole room
was just packed full

1429
01:13:56,978 --> 01:13:59,606
of all this stuff
about Amber's case.

1430
01:13:59,647 --> 01:14:02,609
And it was like, wow,
this is overwhelming.

1431
01:14:12,327 --> 01:14:14,412
- When Amber was taken
a lot of people said

1432
01:14:14,454 --> 01:14:16,581
if we could have just
gotten the word out

1433
01:14:16,623 --> 01:14:18,249
there would probably be
a better chance

1434
01:14:18,291 --> 01:14:20,377
that she could have
been found.

1435
01:14:20,418 --> 01:14:24,589
- It is the desperate search
for this little 9 year old

1436
01:14:24,631 --> 01:14:26,424
and time
is of the essence.

1437
01:14:26,466 --> 01:14:30,136
And so, tell everybody in
the community this has happened,

1438
01:14:30,178 --> 01:14:33,098
give them information,
the photographs, the video,

1439
01:14:33,139 --> 01:14:35,767
here's the suspect vehicle

1440
01:14:35,809 --> 01:14:41,356
and then really engage to get
everybody to help search.

1441
01:14:41,398 --> 01:14:43,942
- I think that was in
a lot of peoples' minds

1442
01:14:43,983 --> 01:14:46,820
is, Can we do this?
How can we do this,

1443
01:14:46,861 --> 01:14:50,281
and how can we put that
into action?

1444
01:14:50,323 --> 01:14:53,201
Diana Simone was one of those
people who could see that

1445
01:14:53,243 --> 01:14:55,912
that was a good
possibility.

1446
01:14:55,954 --> 01:14:57,122
{\an8}I am Diana Simone,

1447
01:14:57,163 --> 01:15:00,291
{\an8}and I am resident
of Fort Worth, Texas.

1448
01:15:00,333 --> 01:15:02,544
I rarely, if ever,
watched the news.

1449
01:15:02,585 --> 01:15:06,631
But the TV was on,
and as I passed by it,

1450
01:15:06,673 --> 01:15:11,011
I noticed what appeared to be
somebody's home video was on.

1451
01:15:11,052 --> 01:15:13,138
There's such a different
emotional reaction

1452
01:15:13,179 --> 01:15:15,432
when you see a child
opening presents

1453
01:15:15,473 --> 01:15:18,393
and riding a bike
and waving and smiling

1454
01:15:18,435 --> 01:15:21,146
than you do
just a flat picture.

1455
01:15:21,187 --> 01:15:24,649
This child becomes
very real to you.

1456
01:15:24,691 --> 01:15:28,319
Then to hear this horrifying
situation had taken place,

1457
01:15:28,361 --> 01:15:29,362
you just immediately think

1458
01:15:29,404 --> 01:15:31,239
what her mother
must be feeling.

1459
01:15:35,618 --> 01:15:38,830
In Amber's case,
she was taken around 4:00.

1460
01:15:38,872 --> 01:15:40,457
It was 6:00 or 6:30
when I saw it.

1461
01:15:40,498 --> 01:15:43,168
So two and half hours
had already passed

1462
01:15:43,209 --> 01:15:46,254
before the public became aware
of what was going on.

1463
01:15:46,296 --> 01:15:48,548
I called the radio station
and I said,

1464
01:15:48,590 --> 01:15:50,425
"I'm calling about
the Amber Hagerman case."

1465
01:15:50,467 --> 01:15:52,844
And she said,
"Do you have any information?"

1466
01:15:52,886 --> 01:15:55,388
And I said, "No, I don't,
but I do have an idea."

1467
01:15:58,350 --> 01:15:59,893
- So often when children
were being taken

1468
01:15:59,934 --> 01:16:02,354
it was by a suspect
in a vehicle,

1469
01:16:02,395 --> 01:16:04,689
put the child in a vehicle,
they drive off.

1470
01:16:04,731 --> 01:16:06,858
{\an8}So wouldn't it be great
if there was a way

1471
01:16:06,900 --> 01:16:08,735
{\an8}to let everybody
know about it,

1472
01:16:08,777 --> 01:16:11,780
{\an8}so that they could be your
eyes and ears on the street

1473
01:16:11,821 --> 01:16:13,323
{\an8}looking for that
suspect vehicle.

1474
01:16:13,365 --> 01:16:17,702
Looking for that suspect.
Looking for that child.

1475
01:16:17,744 --> 01:16:20,747
Arlington Police and this group
of radio station managers

1476
01:16:20,789 --> 01:16:24,125
ended up getting together,
and formulating this plan

1477
01:16:24,167 --> 01:16:26,002
for this
emergency broadcast alert

1478
01:16:26,044 --> 01:16:27,504
that they would put out.

1479
01:16:27,545 --> 01:16:29,631
And it would have a loud,
obnoxious sound.

1480
01:16:29,673 --> 01:16:32,300
It was gonna go out
on the radio stations

1481
01:16:32,342 --> 01:16:35,220
and would alert people that
there'd been a child abduction,

1482
01:16:35,261 --> 01:16:37,889
give them information
like where did it happen,

1483
01:16:37,931 --> 01:16:39,224
what does the suspect
look like,

1484
01:16:39,265 --> 01:16:41,559
what is the suspect driving.

1485
01:16:41,601 --> 01:16:43,103
{\an8}- It's so simple,
it's brilliant,

1486
01:16:43,144 --> 01:16:44,729
{\an8}because the whole idea
is to be able

1487
01:16:44,771 --> 01:16:47,774
{\an8}to get out to the public
information that they can use

1488
01:16:47,816 --> 01:16:51,152
{\an8}to provide us
with actionable intelligence.

1489
01:16:51,194 --> 01:16:52,362
{\an8}A description of suspect.

1490
01:16:52,404 --> 01:16:54,906
{\an8}Description of vehicle.
License plate.

1491
01:16:54,948 --> 01:16:57,701
{\an8}Something that
they could work with.

1492
01:16:57,742 --> 01:16:59,452
{\an8}- It's a real partnership.
It's a partnership

1493
01:16:59,494 --> 01:17:01,996
{\an8}between law enforcement
and broadcasters

1494
01:17:02,038 --> 01:17:05,083
{\an8}to work together
when time is critical

1495
01:17:05,125 --> 01:17:06,668
{\an8}on a serious
child abduction case.

1496
01:17:09,170 --> 01:17:10,964
- Today we're unveiling
the Amber Plan.

1497
01:17:11,006 --> 01:17:13,842
[applause]

1498
01:17:13,883 --> 01:17:18,096
- I encourage all radio stations
to participate in this

1499
01:17:18,138 --> 01:17:20,223
because it is
a great idea

1500
01:17:20,265 --> 01:17:22,517
and it will get information out
that we need

1501
01:17:22,559 --> 01:17:26,229
to get a little girl
or a little boy home.

1502
01:17:26,271 --> 01:17:28,481
{\an8}- Some staggering
percentage of people

1503
01:17:28,523 --> 01:17:30,608
{\an8}had their radio on
when they were in the car.

1504
01:17:30,650 --> 01:17:31,860
{\an8}And so we thought
if we could get it across

1505
01:17:31,901 --> 01:17:34,112
{\an8}all the radio stations
in Dallas-Fort Worth,

1506
01:17:34,154 --> 01:17:37,365
just think how many eyes we'd
have out looking for the kids.

1507
01:17:37,407 --> 01:17:38,450
And so it just worked
like a charm

1508
01:17:38,491 --> 01:17:40,577
as far as getting people
to say, Yes.

1509
01:17:40,618 --> 01:17:42,829
And then Rae-Leigh Bradbury
comes along.

1510
01:17:48,376 --> 01:17:50,795
{\an8}- We got a call that
there was a missing baby

1511
01:17:50,837 --> 01:17:53,131
{\an8}by the name
of Rae-Leigh.

1512
01:17:53,173 --> 01:17:57,052
{\an8}- We were living in Arlington
throughout my whole pregnancy.

1513
01:17:57,093 --> 01:17:58,636
{\an8}I knew everybody.

1514
01:17:58,678 --> 01:18:00,096
{\an8}I loved everybody.

1515
01:18:00,138 --> 01:18:02,349
{\an8}And I had this little lady,
she's as cute as could be.

1516
01:18:02,390 --> 01:18:04,809
Her name was
Sandra Fallis.

1517
01:18:04,851 --> 01:18:06,936
I thought of her
as a friend.

1518
01:18:06,978 --> 01:18:08,313
And I trusted her.

1519
01:18:08,355 --> 01:18:11,274
So that's why I felt like
that it was a good choice

1520
01:18:11,316 --> 01:18:16,488
that I let her
become my babysitter.

1521
01:18:16,529 --> 01:18:20,241
- I drop her off that morning
in a little onesie nighty.

1522
01:18:20,283 --> 01:18:22,660
And then
her diaper bag full.

1523
01:18:22,702 --> 01:18:27,123
And then just
do a normal 8-hour workday.

1524
01:18:27,165 --> 01:18:29,501
- And then when evening
came time

1525
01:18:29,542 --> 01:18:31,294
and the babysitter was
supposed to show up with her,

1526
01:18:31,336 --> 01:18:32,587
she-- they didn't show up.

1527
01:18:36,591 --> 01:18:37,801
- I didn't think
she was kidnapped.

1528
01:18:37,842 --> 01:18:39,803
That's not a word
that I would even associate.

1529
01:18:42,555 --> 01:18:45,266
No local hospitals
had heard of any wrecks

1530
01:18:45,308 --> 01:18:46,935
or anything like that.

1531
01:18:46,976 --> 01:18:49,896
And then finally I just
decided to call 9-1-1.

1532
01:18:49,938 --> 01:18:54,609
I'm like, "My babysitter
hasn't brought my baby home."

1533
01:18:54,651 --> 01:18:56,611
Basically a policeman
came up

1534
01:18:56,653 --> 01:18:59,489
and he was like taking
the report and stuff.

1535
01:18:59,531 --> 01:19:00,907
- And we started
talking about,

1536
01:19:00,949 --> 01:19:02,659
"Well is this, is this the time
we should do this?"

1537
01:19:02,701 --> 01:19:04,494
We felt like, Okay, you know,
something's got to happen.

1538
01:19:04,536 --> 01:19:07,122
We've got to get
this baby back.

1539
01:19:07,163 --> 01:19:08,623
I remember calling
the police chief,

1540
01:19:08,665 --> 01:19:10,375
I'm getting ready
to do this.

1541
01:19:10,417 --> 01:19:11,793
- They were like,
"We're going to use this thing

1542
01:19:11,835 --> 01:19:13,003
called the Amber Alert."

1543
01:19:17,757 --> 01:19:19,884
- This is an activation
of the Amber Alert system

1544
01:19:19,926 --> 01:19:23,096
at the request of
the Arlington Police Department.

1545
01:19:23,138 --> 01:19:24,973
Arlington Police
say a child,

1546
01:19:25,015 --> 01:19:28,393
a 2-month-old white female baby
has been kidnapped.

1547
01:19:28,435 --> 01:19:31,146
The baby's name is
Rae-Leigh Ann Bradbury.

1548
01:19:31,187 --> 01:19:34,065
Police believe the victim was
abducted by her babysitter,

1549
01:19:34,107 --> 01:19:36,192
Sandra Joyce Fallis,
a white female,

1550
01:19:36,234 --> 01:19:39,863
42 years of age,
5'3", 135 pounds,

1551
01:19:39,904 --> 01:19:42,699
with black hair, brown eyes
and driving a turquoise

1552
01:19:42,741 --> 01:19:46,369
1993 Ford Ranger Splash
pickup truck.

1553
01:19:46,411 --> 01:19:48,079
- It literally
was like 30 minutes.

1554
01:19:59,007 --> 01:20:13,563
**

1555
01:20:18,651 --> 01:20:20,070
- Guy driving down the highway
next to her,

1556
01:20:20,111 --> 01:20:21,488
{\an8}looking in the vehicle,

1557
01:20:21,529 --> 01:20:23,907
{\an8}"I see the baby sitting
on the front seat!

1558
01:20:23,948 --> 01:20:25,075
{\an8}"In her car seat."

1559
01:20:27,577 --> 01:20:29,454
- So we got a patrol officer
out there.

1560
01:20:29,496 --> 01:20:30,955
Pulled her over,
got the baby.

1561
01:20:38,630 --> 01:20:41,966
{\an8}- I was in the car driving home
and I was elated.

1562
01:20:42,008 --> 01:20:44,678
{\an8}I was absolutely elated.

1563
01:20:44,719 --> 01:20:47,722
{\an8}I mean there were just,
there are no words, you know.

1564
01:20:47,764 --> 01:20:50,517
{\an8}Because you're just like,
"Oh, my God, it's working.

1565
01:20:50,558 --> 01:20:52,769
{\an8}"It's absolutely working."

1566
01:20:52,811 --> 01:20:54,354
{\an8}- When I was finally able
to hold her,

1567
01:20:54,396 --> 01:20:55,814
{\an8}it was a relief.

1568
01:20:55,855 --> 01:20:59,818
{\an8}It was just
an overwhelming relief.

1569
01:20:59,859 --> 01:21:01,611
{\an8}I didn't want
to let her go.

1570
01:21:01,653 --> 01:21:04,823
{\an8}I was not going
to let her go.

1571
01:21:04,864 --> 01:21:06,408
{\an8}- It couldn't have happened
any better.

1572
01:21:06,449 --> 01:21:08,451
{\an8}So yeah,
a happy ending

1573
01:21:08,493 --> 01:21:12,747
{\an8}to a thing rooted
in a terrible tragedy.

1574
01:21:12,789 --> 01:21:14,666
{\an8}- That was awesome.
Me and my mom,

1575
01:21:14,708 --> 01:21:17,377
{\an8}we just kinda looked up
in heaven and said,

1576
01:21:17,419 --> 01:21:18,962
{\an8}"You did it, girl."

1577
01:21:20,505 --> 01:21:21,548
{\an8}I've said how much

1578
01:21:21,589 --> 01:21:23,633
{\an8}Amber Hagerman
has meant to me.

1579
01:21:23,675 --> 01:21:25,593
{\an8}And it's true
to this day,

1580
01:21:25,635 --> 01:21:27,303
{\an8}I wouldn't be here
without her.

1581
01:21:27,345 --> 01:21:30,056
{\an8}I used to call her
my guardian angel.

1582
01:21:30,098 --> 01:21:32,767
{\an8}I used to pray to her,
just like little prayers

1583
01:21:32,809 --> 01:21:34,477
{\an8}like, "Thank you
for this day",

1584
01:21:34,519 --> 01:21:37,355
{\an8}like, "Thanks for
watching over me."

1585
01:21:37,397 --> 01:21:38,773
{\an8}- Every time I hear
a Amber Alert,

1586
01:21:38,815 --> 01:21:41,609
{\an8}I say to myself,
"It's time to go to work, Sis.

1587
01:21:41,651 --> 01:21:43,486
{\an8}"Do your thing."

1588
01:21:43,528 --> 01:21:44,696
{\an8}I just wish that

1589
01:21:44,738 --> 01:21:48,283
{\an8}Amber had something
in place at the time.

1590
01:21:48,324 --> 01:21:49,826
{\an8}It's bittersweet.

1591
01:21:49,868 --> 01:21:53,204
{\an8}What if we had a Amber Alert
when Amber was missing?

1592
01:21:53,246 --> 01:21:55,081
{\an8}Could it have
saved her life?

1593
01:21:58,626 --> 01:22:00,962
{\an8}- Once other areas
across the country

1594
01:22:01,004 --> 01:22:04,507
{\an8}heard about the program,
they said,

1595
01:22:04,549 --> 01:22:07,385
{\an8}"We're going to set one up
in our town."

1596
01:22:07,427 --> 01:22:11,639
{\an8}- Within weeks of us
activating Amber,

1597
01:22:11,681 --> 01:22:13,183
I was receiving calls

1598
01:22:13,224 --> 01:22:16,770
and other people were receiving
calls from around Texas

1599
01:22:16,811 --> 01:22:19,647
and from around
the United States on,

1600
01:22:19,689 --> 01:22:21,608
"Okay, how do you
do this?"

1601
01:22:21,649 --> 01:22:23,651
I would walk them
through the process

1602
01:22:23,693 --> 01:22:26,071
that we went through
in developing

1603
01:22:26,112 --> 01:22:29,699
the relationships
with their radio stations,

1604
01:22:29,741 --> 01:22:32,327
and actually putting it
in place

1605
01:22:32,369 --> 01:22:35,080
and getting it up
and running.

1606
01:22:35,121 --> 01:22:37,040
We have a critical time

1607
01:22:37,082 --> 01:22:38,792
that we have to
get this information out

1608
01:22:38,833 --> 01:22:41,503
to galvanize the community,

1609
01:22:41,544 --> 01:22:45,340
to get their ears and eyes
looking everywhere

1610
01:22:45,382 --> 01:22:47,926
for the child,
for the vehicle.

1611
01:22:47,967 --> 01:22:51,179
It was exciting to see
the programs popping up

1612
01:22:51,221 --> 01:22:52,555
around the country,

1613
01:22:52,597 --> 01:22:54,891
and it was
in 2000

1614
01:22:54,933 --> 01:22:57,852
that the National Center for
Missing and Exploited Children

1615
01:22:57,894 --> 01:23:02,065
said, "You know what,
we should take this national."

1616
01:23:02,107 --> 01:23:04,693
- And then to just see it
just explode.

1617
01:23:04,734 --> 01:23:08,071
It just becomes this
phenomenon and it works.

1618
01:23:13,576 --> 01:23:14,703
{\an8}Ladies and Gentlemen,

1619
01:23:14,744 --> 01:23:17,706
{\an8}the President
of the United States.

1620
01:23:17,747 --> 01:23:19,374
{\an8}- President Bush
signed on

1621
01:23:19,416 --> 01:23:22,002
{\an8}and said, you know,
"I support this."

1622
01:23:22,043 --> 01:23:27,674
{\an8}And he designated a National
Amber Alert Coordinator

1623
01:23:27,716 --> 01:23:31,177
{\an8}at the Department
of Justice.

1624
01:23:31,219 --> 01:23:35,223
{\an8}- Amber Hagerman,
whose mom is with us today,

1625
01:23:35,265 --> 01:23:36,933
{\an8}a good Texan
I might add...

1626
01:23:36,975 --> 01:23:41,521
{\an8}[applause]

1627
01:23:41,563 --> 01:23:42,897
{\an8}Was 9 years old

1628
01:23:42,939 --> 01:23:45,942
{\an8}when she was taken away
from her parents.

1629
01:23:45,984 --> 01:23:49,237
{\an8}We are acting today
in her memory

1630
01:23:49,279 --> 01:23:51,614
{\an8}and in the memory of so many
other girls and boys

1631
01:23:51,656 --> 01:23:53,241
{\an8}who lost their lives
and innocence

1632
01:23:53,283 --> 01:23:55,118
{\an8}in acts of cruelty.

1633
01:23:55,160 --> 01:23:56,578
{\an8}And now it is my honor

1634
01:23:56,619 --> 01:24:01,583
{\an8}to sign the Protect Act
of 2003.

1635
01:24:01,624 --> 01:24:04,210
{\an8}- That was sort of
the crowning moment,

1636
01:24:04,252 --> 01:24:05,503
{\an8}and I get chills,

1637
01:24:05,545 --> 01:24:09,674
{\an8}because everybody's work
had paid off.

1638
01:24:09,716 --> 01:24:14,429
{\an8}[applause]

1639
01:24:14,471 --> 01:24:17,057
{\an8}- It was nerve-wracking,
but I was still really proud

1640
01:24:17,098 --> 01:24:20,727
{\an8}because the President is
talking about my little girl.

1641
01:24:20,769 --> 01:24:22,062
{\an8}And I was able
to talk to him

1642
01:24:22,103 --> 01:24:24,064
about my little girl
and what happened to her.

1643
01:24:27,984 --> 01:24:30,987
Donna really evolved.

1644
01:24:31,029 --> 01:24:33,615
She turned her grief
and anger

1645
01:24:33,656 --> 01:24:36,785
into advocacy.

1646
01:24:36,826 --> 01:24:40,288
She's been a champion
of the Amber Alert program

1647
01:24:40,330 --> 01:24:42,123
the entire time

1648
01:24:42,165 --> 01:24:44,292
and she knows that,

1649
01:24:44,334 --> 01:24:46,670
you know, this is
her daughter's legacy.

1650
01:24:55,553 --> 01:24:57,514
- Tragedy struck
this community

1651
01:24:57,555 --> 01:25:01,142
{\an8}January 13, 1996.

1652
01:25:01,184 --> 01:25:03,728
{\an8}Our resolve
to solve this case

1653
01:25:03,770 --> 01:25:06,981
{\an8}has not wavered.

1654
01:25:07,023 --> 01:25:09,984
{\an8}- Anytime there's an anniversary
of her abduction and murder,

1655
01:25:10,026 --> 01:25:13,697
{\an8}and there's a press conference
or a memorial,

1656
01:25:13,738 --> 01:25:16,116
{\an8}we have a bunch
of community members

1657
01:25:16,157 --> 01:25:19,494
{\an8}come out in support
of the family.

1658
01:25:19,536 --> 01:25:21,121
- This case
is personal to me

1659
01:25:21,162 --> 01:25:23,039
because I've been
involved in some aspect

1660
01:25:23,081 --> 01:25:25,917
since the day
that Amber was abducted.

1661
01:25:25,959 --> 01:25:28,795
In 2010, I became
the lead detective.

1662
01:25:28,837 --> 01:25:31,840
And I had the case
from then until 2018

1663
01:25:31,881 --> 01:25:33,717
when I promoted
to Sergeant.

1664
01:25:33,758 --> 01:25:35,885
At that time
Detective Grant Gildon

1665
01:25:35,927 --> 01:25:37,929
{\an8}took over
as the lead detective.

1666
01:25:37,971 --> 01:25:40,765
{\an8}- Actually, I was a sophomore
in high school

1667
01:25:40,807 --> 01:25:42,684
{\an8}when, when this case
happened.

1668
01:25:42,726 --> 01:25:44,227
{\an8}And I remember hearing
of the Amber Alert

1669
01:25:44,269 --> 01:25:46,062
{\an8}and that it was named
after a young girl

1670
01:25:46,104 --> 01:25:48,690
{\an8}that was kidnapped
and murdered.

1671
01:25:48,732 --> 01:25:51,693
It wasn't until
I was applying

1672
01:25:51,735 --> 01:25:53,570
with the Arlington
Police Department

1673
01:25:53,611 --> 01:25:55,613
that I became
aware that

1674
01:25:55,655 --> 01:25:58,700
the case originated
in Arlington, Texas.

1675
01:25:58,742 --> 01:26:00,702
I saw just how
passionate they were

1676
01:26:00,744 --> 01:26:02,871
about trying to solve
Amber's case.

1677
01:26:02,912 --> 01:26:05,206
Then it,
it really struck me that

1678
01:26:05,248 --> 01:26:08,043
that was something I wanted
to help contribute to.

1679
01:26:08,084 --> 01:26:10,211
The figure we gave
of 5,500.

1680
01:26:10,253 --> 01:26:13,548
That's the number of leads
the Amber Hagerman Task Force

1681
01:26:13,590 --> 01:26:16,551
investigated between
February of '96

1682
01:26:16,593 --> 01:26:18,178
and June of '97.

1683
01:26:18,219 --> 01:26:22,891
Current to date,
we've investigated over 7,000.

1684
01:26:22,932 --> 01:26:26,061
{\an8}- The 25th year anniversary
is just another year with,

1685
01:26:26,102 --> 01:26:29,564
{\an8}with no answers, no justice,
and we want that to change.

1686
01:26:29,606 --> 01:26:31,941
{\an8}We want justice.
That's our goal.

1687
01:26:31,983 --> 01:26:35,236
{\an8}That's-that's what we need.
Our family needs closure.

1688
01:26:35,278 --> 01:26:38,990
- One of the major, um,
issues with a case

1689
01:26:39,032 --> 01:26:41,910
that is a long-term case
like this

1690
01:26:41,951 --> 01:26:44,704
is that, you know,
people forget about it.

1691
01:26:44,746 --> 01:26:48,124
But Amber's killer
is out there somewhere.

1692
01:26:48,166 --> 01:27:03,264
**

1693
01:27:06,017 --> 01:27:09,562
- After 25 years, of course it
gets frustrating at times

1694
01:27:09,604 --> 01:27:11,690
because we want
to solve the case

1695
01:27:11,731 --> 01:27:15,110
and we want answers
for Amber's family.

1696
01:27:15,151 --> 01:27:18,321
But as homicide
detectives

1697
01:27:18,363 --> 01:27:20,990
we never let
that frustration get to us

1698
01:27:21,032 --> 01:27:23,493
to the point
of quitting.

1699
01:27:23,535 --> 01:27:27,789
{\an8}- Recently, there was
some new technology

1700
01:27:27,831 --> 01:27:29,332
{\an8}that I became aware of

1701
01:27:29,374 --> 01:27:33,920
{\an8}that we thought was relevant
to some of the evidence

1702
01:27:33,962 --> 01:27:36,840
{\an8}that we've maintained
in this case.

1703
01:27:36,881 --> 01:27:40,093
We've started to discuss
the possibility

1704
01:27:40,135 --> 01:27:42,345
of testing some
of the evidence we have

1705
01:27:42,387 --> 01:27:46,599
that we hope can
produce DNA in this case.

1706
01:27:46,641 --> 01:27:47,851
With Amber,

1707
01:27:47,892 --> 01:27:52,022
there is just not much
trace evidence at all.

1708
01:27:52,063 --> 01:27:53,606
- The main question
when determining

1709
01:27:53,648 --> 01:27:54,816
what evidence to test

1710
01:27:54,858 --> 01:27:57,235
and what kind
of testing to do

1711
01:27:57,277 --> 01:28:00,739
is thinking about the quantity
of the evidence

1712
01:28:00,780 --> 01:28:02,824
and whether or not
you're going to use up

1713
01:28:02,866 --> 01:28:06,745
or consume
all of the potential DNA

1714
01:28:06,786 --> 01:28:08,705
while doing the testing.

1715
01:28:08,747 --> 01:28:11,875
- Is it worth the risk
of destroying all the evidence

1716
01:28:11,916 --> 01:28:14,127
in the testing process?

1717
01:28:14,169 --> 01:28:19,132
Or is it something we should
wait a few months to test

1718
01:28:19,174 --> 01:28:21,843
because of the advancements
in the technology

1719
01:28:21,885 --> 01:28:25,096

Name: Simon and Laura
Subtitle Data:
1
00:01:53,054 --> 00:01:54,387
Standby.

2
00:01:56,679 --> 00:01:59,012
Keep still, number two, standby.

3
00:02:00,721 --> 00:02:02,845
How's he gonna get the time?

4
00:02:02,846 --> 00:02:03,804
Get ready, number three.

5
00:02:03,805 --> 00:02:06,445
We're coming over to you in five seconds.

6
00:02:12,471 --> 00:02:13,887
Excuse me, sir.

7
00:02:37,932 --> 00:02:39,012
Yes, what is it?

8
00:02:39,013 --> 00:02:40,845
The CT wants you in his office, sir.

9
00:02:40,846 --> 00:02:41,678
Oh.

10
00:02:41,679 --> 00:02:42,554
Take over, Bill, will you?

11
00:02:42,555 --> 00:02:43,471
The CT wants me.

12
00:02:43,472 --> 00:02:45,095
Okay.

13
00:02:45,096 --> 00:02:46,845
And now would you show us, in close up,

14
00:02:46,846 --> 00:02:48,470
what you are going to demonstrate.

15
00:02:48,471 --> 00:02:50,053
When the camera's in close up.

16
00:02:50,054 --> 00:02:52,178
This is the tawny, or brown owl.

17
00:02:52,179 --> 00:02:54,511
The kind we get in the London parks,

18
00:02:54,512 --> 00:02:55,595
and a very useful.

19
00:02:55,596 --> 00:02:58,845
Oh, oh, no, no, no, no.

20
00:02:58,846 --> 00:03:00,303
First of all, the wings,

21
00:03:00,304 --> 00:03:01,845
well, just like that.

22
00:03:01,846 --> 00:03:02,928
I hope that comes off.

23
00:03:02,929 --> 00:03:05,136
- The beak and the...
- Excuse me, sir,

24
00:03:05,137 --> 00:03:06,386
the CT wants you.

25
00:03:06,387 --> 00:03:07,636
Right.

26
00:03:07,637 --> 00:03:09,345
The CT wants you in his office.

27
00:03:09,346 --> 00:03:10,346
Oh, dear.

28
00:03:15,418 --> 00:03:16,678
- Hello there.
- Hi.

29
00:03:16,679 --> 00:03:17,512
What's all this in aid of?

30
00:03:17,513 --> 00:03:19,345
Prentice has an idea
for a new programme,

31
00:03:19,346 --> 00:03:21,053
another spelling bee,
I shouldn't surprised.

32
00:03:21,054 --> 00:03:22,095
That takes me out.

33
00:03:22,096 --> 00:03:23,836
I can't spell my own name.

34
00:03:25,887 --> 00:03:27,553
Ah, gentlemen, come in.

35
00:03:27,554 --> 00:03:28,803
Sit down, won't you?

36
00:03:28,804 --> 00:03:30,304
I won't keep you long.

37
00:03:31,356 --> 00:03:33,636
Well, I've called you here together

38
00:03:33,637 --> 00:03:35,428
to discuss a rather interesting proposal

39
00:03:35,429 --> 00:03:37,289
put out by Mr. Prentice here.

40
00:03:37,290 --> 00:03:39,803
You know, those of us
who've been in television

41
00:03:39,804 --> 00:03:42,053
since the beginning realise
that nothing succeeds

42
00:03:42,054 --> 00:03:44,386
like a series or a serial.

43
00:03:44,387 --> 00:03:47,262
I almost said nothing
succeeds like excess.

44
00:03:48,887 --> 00:03:50,553
Rather like advertising.

45
00:03:50,554 --> 00:03:51,803
Repeat a thing often enough

46
00:03:51,804 --> 00:03:52,928
and everybody has to buy it,

47
00:03:52,929 --> 00:03:55,303
whether they really like it or not.

48
00:03:55,304 --> 00:03:58,803
In fact, the DG sometimes
says, jokingly of course,

49
00:03:58,804 --> 00:04:00,970
that if one televised a few pages

50
00:04:00,971 --> 00:04:02,595
of the London telephone directory

51
00:04:02,596 --> 00:04:04,678
regularly for five or six weeks,

52
00:04:04,679 --> 00:04:08,345
one would gain an average
audience of over 10 million,

53
00:04:08,346 --> 00:04:10,386
which brings us to Mr. Prentice.

54
00:04:10,387 --> 00:04:12,678
All right, David, tell us your idea.

55
00:04:12,679 --> 00:04:14,095
Thank you, sir.

56
00:04:14,096 --> 00:04:16,053
Would you mind if I took off my coat, sir?

57
00:04:16,054 --> 00:04:17,720
Why, is it hot in here?

58
00:04:17,721 --> 00:04:19,928
No, but I always think
better with it off.

59
00:04:19,929 --> 00:04:21,470
Remove it, by all means.

60
00:04:21,471 --> 00:04:22,845
Thank you, sir.

61
00:04:22,846 --> 00:04:24,886
Well now, my plan, in a nutshell,

62
00:04:24,887 --> 00:04:28,011
is to put on every evening
at a peak viewing hour

63
00:04:28,012 --> 00:04:31,303
a programme that will, well,
that will mirror the lives

64
00:04:31,304 --> 00:04:34,428
of an ordinary, happily
married husband and wife.

65
00:04:34,429 --> 00:04:36,095
We show their ups and downs,

66
00:04:36,096 --> 00:04:38,720
their, well, the fun they get out of life,

67
00:04:38,721 --> 00:04:41,845
the minor tragedies that
inevitably creep in their lives,

68
00:04:41,846 --> 00:04:44,053
their hobbies, what they're talking about,

69
00:04:44,054 --> 00:04:46,636
thinking, reading, and
so on, so on, and so on.

70
00:04:46,637 --> 00:04:49,178
A sort of "Mrs. Dale's Diary," in fact.

71
00:04:49,179 --> 00:04:50,720
Oh no, no, nothing like that.

72
00:04:50,721 --> 00:04:53,095
We want an actual real-life couple

73
00:04:53,096 --> 00:04:55,678
with genuine glamour and
excitement in their lives.

74
00:04:55,679 --> 00:04:58,220
And whose fundamental interest
is a contented home life.

75
00:04:58,221 --> 00:04:59,054
Exactly.

76
00:04:59,055 --> 00:05:00,511
You'll never find them, old boy.

77
00:05:00,512 --> 00:05:01,678
Why not?

78
00:05:01,679 --> 00:05:03,428
I mean, we can pick a well
known actor and actress

79
00:05:03,429 --> 00:05:04,886
who also happen to be married.

80
00:05:04,887 --> 00:05:06,053
And how do you know they still will be

81
00:05:06,054 --> 00:05:07,970
by the time you get to
the second programme?

82
00:05:07,971 --> 00:05:09,803
That's a sound point, Johnson.

83
00:05:09,804 --> 00:05:10,928
But there are several of them

84
00:05:10,929 --> 00:05:12,720
that have been happily married for years.

85
00:05:12,721 --> 00:05:13,928
Such as?

86
00:05:13,929 --> 00:05:15,511
The Attenboroughs.

87
00:05:15,512 --> 00:05:16,553
The Oliviers.

88
00:05:16,554 --> 00:05:17,720
I think we can do better than that.

89
00:05:17,721 --> 00:05:19,678
What about the Fosters?

90
00:05:19,679 --> 00:05:20,512
Hmm.

91
00:05:20,513 --> 00:05:21,928
They've been married for years.

92
00:05:21,929 --> 00:05:22,887
Both of them have been stars

93
00:05:22,888 --> 00:05:24,095
for as long as I can remember.

94
00:05:24,096 --> 00:05:26,916
And, sir, absolutely
devoted to one another.

95
00:05:28,554 --> 00:05:30,095
Just a minute, Laura!

96
00:05:30,096 --> 00:05:31,096
Laura!

97
00:05:31,804 --> 00:05:32,804
Ooh!

98
00:05:37,096 --> 00:05:38,178
Simon!

99
00:05:38,179 --> 00:05:39,553
Open this door!

100
00:05:39,554 --> 00:05:40,886
Not till you apologise!

101
00:05:40,887 --> 00:05:42,053
I'll break it down first!

102
00:05:42,054 --> 00:05:43,261
Just you try!

103
00:05:43,262 --> 00:05:44,199
Cad!

104
00:05:44,200 --> 00:05:45,137
Slut!

105
00:05:45,138 --> 00:05:46,761
- Beast!
- Trollop!

106
00:05:46,762 --> 00:05:47,595
Ooh!

107
00:05:47,596 --> 00:05:48,429
You called, sir?

108
00:05:48,430 --> 00:05:49,470
Simon!

109
00:05:49,471 --> 00:05:51,220
I was addressing my wife.

110
00:05:51,221 --> 00:05:53,303
- I'll make lunch.
- Open this door!

111
00:05:53,304 --> 00:05:54,221
You know

112
00:05:54,222 --> 00:05:55,261
- what happened last time!
- Wilson?

113
00:05:55,262 --> 00:05:56,095
Sir?

114
00:05:56,096 --> 00:05:56,929
- I'll call the police!
- What time is the next

115
00:05:56,930 --> 00:05:58,095
presentable train for Leicester?

116
00:05:58,096 --> 00:05:59,345
Discriminating travellers

117
00:05:59,346 --> 00:06:02,053
speak very highly of the 1:25, sir.

118
00:06:02,054 --> 00:06:02,887
Good.

119
00:06:02,888 --> 00:06:03,970
Now, nip around to Cook's
and get me a ticket.

120
00:06:03,971 --> 00:06:06,178
- One, sir?
- One, single.

121
00:06:06,179 --> 00:06:08,179
Try and get me a corner seat.

122
00:06:09,538 --> 00:06:10,678
What do you want?

123
00:06:10,679 --> 00:06:11,512
Money, sir.

124
00:06:11,513 --> 00:06:12,553
I am temporarily embarrassed.

125
00:06:12,554 --> 00:06:14,595
Well, take it out of
the housekeeping money.

126
00:06:14,596 --> 00:06:16,345
The housekeeping is
also embarrassed, sir.

127
00:06:16,346 --> 00:06:17,179
Well, scrape it up somehow.

128
00:06:17,180 --> 00:06:18,012
Excuse me, sir.

129
00:06:18,013 --> 00:06:20,345
Someone seems to be knocking, sir.

130
00:06:20,346 --> 00:06:23,136
- Open this!
- All right, well answer it.

131
00:06:23,137 --> 00:06:24,303
There's the key.

132
00:06:24,304 --> 00:06:26,136
Thank you very much, sir.

133
00:06:26,137 --> 00:06:28,304
Will you open this door?

134
00:06:29,512 --> 00:06:30,512
Simon!

135
00:06:31,221 --> 00:06:32,804
You nasty old hand!

136
00:06:34,346 --> 00:06:37,636
You!

137
00:06:37,637 --> 00:06:39,428
Thank you, Wilson.

138
00:06:39,429 --> 00:06:40,629
A pleasure, madam.

139
00:06:41,512 --> 00:06:42,512
Hello?

140
00:06:42,513 --> 00:06:45,595
May I speak to Mr. Burton, please?

141
00:06:45,596 --> 00:06:46,429
Don't give me that.

142
00:06:46,430 --> 00:06:48,595
Bertie hasn't made a round
of the studios for 20 years.

143
00:06:48,596 --> 00:06:50,996
Tell him I'll be there in 10 minutes.

144
00:06:54,471 --> 00:06:55,720
Wilson!

145
00:06:55,721 --> 00:06:56,845
Bring me a suitcase.

146
00:06:56,846 --> 00:06:58,136
- I have it here, sir.
- Good.

147
00:06:58,137 --> 00:06:59,877
And your clean shirts, sir.

148
00:07:08,429 --> 00:07:11,220
Are you, um, planning to go somewhere?

149
00:07:11,221 --> 00:07:12,553
Yes, home to Mother.

150
00:07:12,554 --> 00:07:13,470
For long?

151
00:07:13,471 --> 00:07:14,387
For good.

152
00:07:14,388 --> 00:07:15,845
Then you'd better take this scarf.

153
00:07:15,846 --> 00:07:17,345
You'll probably need it.

154
00:07:17,346 --> 00:07:19,595
Your mother's house gets
very damp in the winter.

155
00:07:19,596 --> 00:07:20,720
Where did you get this?

156
00:07:20,721 --> 00:07:22,303
In your golf jacket.

157
00:07:22,304 --> 00:07:24,884
No wonder your handicap's gone up to 20.

158
00:07:24,885 --> 00:07:26,928
Laura, I've asked you
not to go through my things

159
00:07:26,929 --> 00:07:28,178
like a customs official.

160
00:07:28,179 --> 00:07:30,886
Hmm, I can well understand why.

161
00:07:30,887 --> 00:07:33,428
These I found in your golfing trousers.

162
00:07:33,429 --> 00:07:34,262
What are they?

163
00:07:34,263 --> 00:07:37,095
Their two tees, a hair
grip and an earring, sir.

164
00:07:37,096 --> 00:07:40,396
Ladies day at Sunningdale
must be quite an occasion.

165
00:07:40,397 --> 00:07:42,220
Wilson, I asked you to
go and get me a ticket.

166
00:07:42,221 --> 00:07:43,261
Yes, sir, at once, sir.

167
00:07:43,262 --> 00:07:45,178
It's just that I find the rapier thrusts

168
00:07:45,179 --> 00:07:48,928
of madam's conversation highly
stimulating, sir.

169
00:07:48,929 --> 00:07:49,929
Simon.

170
00:07:51,637 --> 00:07:55,095
Before you go, I, I just
want to say one thing.

171
00:07:55,096 --> 00:07:57,886
You left me permanently for
your mother's five times

172
00:07:57,887 --> 00:07:59,678
in the last three years.

173
00:07:59,679 --> 00:08:02,428
The average length of absence
has been about 10 weeks.

174
00:08:02,429 --> 00:08:04,428
Then you've appeared in that doorway

175
00:08:04,429 --> 00:08:06,428
with a nauseating smirk on your face

176
00:08:06,429 --> 00:08:08,678
and two dozen roses in your hand.

177
00:08:08,679 --> 00:08:10,636
And I, heaven forgive me, have said,

178
00:08:10,637 --> 00:08:13,011
"All right, come in."

179
00:08:13,012 --> 00:08:14,845
Well, understand this, Simon.

180
00:08:14,846 --> 00:08:17,095
This time I'm not saying come in.

181
00:08:17,096 --> 00:08:19,636
And this time I'm not
wasting my money on roses.

182
00:08:19,637 --> 00:08:21,011
You didn't the last two times.

183
00:08:21,012 --> 00:08:23,803
The bill came in for the
florist, and I paid it.

184
00:08:23,804 --> 00:08:24,824
12, 15, 17, 19.

185
00:08:29,012 --> 00:08:30,303
22, 23.

186
00:08:30,304 --> 00:08:32,095
Hmm, still not enough.

187
00:08:32,096 --> 00:08:34,428
The governor'll never travel third class.

188
00:08:34,429 --> 00:08:36,829
Well, bang goes the bread money again.

189
00:08:36,830 --> 00:08:39,386
You must be philosophical
about it, Jessie.

190
00:08:39,387 --> 00:08:41,667
Well, I only hope the baker will be.

191
00:08:46,846 --> 00:08:48,803
Oh, very pretty.

192
00:08:48,804 --> 00:08:50,386
And where are you off to now?

193
00:08:50,387 --> 00:08:51,262
I'm going to see my agent.

194
00:08:51,263 --> 00:08:53,678
Remind him if he's drawing
up any sort of a settlement

195
00:08:53,679 --> 00:08:55,970
that the furniture's mine and paid for.

196
00:08:55,971 --> 00:08:56,803
And the house is mine.

197
00:08:56,804 --> 00:08:57,762
You mean the mortgage on it is,

198
00:08:57,763 --> 00:09:00,470
and the payments are 18 months in arrears.

199
00:09:00,471 --> 00:09:02,511
Now, what will you do, my darling,

200
00:09:02,512 --> 00:09:03,803
when you get to Leicester?

201
00:09:03,804 --> 00:09:06,136
Is there a repertory
theatre you could join?

202
00:09:06,137 --> 00:09:07,054
Repertory?

203
00:09:07,055 --> 00:09:10,011
They'd probably welcome an
older man with your experience.

204
00:09:10,012 --> 00:09:11,595
Very interesting life, too.

205
00:09:11,596 --> 00:09:13,345
"Streetcar Named Desire" one week,

206
00:09:13,346 --> 00:09:15,470
"Lace on Her Petticoat" the next.

207
00:09:15,471 --> 00:09:17,053
I'm sorry, the idea
doesn't appeal to me.

208
00:09:17,054 --> 00:09:17,887
Oh, pity.

209
00:09:17,888 --> 00:09:19,470
It uh, might get rid of some of those

210
00:09:19,471 --> 00:09:22,345
irritating mannerisms of yours.

211
00:09:22,346 --> 00:09:23,179
Mannerisms.

212
00:09:23,180 --> 00:09:24,803
You can't do double takes

213
00:09:24,804 --> 00:09:27,428
52 weeks in a year even in Leicester.

214
00:09:27,429 --> 00:09:28,720
At the end of the second month,

215
00:09:28,721 --> 00:09:30,970
the people will begin to think
you had a permanent twitch.

216
00:09:30,971 --> 00:09:33,178
Might I remind you that
you were carrying entrees

217
00:09:33,179 --> 00:09:34,595
when I was already a leading man?

218
00:09:34,596 --> 00:09:36,095
Might I remind you
that you haven't worked

219
00:09:36,096 --> 00:09:38,053
for the last 11 months,

220
00:09:38,054 --> 00:09:41,011
and I very much doubt if
you'll work for another 11.

221
00:09:41,012 --> 00:09:43,636
The skids are well and
truly under you, Simon,

222
00:09:43,637 --> 00:09:46,303
only you're too pigheaded to admit it.

223
00:09:46,304 --> 00:09:47,845
Thank you very much.

224
00:09:47,846 --> 00:09:50,366
Your great faith in me is most touching.

225
00:09:59,137 --> 00:10:02,179
Wait here a minute, will you, please?

226
00:10:06,096 --> 00:10:07,096
Morning.

227
00:10:07,097 --> 00:10:08,178
Mr. Burton's expecting me.

228
00:10:08,179 --> 00:10:09,678
- I'm sorry, but...
- Oh, pay off my taxi,

229
00:10:09,679 --> 00:10:10,595
will you, darling?

230
00:10:10,596 --> 00:10:11,512
I haven't any change.

231
00:10:11,513 --> 00:10:13,345
Know more after I've
been in touch with Binkie.

232
00:10:13,346 --> 00:10:14,678
- Yours faithfully.
- Good morning, Bertie.

233
00:10:14,679 --> 00:10:15,512
Good morning, Miss Jones.

234
00:10:15,513 --> 00:10:16,636
I don't see anything good about it.

235
00:10:16,637 --> 00:10:17,512
I know, you're busy.

236
00:10:17,513 --> 00:10:18,346
So am I.

237
00:10:18,347 --> 00:10:20,303
I called in for a check, not a chat.

238
00:10:20,304 --> 00:10:21,137
50 pounds will do.

239
00:10:21,138 --> 00:10:23,136
Now, why should I give you 50 pounds?

240
00:10:23,137 --> 00:10:24,136
As an advance.

241
00:10:24,137 --> 00:10:25,054
An advance against what?

242
00:10:25,055 --> 00:10:26,553
Now don't be silly, Bertie,

243
00:10:26,554 --> 00:10:28,928
against my next salary check.

244
00:10:28,929 --> 00:10:30,470
And when will that come?

245
00:10:30,471 --> 00:10:32,428
Well, you oughta know,
you're my agent, aren't you?

246
00:10:32,429 --> 00:10:33,887
Unfortunately, yes.

247
00:10:35,054 --> 00:10:37,454
I'd like to ask you something, Simon.

248
00:10:37,676 --> 00:10:40,136
Just what do you think an agent is for?

249
00:10:40,137 --> 00:10:42,053
Ah, that's something we've all wondered

250
00:10:42,054 --> 00:10:43,053
from time to time.

251
00:10:43,054 --> 00:10:43,887
Now, now, now, don't banter.

252
00:10:43,888 --> 00:10:44,721
I'll tell you.

253
00:10:44,722 --> 00:10:46,761
To get you jobs and take
10% of the money you make.

254
00:10:46,762 --> 00:10:47,596
- Exactly.
- Now I'll tell you

255
00:10:47,597 --> 00:10:48,429
what he's not for.

256
00:10:48,430 --> 00:10:50,845
He's not for settling your income tax.

257
00:10:50,846 --> 00:10:52,803
He's not for settling your gambling debts.

258
00:10:52,804 --> 00:10:55,053
Nor for cabling you your
return fair from Monte Carlo

259
00:10:55,054 --> 00:10:56,720
when you're cleaned out at the tables.

260
00:10:56,721 --> 00:10:57,803
Well, you enjoy a flutter yourself.

261
00:10:57,804 --> 00:10:58,886
Certainly I do.

262
00:10:58,887 --> 00:11:00,386
But when I lose, I don't come to you

263
00:11:00,387 --> 00:11:01,595
and ask you to pay my bookmaker.

264
00:11:01,596 --> 00:11:02,428
Neither do I.

265
00:11:02,429 --> 00:11:03,262
No, but it comes to the same thing

266
00:11:03,263 --> 00:11:04,096
when you expect me to advance you

267
00:11:04,097 --> 00:11:05,845
10% of some other actor's salary

268
00:11:05,846 --> 00:11:08,345
when you've neither of
you worked for a year!

269
00:11:08,346 --> 00:11:09,179
Well, I must admit,

270
00:11:09,180 --> 00:11:10,803
for an agent you've been very generous.

271
00:11:10,804 --> 00:11:11,970
Oh, well, thank you.

272
00:11:11,971 --> 00:11:12,804
That's big of you.

273
00:11:12,805 --> 00:11:14,470
That's very big of you.

274
00:11:14,471 --> 00:11:16,553
On the other hand, if you got me a job,

275
00:11:16,554 --> 00:11:18,761
I wouldn't have been
out of work for a year.

276
00:11:18,762 --> 00:11:21,012
Now, now, let's not be sordid.

277
00:11:21,846 --> 00:11:22,846
Excuse me.

278
00:11:24,762 --> 00:11:25,762
Yes?

279
00:11:25,763 --> 00:11:27,261
Miss Drake's still waiting
to see you, Mr. Burton.

280
00:11:27,262 --> 00:11:28,303
Oh good heavens, don't keep her waiting.

281
00:11:28,304 --> 00:11:29,970
Send her in.

282
00:11:29,971 --> 00:11:31,261
Give him a check, give him the cash box,

283
00:11:31,262 --> 00:11:32,803
give him the keys to the safe.

284
00:11:32,804 --> 00:11:33,637
- Hello!
- Darling,

285
00:11:33,638 --> 00:11:35,053
nobody told me you were here, mwah.

286
00:11:35,054 --> 00:11:36,428
- Do you now Simon Foster?
- How do you do?

287
00:11:36,429 --> 00:11:37,928
I'm still not absolutely convinced

288
00:11:37,929 --> 00:11:40,095
that I'm doing the right thing.

289
00:11:40,096 --> 00:11:41,303
I tell you what I will do.

290
00:11:41,304 --> 00:11:43,095
I'll agree to a four-weeks trial.

291
00:11:43,096 --> 00:11:43,929
How's that?

292
00:11:43,930 --> 00:11:45,303
I'm sure you won't regret it, sir.

293
00:11:45,304 --> 00:11:46,470
And I can contact the Fosters?

294
00:11:46,471 --> 00:11:47,595
Yes, if they're agreeable,

295
00:11:47,596 --> 00:11:49,470
you can go ahead with
the preliminary plans.

296
00:11:49,471 --> 00:11:50,886
Oh, and see that the script

297
00:11:50,887 --> 00:11:53,386
stresses the solidarity of the home.

298
00:11:53,387 --> 00:11:55,761
Peaceful, happy atmosphere
of marital bliss.

299
00:11:55,762 --> 00:11:57,261
It's very important.

300
00:11:57,262 --> 00:11:58,761
Who were you thinking of for the writer?

301
00:11:58,762 --> 00:12:02,053
Well, I thought of Janet Honeyman, sir.

302
00:12:02,054 --> 00:12:02,887
You mean the girl

303
00:12:02,888 --> 00:12:05,095
who's doing "Insect
Life in British Ponds"?

304
00:12:05,096 --> 00:12:07,053
Oh, but she did do the "Darby
and Joan" programme, too, sir.

305
00:12:07,054 --> 00:12:08,970
All right, I'll leave it to you.

306
00:12:08,971 --> 00:12:10,595
Thank you, sir.

307
00:12:10,596 --> 00:12:13,011
There's one thing
you've forgotten, Mr. Prentice.

308
00:12:13,012 --> 00:12:14,178
Sir?

309
00:12:14,179 --> 00:12:15,970
Your coat.

310
00:12:15,971 --> 00:12:17,220
Oh.

311
00:12:17,221 --> 00:12:18,262
Thank you, sir.

312
00:12:36,581 --> 00:12:37,721
Your ticket, sir.

313
00:12:37,722 --> 00:12:39,162
Oh, thank you, Wilson.

314
00:12:40,480 --> 00:12:42,220
Here's a couple of pounds.

315
00:12:42,221 --> 00:12:43,054
Keep the change.

316
00:12:43,055 --> 00:12:44,178
Oh, thank you, sir.

317
00:12:44,179 --> 00:12:45,929
Now, before I go, wages.

318
00:12:46,453 --> 00:12:50,053
No, on second thought, I'll
give you and Jessie a check.

319
00:12:50,054 --> 00:12:50,887
I shouldn't bother, sir.

320
00:12:50,888 --> 00:12:52,303
It only causes embarrassment.

321
00:12:52,304 --> 00:12:54,344
No, I'll write you one at once.

322
00:12:58,377 --> 00:12:59,637
What are you doing?

323
00:12:59,638 --> 00:13:02,386
There's no need to add
kleptomania to your other failings.

324
00:13:02,387 --> 00:13:03,470
You put those back at once.

325
00:13:03,471 --> 00:13:04,429
They happen to be mine.

326
00:13:04,430 --> 00:13:05,803
They most certainly are not.

327
00:13:05,804 --> 00:13:06,637
They were presented to me

328
00:13:06,638 --> 00:13:08,220
by the cast on the 300th performance

329
00:13:08,221 --> 00:13:09,511
of "Marriage in Mayfair".

330
00:13:09,512 --> 00:13:11,511
I seem to remember that
on the 300th performance

331
00:13:11,512 --> 00:13:14,554
you were on holiday in
Paris with Sybil Hunter.

332
00:13:15,429 --> 00:13:17,053
Laura, before I leave,

333
00:13:17,054 --> 00:13:18,803
I want you to know,

334
00:13:18,804 --> 00:13:20,928
I forgive you for all your insults,

335
00:13:20,929 --> 00:13:21,762
including that last one.

336
00:13:21,763 --> 00:13:22,762
My insults?

337
00:13:23,554 --> 00:13:25,720
Ooh ha, ha, that's rich.

338
00:13:25,721 --> 00:13:28,595
Who started that sordid
brawl this morning?

339
00:13:28,596 --> 00:13:29,928
The same person who usually does.

340
00:13:29,929 --> 00:13:31,928
The reason was
cigarette ends in teacups.

341
00:13:31,929 --> 00:13:32,845
It was nothing of the sort.

342
00:13:32,846 --> 00:13:33,846
It was a...
If there's one thing

343
00:13:33,847 --> 00:13:36,136
I abominate, it's a filthy wet mess

344
00:13:36,137 --> 00:13:37,345
of loose tobacco swimming

345
00:13:37,346 --> 00:13:38,428
- about amongst the tea things!
- I merely happened

346
00:13:38,429 --> 00:13:39,429
to mention.

347
00:13:39,971 --> 00:13:42,011
As I was saying when you slammed

348
00:13:42,012 --> 00:13:42,846
the door in my face...

349
00:13:42,847 --> 00:13:44,178
There are seven ashtrays placed

350
00:13:44,179 --> 00:13:47,261
in strategic positions
all around the room.

351
00:13:47,262 --> 00:13:48,428
Now, do you ever use one?

352
00:13:48,429 --> 00:13:49,346
Oh, no.

353
00:13:49,347 --> 00:13:50,886
If you can't find a teacup handy,

354
00:13:50,887 --> 00:13:52,470
your beastly cigarettes get stamped

355
00:13:52,471 --> 00:13:54,011
out on my dressing table,

356
00:13:54,012 --> 00:13:56,261
in the rose bowl or down the sink.

357
00:13:56,262 --> 00:13:57,720
I go around cleaning up after you

358
00:13:57,721 --> 00:13:59,178
like an attendant at the zoo.

359
00:13:59,179 --> 00:14:00,054
Have you finished?

360
00:14:00,055 --> 00:14:01,678
For the time being, yes.

361
00:14:01,679 --> 00:14:02,886
One of the most tragic fates

362
00:14:02,887 --> 00:14:05,345
a man can suffer is to
be saddled to a nag.

363
00:14:05,346 --> 00:14:06,179
Saddled to a what?

364
00:14:06,180 --> 00:14:07,261
A nag.

365
00:14:07,262 --> 00:14:08,179
And no matter how much you think

366
00:14:08,180 --> 00:14:09,636
my education has been neglected,

367
00:14:09,637 --> 00:14:12,303
the equestrian phraseology
was intentional.

368
00:14:12,304 --> 00:14:14,053
You know, you really shouldn't

369
00:14:14,054 --> 00:14:14,887
try and talk like Wilson.

370
00:14:14,888 --> 00:14:17,386
You just haven't got the
presence to get away with it.

371
00:14:17,387 --> 00:14:19,095
This morning, on
looking through the back

372
00:14:19,096 --> 00:14:20,012
page of the daily paper,

373
00:14:20,013 --> 00:14:21,220
I merely happened to mention

374
00:14:21,221 --> 00:14:22,428
that the lady in the divorce case

375
00:14:22,429 --> 00:14:23,511
had remarkably good legs.

376
00:14:23,512 --> 00:14:24,636
- I remember perfectly...
- Seven minutes later,

377
00:14:24,637 --> 00:14:26,428
after you'd twisted that remark,

378
00:14:26,429 --> 00:14:28,345
you'd practically made
me the co-respondent.

379
00:14:28,346 --> 00:14:29,221
Well, what do you expect

380
00:14:29,222 --> 00:14:32,462
if you will be seen going
around with Sybil Hunter.

381
00:14:32,463 --> 00:14:35,345
Sybil Hunter happens to
be a patron of the arts.

382
00:14:35,346 --> 00:14:36,386
Uh, bunk.

383
00:14:36,387 --> 00:14:37,720
She's a patron of one thing

384
00:14:37,721 --> 00:14:39,761
and one thing only, men.

385
00:14:39,762 --> 00:14:40,886
And in her declining years,

386
00:14:40,887 --> 00:14:43,095
she's getting less and
less choosy what men.

387
00:14:43,096 --> 00:14:45,386
Mm, Gerald Baxter to you.

388
00:14:45,387 --> 00:14:46,886
And what is the matter
with Gerald Baxter?

389
00:14:46,887 --> 00:14:48,261
He's made some excellent pictures

390
00:14:48,262 --> 00:14:49,096
in these last two years.

391
00:14:49,097 --> 00:14:51,428
And he's made some
excellent passes at you,

392
00:14:51,429 --> 00:14:53,553
and you've encouraged him.

393
00:14:53,554 --> 00:14:55,220
How dare you!

394
00:14:55,221 --> 00:14:56,428
You take that back at once.

395
00:14:56,429 --> 00:14:57,261
I will not.

396
00:14:57,262 --> 00:14:58,398
I called you a trollop,

397
00:14:58,399 --> 00:14:59,536
and I meant a trollop.

398
00:14:59,887 --> 00:15:00,887
Ooh.

399
00:15:03,554 --> 00:15:04,554
Trollop!

400
00:15:07,000 --> 00:15:09,220
After due consideration, we decided

401
00:15:09,221 --> 00:15:11,636
that the Fosters were the ideal couple.

402
00:15:11,637 --> 00:15:12,717
What do you say?

403
00:15:13,446 --> 00:15:14,886
Oh, I beg your pardon.

404
00:15:14,887 --> 00:15:15,804
When do you want to start?

405
00:15:15,805 --> 00:15:16,637
Right away.

406
00:15:16,638 --> 00:15:19,928
Ooh, ooh, I'm afraid that's
extremely dodgy, old boy.

407
00:15:19,929 --> 00:15:21,636
Three different studios
want 'em for a picture.

408
00:15:21,637 --> 00:15:23,303
Simon has an offer to a play,

409
00:15:23,304 --> 00:15:24,803
and Laura's more or less promised

410
00:15:24,804 --> 00:15:26,886
to take a real big part on Broadway.

411
00:15:26,887 --> 00:15:27,845
Oh.

412
00:15:27,846 --> 00:15:28,678
Oh, I see.

413
00:15:28,679 --> 00:15:29,512
It's all those dollars.

414
00:15:29,513 --> 00:15:30,346
You know how it is.

415
00:15:30,347 --> 00:15:31,928
They sound so much more than pounds,

416
00:15:31,929 --> 00:15:33,386
particularly BBC pounds,

417
00:15:33,387 --> 00:15:35,386
if you don't mind my saying so.

418
00:15:35,387 --> 00:15:36,553
Oh, dear.

419
00:15:36,554 --> 00:15:39,428
Oh, well, I suppose I
better try the Oliviers.

420
00:15:39,429 --> 00:15:40,845
No, no, don't do that!

421
00:15:40,846 --> 00:15:42,928
I mean, I just hate to let you down.

422
00:15:42,929 --> 00:15:44,011
I tell you what I'll do,

423
00:15:44,012 --> 00:15:45,386
I'll get them on the phone

424
00:15:45,387 --> 00:15:47,428
and see if I can bring a
little pressure to bear.

425
00:15:47,429 --> 00:15:48,262
Oh.

426
00:15:48,263 --> 00:15:50,220
Oh, well, that'd be
awfully kind of you, sir.

427
00:15:50,221 --> 00:15:51,053
Not at all.

428
00:15:51,054 --> 00:15:51,887
Yes, Mr. Burton.

429
00:15:51,888 --> 00:15:55,428
Miss Jones, put a call through
to the Fosters, will you?

430
00:16:01,721 --> 00:16:03,053
Hello.

431
00:16:03,054 --> 00:16:04,074
Oh, Mr. Burton.

432
00:16:04,887 --> 00:16:07,886
No, I'm afraid Mr. Foster's not at home.

433
00:16:07,887 --> 00:16:09,553
No, sir, madam's resting.

434
00:16:09,554 --> 00:16:10,387
He's just left.

435
00:16:10,388 --> 00:16:12,928
He's catching the 1:25 to Leicester.

436
00:16:12,929 --> 00:16:16,095
I believe...

437
00:16:16,096 --> 00:16:17,637
No manners.

438
00:16:26,096 --> 00:16:27,470
Where to, sir?

439
00:16:27,471 --> 00:16:28,803
Leicester, the 1:25.

440
00:16:28,804 --> 00:16:29,804
Right.

441
00:16:36,429 --> 00:16:39,095
The 1:25 train to Bransford

442
00:16:39,096 --> 00:16:41,928
leaves from platform three.

443
00:16:41,929 --> 00:16:45,179
Calling in Leicester, Trent, Chesterfield,

444
00:16:46,596 --> 00:16:49,096
Sheffield, Leeds and...
Simon!

445
00:16:50,721 --> 00:16:52,095
Simon!

446
00:16:52,096 --> 00:16:53,220
Hello, Bertie.

447
00:16:53,221 --> 00:16:54,054
Come over here.

448
00:16:54,055 --> 00:16:57,970
I want to talk to you!

449
00:16:57,971 --> 00:16:58,804
What's the matter?

450
00:16:58,805 --> 00:16:59,845
Now, what's all this nonsense

451
00:16:59,846 --> 00:17:00,679
about you going to Leicester?

452
00:17:00,680 --> 00:17:01,512
It is not nonsense.

453
00:17:01,513 --> 00:17:02,845
I am going home to Mother.

454
00:17:02,846 --> 00:17:03,846
I've left Laura.

455
00:17:03,847 --> 00:17:04,679
Left Laura?

456
00:17:04,680 --> 00:17:05,845
Don't be silly, you can't do that.

457
00:17:05,846 --> 00:17:08,246
Not now, not when I have work for you.

458
00:17:08,804 --> 00:17:10,553
What did you say, dear boy?

459
00:17:10,554 --> 00:17:11,386
Work!

460
00:17:11,387 --> 00:17:12,304
Yes, it is extraordinary, isn't it?

461
00:17:12,305 --> 00:17:13,803
Look, we can't talk here.

462
00:17:13,804 --> 00:17:14,762
Let's go and have a drink.

463
00:17:14,763 --> 00:17:17,011
All right.

464
00:17:17,012 --> 00:17:17,928
Come on.

465
00:17:17,929 --> 00:17:18,846
Now.

466
00:17:24,022 --> 00:17:25,762
Two scotches, miss, please.

467
00:17:25,763 --> 00:17:27,011
Large ones.

468
00:17:27,012 --> 00:17:28,553
Now, Bertie, what's
all this about a job?

469
00:17:28,554 --> 00:17:31,053
Simon, I think I
deserve a pat on the back.

470
00:17:31,054 --> 00:17:32,428
I've landed you something every actor

471
00:17:32,429 --> 00:17:33,387
in this country would
give his eye teeth for.

472
00:17:33,388 --> 00:17:34,928
What, in the theatre?

473
00:17:34,929 --> 00:17:35,762
The theatre?

474
00:17:35,763 --> 00:17:37,845
Oh, don't be silly, old
boy, the theater's had it.

475
00:17:37,846 --> 00:17:38,804
Is something the matter?

476
00:17:38,805 --> 00:17:39,928
No, I'm sorry, no.

477
00:17:39,929 --> 00:17:40,762
Do forgive me.

478
00:17:40,763 --> 00:17:41,595
Don't mind me.

479
00:17:41,596 --> 00:17:42,429
But you know, just for a moment,

480
00:17:42,430 --> 00:17:44,761
I thought you were Simon Foster.

481
00:17:44,762 --> 00:17:47,303
But of course, I see
you're very much older.

482
00:17:47,304 --> 00:17:48,304
Thank you.

483
00:17:48,961 --> 00:17:50,221
What is it, a film?

484
00:17:50,222 --> 00:17:51,054
Films?

485
00:17:51,055 --> 00:17:52,428
By the time they've made up their mind

486
00:17:52,429 --> 00:17:53,595
what size and shape they're gonna be,

487
00:17:53,596 --> 00:17:54,429
they'll be through.

488
00:17:54,430 --> 00:17:56,886
3-D, 4-D, curved screen, cinerama,

489
00:17:56,887 --> 00:17:58,095
who cares if the story's no good.

490
00:17:58,096 --> 00:17:59,511
Don't spoil it.

491
00:17:59,512 --> 00:18:01,595
Bertie, I've already
made it crystal clear,

492
00:18:01,596 --> 00:18:03,178
I cannot skate.

493
00:18:03,179 --> 00:18:04,303
My dear fellow, I wouldn't dream

494
00:18:04,304 --> 00:18:05,595
of putting you on ice.

495
00:18:05,596 --> 00:18:07,179
Well, what is it?

496
00:18:09,804 --> 00:18:11,678
Television.

497
00:18:11,679 --> 00:18:13,095
Television?

498
00:18:13,096 --> 00:18:14,845
And you call that a wonderful job?

499
00:18:14,846 --> 00:18:15,679
But of course.

500
00:18:15,680 --> 00:18:16,970
Three weeks rehearsal,

501
00:18:16,971 --> 00:18:18,970
hardly enough money for
your fair to the studio,

502
00:18:18,971 --> 00:18:21,178
a technical breakdown in the
middle of your big scene,

503
00:18:21,179 --> 00:18:22,303
and no repeat performance.

504
00:18:22,304 --> 00:18:23,137
No, thank you.

505
00:18:23,138 --> 00:18:25,220
But, Simon, this is gonna be
something entirely different,

506
00:18:25,221 --> 00:18:26,928
something that may well put you and Laura

507
00:18:26,929 --> 00:18:28,178
right back...
Laura, is she in it?

508
00:18:28,179 --> 00:18:29,220
But of course!

509
00:18:29,221 --> 00:18:30,345
What's one without the other?

510
00:18:30,346 --> 00:18:32,553
Romeo and Juliet, Swan & Edgar,

511
00:18:32,554 --> 00:18:33,886
scotch and soda, Simon and Laura.

512
00:18:33,887 --> 00:18:34,804
Now, just a minute.

513
00:18:34,805 --> 00:18:36,761
In the first place, I have no intention

514
00:18:36,762 --> 00:18:37,637
of appearing on television,

515
00:18:37,638 --> 00:18:39,220
and in the second place,

516
00:18:39,221 --> 00:18:40,781
Laura and I are parting.

517
00:18:41,693 --> 00:18:43,553
I'm going home to Mother's,

518
00:18:43,554 --> 00:18:44,471
and that is final.

519
00:18:44,472 --> 00:18:46,220
Now, Simon, look, be sensible.

520
00:18:46,221 --> 00:18:47,470
Uh, excuse me!

521
00:18:47,471 --> 00:18:49,387
Nine shillings, please.

522
00:18:51,810 --> 00:18:53,970
Bertie, you're wasting your time.

523
00:18:53,971 --> 00:18:56,428
Nothing could persuade me
to work with Laura anymore.

524
00:18:56,429 --> 00:18:58,720
But you know you're
marvellous when you're together.

525
00:18:58,721 --> 00:19:00,470
Mm, if you'd seen what
went on this morning,

526
00:19:00,471 --> 00:19:01,387
you wouldn't be too sure.

527
00:19:01,388 --> 00:19:02,304
Leave it Bertie.

528
00:19:02,305 --> 00:19:03,345
I'll fix all that.

529
00:19:03,346 --> 00:19:05,720
Look, it'd take more than
one piffling TV engagement

530
00:19:05,721 --> 00:19:06,596
to bring us together again.

531
00:19:06,597 --> 00:19:07,970
This isn't one engagement, you clod,

532
00:19:07,971 --> 00:19:09,053
it's for every day!

533
00:19:09,054 --> 00:19:09,887
What do you mean every day?

534
00:19:09,888 --> 00:19:11,261
Five days a week, 52 weeks of the year.

535
00:19:11,262 --> 00:19:13,595
In three months, you'll
be a national figure.

536
00:19:13,596 --> 00:19:15,553
Ah, there's David Prentice now.

537
00:19:15,554 --> 00:19:17,553
Arriving together, that's a good omen.

538
00:19:17,554 --> 00:19:19,054
I'm glad you think so.

539
00:19:30,929 --> 00:19:32,345
David, dear boy.

540
00:19:32,346 --> 00:19:33,886
This is Simon Foster.

541
00:19:33,887 --> 00:19:34,928
How do you do?

542
00:19:34,929 --> 00:19:36,189
How do you do, sir?

543
00:19:37,762 --> 00:19:40,262
Well, come along in.

544
00:19:42,720 --> 00:19:44,220
Good afternoon, Wilson.

545
00:19:44,221 --> 00:19:45,054
- Good afternoon.
- Where's your mistress,

546
00:19:45,055 --> 00:19:45,886
Wilson?

547
00:19:45,887 --> 00:19:46,721
Upstairs, sir.

548
00:19:46,722 --> 00:19:47,845
Will you tell her Mr. Burton's here

549
00:19:47,846 --> 00:19:49,261
on business with a producer.

550
00:19:49,262 --> 00:19:50,262
Yes, sir.

551
00:19:55,471 --> 00:19:57,553
Oh, you must forgive my staring.

552
00:19:57,554 --> 00:19:58,803
It's disconcerting, I know,

553
00:19:58,804 --> 00:20:01,220
but nowadays, I see
everything in terms of angles.

554
00:20:01,221 --> 00:20:02,720
That must make it a bit tricky

555
00:20:02,721 --> 00:20:03,928
when you're addressing a golf ball.

556
00:20:03,929 --> 00:20:05,303
Oh, I don't play golf.

557
00:20:05,304 --> 00:20:07,224
No, I didn't think you would.

558
00:20:07,666 --> 00:20:09,886
Yes, yours is a face with problems.

559
00:20:09,887 --> 00:20:12,220
You, to coin a phrase, are telling me.

560
00:20:12,221 --> 00:20:13,553
No, I mean camera problems,

561
00:20:13,554 --> 00:20:15,386
but a lot, of course, can
be done with lighting.

562
00:20:15,387 --> 00:20:17,303
Yes, or you could
put it behind the sofa.

563
00:20:17,304 --> 00:20:18,345
Do come in.

564
00:20:18,346 --> 00:20:19,346
Oh, thank you.

565
00:20:20,387 --> 00:20:22,261
Ah, this is a good room.

566
00:20:22,262 --> 00:20:24,678
Oh, do you think it has
a spiritual atmosphere?

567
00:20:24,679 --> 00:20:26,839
No, I mean from our point of view.

568
00:20:27,591 --> 00:20:29,511
Madam presents her compliments

569
00:20:29,512 --> 00:20:30,928
and asks me to assure you

570
00:20:30,929 --> 00:20:32,220
she'll be with you immediately.

571
00:20:32,221 --> 00:20:34,021
Thank you very much, Wilson.

572
00:20:35,512 --> 00:20:37,136
Was that your manservant?

573
00:20:37,137 --> 00:20:38,054
Oh, Wilson, yes.

574
00:20:38,055 --> 00:20:39,595
He was an actor, and he was my dresser...

575
00:20:39,596 --> 00:20:40,678
Ah, an actor.

576
00:20:40,679 --> 00:20:41,512
Ah yes, I thought so.

577
00:20:41,513 --> 00:20:43,136
He's a natural.

578
00:20:43,137 --> 00:20:44,577
He moves, doesn't he?

579
00:20:45,429 --> 00:20:46,929
From time to time, yes.

580
00:20:49,971 --> 00:20:50,971
Aha!

581
00:20:51,637 --> 00:20:53,553
Laura, darling.

582
00:20:53,554 --> 00:20:54,386
Bertie!

583
00:20:54,387 --> 00:20:55,221
Laura, I want you to meet

584
00:20:55,222 --> 00:20:58,386
a very brilliant young
producer, David Prentice.

585
00:20:58,387 --> 00:20:59,387
Hello!

586
00:21:00,554 --> 00:21:01,845
Uh h-hello.

587
00:21:01,846 --> 00:21:05,221
David, what on earth are you doing here?

588
00:21:05,426 --> 00:21:07,346
Well, if you come and sit down

589
00:21:07,347 --> 00:21:08,886
and relax, he'll probably tell you.

590
00:21:08,887 --> 00:21:10,803
I thought you were on
your way to Leicester.

591
00:21:10,804 --> 00:21:11,637
I'm getting a later train.

592
00:21:11,638 --> 00:21:12,720
Don't miss it, dear.

593
00:21:12,721 --> 00:21:13,553
Don't worry.

594
00:21:13,554 --> 00:21:16,134
If I do, I'll sleep in the waiting room.

595
00:21:16,135 --> 00:21:17,261
Isn't it absurd?

596
00:21:17,262 --> 00:21:19,636
Always pretending to be
fighting, such children.

597
00:21:19,637 --> 00:21:21,595
David, come and sit here by me

598
00:21:21,596 --> 00:21:23,095
and tell me what it's all about.

599
00:21:23,096 --> 00:21:25,053
Oh, um, well, do you mind

600
00:21:25,054 --> 00:21:26,928
if I sort of wonder about a bit?

601
00:21:26,929 --> 00:21:27,762
Oh, please do?

602
00:21:27,763 --> 00:21:29,345
May I slip my jacket off?

603
00:21:29,346 --> 00:21:30,386
Is it hot in here?

604
00:21:30,387 --> 00:21:33,678
Well, no, but I always
think better with it off.

605
00:21:33,679 --> 00:21:36,595
Well, I am here because CT.

606
00:21:36,596 --> 00:21:37,429
CT?

607
00:21:37,430 --> 00:21:39,345
Oh, he's the controller of television

608
00:21:39,346 --> 00:21:43,011
and DTD, he's the director
of television drama,

609
00:21:43,012 --> 00:21:45,053
well, they have given me the go-ahead

610
00:21:45,054 --> 00:21:47,428
on a new programme which
deals with the private life

611
00:21:47,429 --> 00:21:50,849
of a celebrated couple who
are really happily married.

612
00:21:55,054 --> 00:21:56,054
Who was that?

613
00:21:56,055 --> 00:21:57,178
Well, the governor's come back.

614
00:21:57,179 --> 00:21:59,011
I hope he doesn't want his lunch.

615
00:21:59,012 --> 00:21:59,846
Why?

616
00:21:59,847 --> 00:22:01,347
Because I've eaten it.

617
00:22:02,471 --> 00:22:03,471
Pardon.

618
00:22:03,472 --> 00:22:05,678
They're doing the same
thing in America, you know.

619
00:22:05,679 --> 00:22:07,470
Oh yes, and with great success.

620
00:22:07,471 --> 00:22:09,470
You probably read recently, Mrs. Foster,

621
00:22:09,471 --> 00:22:10,429
the nationwide interest over there

622
00:22:10,430 --> 00:22:13,511
when the wife in their
programme had a baby on TV.

623
00:22:13,512 --> 00:22:16,428
I hope you're not suggesting
I should do the same.

624
00:22:16,429 --> 00:22:18,636
Well, it's not absolutely essential.

625
00:22:18,637 --> 00:22:20,803
I'm so glad.

626
00:22:20,804 --> 00:22:22,553
Well, anyway, we feel,

627
00:22:22,554 --> 00:22:24,928
we feel that it is essential
that everything else

628
00:22:24,929 --> 00:22:27,720
should be as authentic as we can make it.

629
00:22:27,721 --> 00:22:30,511
You know, sort of a, well, an EWA.

630
00:22:30,512 --> 00:22:31,678
A sort of what?

631
00:22:31,679 --> 00:22:34,678
Oh, an eyewitness account.

632
00:22:34,679 --> 00:22:36,261
- Oh.
- But that.

633
00:22:36,262 --> 00:22:38,511
- I do beg your pardon, sir.
- I'm terribly sorry.

634
00:22:38,512 --> 00:22:41,220
But that is why our
couple should be not only

635
00:22:41,221 --> 00:22:44,136
well known as actors
but as a genuinely happy

636
00:22:44,137 --> 00:22:45,277
husband and wife.

637
00:22:46,258 --> 00:22:49,678
Frankly, well, it rested
between you and the Oliviers.

638
00:22:49,679 --> 00:22:52,303
But both CT and DT plumped for you.

639
00:22:52,304 --> 00:22:53,179
Oh, why?

640
00:22:53,180 --> 00:22:56,300
Because you've been
married so very much longer.

641
00:22:59,512 --> 00:23:01,804
