00:22:00,101 --> 00:22:02,518
It means sacrificing a piece

242
00:22:02,643 --> 00:22:05,013
to save a game.

243
00:22:23,057 --> 00:22:26,766
If you cut... the root.

244
00:22:26,891 --> 00:22:30,421
If you cut life at the root.

245
00:22:30,848 --> 00:22:33,468
If you are cut from the root of life,

246
00:22:34,556 --> 00:22:39,546
you die. If...
In any strategic technique,

247
00:22:40,764 --> 00:22:44,723
you need to consider saving yourself

248
00:22:44,848 --> 00:22:49,384
and sacrificing a victory card.

249
00:22:51,055 --> 00:22:54,004
If we speak of Okinawa

250
00:22:55,511 --> 00:22:59,208
with respect to Japan's main island,

251
00:23:00,136 --> 00:23:03,336
such was the sacrifice.

252
00:23:10,469 --> 00:23:13,926
The battle was lost in advance,

253
00:23:14,051 --> 00:23:17,968
a battle the Japanese army

254
00:23:18,093 --> 00:23:22,051
had no chance of winning.

255
00:23:22,176 --> 00:23:26,342
It was inscribed
in the context of defeat.

256
00:23:26,467 --> 00:23:31,467
And because that was the context,

257
00:23:31,592 --> 00:23:37,049
the purpose was to fix the aftermath,

258
00:23:37,174 --> 00:23:39,716
and reinforce the "Tennosei",
the imperial system,

259
00:23:39,841 --> 00:23:43,799
which had to survive
to the military defeat.

260
00:23:43,924 --> 00:23:49,381
Another direct consecuence

261
00:23:49,506 --> 00:23:52,631
inscribed in this context of defeat,

262
00:23:52,756 --> 00:23:56,839
was that no effort was made

263
00:23:56,964 --> 00:24:02,672
to protect the civilian population,

264
00:24:02,797 --> 00:24:08,047
so civilian casualties far outnumbered

265
00:24:08,172 --> 00:24:12,129
military casualties.

266
00:24:12,254 --> 00:24:18,294
It's true that Okinawa
was a horrendous battle.

267
00:24:18,419 --> 00:24:22,378
Nothing remains, no culture heritage,

268
00:24:22,503 --> 00:24:25,752
no culture from the past.

269
00:24:25,877 --> 00:24:28,334
Everything was destroyed,

270
00:24:28,459 --> 00:24:31,044
utterly destroyed.

271
00:24:31,169 --> 00:24:34,419
I who love so much the past,

272
00:24:34,544 --> 00:24:39,876
in Okinawa I feel a deep despair.

273
00:24:40,001 --> 00:24:43,126
In a way, the people of Okinawa

274
00:24:43,251 --> 00:24:48,208
are resentful, even today.

275
00:24:48,333 --> 00:24:51,708
There is a profound
feeling of injustice

276
00:24:51,833 --> 00:24:54,499
on account of those events.

277
00:24:54,999 --> 00:24:56,549
I think the war isn't over yet.

278
00:25:02,374 --> 00:25:05,248
In conversation, I still mention
the levels

279
00:25:05,373 --> 00:25:07,623
we used to give to people

280
00:25:07,748 --> 00:25:08,748
when we spoke.

281
00:25:09,998 --> 00:25:12,165
When someone came and said:

282
00:25:12,290 --> 00:25:16,414
"I am Catholic, or Communist,
or Anarchist",

283
00:25:16,539 --> 00:25:21,123
or any other bigotry, we would say:

284
00:25:21,248 --> 00:25:24,244
"Level One!"
We'd laugh so much!

285
00:25:28,289 --> 00:25:32,447
When they were funnier, or wittier,

286
00:25:32,580 --> 00:25:34,616
we'd say: "Level Two!"

287
00:25:35,953 --> 00:25:37,990
But it never went higher.

288
00:25:40,994 --> 00:25:43,618
The Game became such a standard

289
00:25:43,743 --> 00:25:46,993
that we could do nothing
unless we gave levels

290
00:25:47,118 --> 00:25:49,323
to everything in life.

291
00:25:51,909 --> 00:25:54,991
But nothing ever reached Level 5.

292
00:25:57,451 --> 00:26:00,070
I remember one day I said to you:

293
00:26:01,367 --> 00:26:04,614
"Must one die to get to Level Five?"

294
00:26:14,241 --> 00:26:15,824
She had enjoyed Okinawa.

295
00:26:15,949 --> 00:26:19,032
She had loved the ice in summer.

296
00:26:19,157 --> 00:26:21,741
She had loved Naha, a spiritless
city, apparently,

297
00:26:21,866 --> 00:26:25,313
yet full of ghosts,
and they loved ghosts.

298
00:26:41,405 --> 00:26:44,113
She had loved the jungle figs indoors,

299
00:26:44,238 --> 00:26:46,613
and birdsong at traffic lights

300
00:26:46,738 --> 00:26:49,155
that got the blind across.

301
00:26:49,280 --> 00:26:52,277
It was Japan, yet that Japan
that hadn't lost its memory.

302
00:27:03,443 --> 00:27:05,932
There were cats too,
for they loved cats.

303
00:27:06,902 --> 00:27:10,315
There were tags, and owls and karate.

304
00:27:16,818 --> 00:27:20,109
And their cult-film: a ghost story.

305
00:27:20,234 --> 00:27:22,732
Seeing together there
was a sign to them,

306
00:27:22,857 --> 00:27:24,434
and they loved signs.

307
00:27:27,067 --> 00:27:30,314
That's when you started
calling me Laura.

308
00:27:32,066 --> 00:27:34,103
We loved the film.

309
00:27:37,566 --> 00:27:40,598
We didn't know about the song yet.

310
00:27:44,398 --> 00:27:49,731
I was amazed you could fall
for an image,

311
00:27:49,941 --> 00:27:53,720
then have a real lady
appear in its stead.

312
00:27:55,690 --> 00:27:58,722
Can one be as lovely as an image?

313
00:27:59,689 --> 00:28:03,100
Can one be as memorable as a song?

314
00:28:09,397 --> 00:28:12,726
I remember about David Raksin,

315
00:28:13,603 --> 00:28:16,144
commissioned to write a song

316
00:28:16,269 --> 00:28:20,059
over the weekend for Mr Preminger.

317
00:28:20,184 --> 00:28:23,183
You don't keep Mr Preminger waiting.

318
00:28:25,393 --> 00:28:29,717
He'd got a letter from his wife
which he couldn't decipher.

319
00:28:33,143 --> 00:28:37,476
He wasn't short-sighted,
but something odd inside him

320
00:28:37,601 --> 00:28:41,594
prevented him from being able
to read it.

321
00:28:42,683 --> 00:28:46,892
He used to compose by placing
a sheet of paper

322
00:28:47,017 --> 00:28:51,839
on the piano to focus his attention,

323
00:28:52,849 --> 00:28:56,890
so the music flowed from a void,

324
00:28:57,974 --> 00:28:59,973
not from an idea.

325
00:29:00,098 --> 00:29:03,223
And he took his wife's letter
that he couldn't decipher

326
00:29:03,348 --> 00:29:06,132
and put it on the piano.

327
00:29:06,765 --> 00:29:09,927
Then the notes started to flow.

328
00:29:10,680 --> 00:29:14,460
And as they flowed, as they fell,

329
00:29:14,848 --> 00:29:18,709
he began to decipher the words.

330
00:29:20,304 --> 00:29:23,919
They said his wife was leaving him.

331
00:29:35,511 --> 00:29:37,548
And me too, when

332
00:29:38,969 --> 00:29:42,417
I decipher your programme,
I don't understand it fully.

333
00:29:44,426 --> 00:29:47,175
It seems complicated,
I'm afraid I'll mess it up,

334
00:29:47,300 --> 00:29:50,583
I'm afraid I'll find things hidden

335
00:29:54,467 --> 00:29:58,791
that flow out without my noticing.

336
00:29:59,716 --> 00:30:02,717
Like in a storm when there's a fog

337
00:30:02,842 --> 00:30:08,375
and suddenly the sun pierces through
and truth appears.

338
00:30:08,591 --> 00:30:10,628
I'm afraid...

339
00:30:11,341 --> 00:30:16,715
I'll find something's
going to happen there

340
00:30:16,840 --> 00:30:18,877
which I can't see yet,

341
00:30:20,340 --> 00:30:22,377
something that suddenly

342
00:30:23,090 --> 00:30:27,672
will seem as potent as a song

343
00:30:27,797 --> 00:30:30,795
suddenly not ours anymore,

344
00:30:31,839 --> 00:30:34,125
but everyone's to share,

345
00:30:35,047 --> 00:30:39,669
just as Laura's song
has become ours... now.

346
00:31:51,830 --> 00:31:54,071
Can you hear my footsteps?

347
00:32:30,743 --> 00:32:33,574
That summer, a store
hired dancers from Kyoto,

348
00:32:33,699 --> 00:32:36,200
there in the big island,
the true Japan.

349
00:32:36,325 --> 00:32:38,150
Where, in 1944, they'd sent

350
00:32:40,075 --> 00:32:42,824
thousands of children for safety.

351
00:32:42,949 --> 00:32:44,699
No one asked their parents,

352
00:32:44,824 --> 00:32:49,032
for 4 centuries no one
asked anything to the Okinawans.

353
00:32:49,157 --> 00:32:52,199
The children were put on a ship
and the ship sank.

354
00:32:52,324 --> 00:32:54,374
1000 dead. Even before
the battle started,

355
00:32:56,198 --> 00:32:59,781
Okinawa had its dead,
only they didn't know.

356
00:32:59,906 --> 00:33:02,198
Survivors were told to send cards

357
00:33:02,323 --> 00:33:06,150
saying everything was fine,
everyone had landed safely.

358
00:33:10,405 --> 00:33:13,072
Ten years later, Oshima
filmed the parents

359
00:33:13,197 --> 00:33:16,613
gathered where the ship sank,
to console the souls,

360
00:33:16,738 --> 00:33:20,518
as the Japanese saying goes,
of their drowned children.

361
00:35:33,056 --> 00:35:36,753
Seen from the sky, Okinawa's main island
looks like a beast.

362
00:35:37,348 --> 00:35:40,347
Not a green crocodile like Cuba,

363
00:35:40,472 --> 00:35:43,839
rather a crouched beast,

364
00:35:45,014 --> 00:35:47,633
ready to jump, to unfurl

365
00:35:47,972 --> 00:35:51,096
into who knows what form:

366
00:35:51,221 --> 00:35:53,343
a lizard, a dragon?

367
00:35:53,929 --> 00:35:57,554
As if all History's fierceness,

368
00:35:57,679 --> 00:35:59,636
was in that island,

369
00:35:59,761 --> 00:36:03,345
where people are so peaceble
they infuriate History

370
00:36:03,470 --> 00:36:06,800
for having something to do with them.

371
00:36:07,596 --> 00:36:10,635
It's like Julius Caesar
moving to Bora Bora.

372
00:36:10,760 --> 00:36:12,799
Or Napoleon in the South Pole.

373
00:36:14,720 --> 00:36:17,671
St Helena was no fun anyway.

374
00:36:20,092 --> 00:36:22,129
Strange to think that

375
00:36:23,592 --> 00:36:26,800
the first ever mention of Okinawa

376
00:36:26,925 --> 00:36:30,373
was on account of him.

377
00:36:32,091 --> 00:36:34,092
An English Captain came to him

378
00:36:34,217 --> 00:36:36,716
after going around the Pacific,

379
00:36:36,841 --> 00:36:40,917
and described a strange little island,

380
00:36:41,466 --> 00:36:43,835
wherein "the natives had no weapons".

381
00:36:44,966 --> 00:36:49,705
"No cannons?", says the Emperor,
somewhat disgusted.

382
00:36:51,131 --> 00:36:54,082
"No cannons, no pistols,

383
00:36:54,298 --> 00:36:57,165
no muskets,
no weapons at all."

384
00:36:57,672 --> 00:37:00,207
"How do they wage war?"

385
00:37:02,005 --> 00:37:05,003
"They don't.
They're not interested."

386
00:37:05,922 --> 00:37:08,963
Napoleon, outraged,
concluded that people

387
00:37:09,088 --> 00:37:12,832
who don't love war
are most "despicable".

388
00:37:17,961 --> 00:37:21,211
So thought the island,

389
00:37:21,336 --> 00:37:24,503
the big dragon hidden in the island,

390
00:37:24,628 --> 00:37:28,622
ready to pounce like a cat,

391
00:37:29,335 --> 00:37:33,958
like a tiger
waiting for the proper time.

392
00:37:35,127 --> 00:37:38,460
Travellers enraged him,
travellers of all times,

393
00:37:38,585 --> 00:37:41,418
with tales of Okinawan's gentleness.

394
00:37:41,543 --> 00:37:46,365
Gentleness! Is history written
with gentleness?

395
00:37:47,583 --> 00:37:50,782
Do you honour gentleness
when you're a dragon?

396
00:37:53,333 --> 00:37:56,416
So Okinawans hated violence?

397
00:37:56,541 --> 00:37:58,697
They had it coming.

398
00:37:59,874 --> 00:38:02,832
A peaceful isle out of the world,

399
00:38:02,957 --> 00:38:07,873
out of History, would become the stage

400
00:38:07,998 --> 00:38:11,079
of the bloodiest battle of all time.

401
00:38:11,915 --> 00:38:15,575
A happy, life-loving woman

402
00:38:16,955 --> 00:38:19,491
was chosen to encounter death.

403
00:38:21,664 --> 00:38:24,531
I recognise myself
in that little island,

404
00:38:26,163 --> 00:38:29,326
because my suffering,

405
00:38:30,704 --> 00:38:32,079
my most unique suffering,

406
00:38:33,663 --> 00:38:38,118
my most intimate suffering
is also the most banal,

407
00:38:40,953 --> 00:38:43,406
the easiest to name,

408
00:38:45,328 --> 00:38:47,366
So...

409
00:38:48,452 --> 00:38:52,613
It's irrelevant to give it a name
that sounds like a song,

410
00:38:53,953 --> 00:38:55,989
like a movie,

411
00:38:58,576 --> 00:39:00,614
"Okinawa mon amour..."

412
00:39:02,367 --> 00:39:10,367
The Americans landed
in the Kerama islands.

413
00:39:16,449 --> 00:39:24,449
They bombed Naha from there.

414
00:39:34,322 --> 00:39:38,446
Look, we had a swim
over there yesterday.

415
00:39:49,904 --> 00:39:54,028
I'm sure you've read
about it in the papers,

416
00:39:54,153 --> 00:40:00,317
mass suicide in the Kerama islands...

417
00:40:03,070 --> 00:40:07,643
I read page after page on Okinawa

418
00:40:09,236 --> 00:40:11,475
and I feel like crying.

419
00:40:13,152 --> 00:40:17,609
The only place in the world,
the Nazi camps aside, where people

420
00:40:17,734 --> 00:40:19,773
continued to die after the battle.

421
00:40:22,650 --> 00:40:25,358
The islanders weren't true Japanese,

422
00:40:25,483 --> 00:40:27,817
but were Japanese enough to die.

423
00:40:27,942 --> 00:40:31,981
"No one falls into enemy hands alive,
it is shameful".

424
00:40:32,107 --> 00:40:38,815
We were imbued with army orders
stating that,

425
00:40:38,940 --> 00:40:44,898
if necessary, meaning
when encountering the enemy,

426
00:40:45,023 --> 00:40:50,772
the first granade was for the enemy

427
00:40:50,897 --> 00:40:55,056
and the second we had to use
for suicide.

428
00:40:57,230 --> 00:41:00,522
Two months later, one of the most famous
images of that battle

429
00:41:00,647 --> 00:41:04,771
showed a little girl
waving a white flag

430
00:41:04,896 --> 00:41:08,563
at the head of a line
of civilians and soldiers.

431
00:41:08,688 --> 00:41:11,853
Okinawa would remember that symbol:

432
00:41:11,978 --> 00:41:15,061
A child survivor of forced suicide

433
00:41:15,186 --> 00:41:19,097
put out to protect an Army in ruins.

434
00:41:42,183 --> 00:41:44,221
See that?

435
00:41:45,766 --> 00:41:48,848
You'll be on American TV.

436
00:41:52,807 --> 00:41:55,474
And because we were convinced
this was what war was,

437
00:41:55,599 --> 00:41:57,973
that everyone was
doing this to everyone,

438
00:41:58,098 --> 00:42:01,890
because they must not shame,
a superior race,

439
00:42:02,015 --> 00:42:06,388
a model for humanity,
and because they were nice,

440
00:42:07,180 --> 00:42:10,131
and because they were helpful

441
00:42:10,971 --> 00:42:14,633
and wanted to do what
was expected of them,

442
00:42:15,222 --> 00:42:18,422
and wanted to prove Napoleon wrong,

443
00:42:21,138 --> 00:42:26,802
they killed themselves...
in their thousands, whole families.

444
00:42:28,679 --> 00:42:32,044
With a granade, if the Army
has supplied granades,

445
00:42:33,386 --> 00:42:36,550
with sticks if they had no granades

446
00:42:37,470 --> 00:42:40,751
or by jumping off cliffs,

447
00:42:42,594 --> 00:42:45,508
like the women of Saipan had done.

448
00:42:47,636 --> 00:42:50,503
I'd seen these images before.

449
00:42:51,885 --> 00:42:57,253
In slow-motion you can see
this woman turn back,

450
00:42:58,593 --> 00:43:00,465
and spot the camera.

451
00:43:01,468 --> 00:43:05,591
Do we know she would have jumped
if at the last minute

452
00:43:05,841 --> 00:43:08,672
she hadn't known she was watched?

453
00:43:13,048 --> 00:43:17,090
I remember the man in Paris, in 1900

454
00:43:17,382 --> 00:43:21,922
attempting a mad leap
with a Batman-like parachute

455
00:43:22,047 --> 00:43:24,965
from the Eiffel Tower.

456
00:43:25,090 --> 00:43:27,329
It's so obvious,

457
00:43:27,754 --> 00:43:30,208
at least it is to me,

458
00:43:32,130 --> 00:43:34,878
that at the last minute,

459
00:43:36,672 --> 00:43:39,420
he knows the contraption won't work,

460
00:43:39,963 --> 00:43:42,000
he knows he'll die,

461
00:43:43,338 --> 00:43:45,577
but the camera is there.

462
00:43:46,546 --> 00:43:48,582
He can't chicken out,

463
00:43:48,920 --> 00:43:52,416
so he jumps and dies.

464
00:43:57,502 --> 00:44:00,252
The woman in Saipan saw the lens
and knew

465
00:44:00,377 --> 00:44:03,044
that foreign devils
would show the world

466
00:44:03,169 --> 00:44:06,865
she hadn't had the guts to jump.

467
00:44:07,376 --> 00:44:11,156
So she jumps. The cameraman
aimed at her

468
00:44:12,460 --> 00:44:17,495
like a hunter through his sights,

469
00:44:19,250 --> 00:44:22,947
and he shot her like a hunter.

470
00:44:39,405 --> 00:44:43,103
This is a little book entitled
"The tragedy of Okinawa".

471
00:44:43,823 --> 00:44:47,697
The print is odd,
with characters spaced

472
00:44:47,822 --> 00:44:50,447
like in a primer.

473
00:44:50,572 --> 00:44:54,447
It's very thin,
the lines are doublespaced.

474
00:44:54,572 --> 00:44:57,154
It's like it intends
to teach how to read,

475
00:44:57,279 --> 00:45:00,064
and how not to read.

476
00:45:00,988 --> 00:45:02,904
No book can explain

477
00:45:03,029 --> 00:45:05,730
how a 16 years old boy kills his mother

478
00:45:07,361 --> 00:45:10,861
beacause an invisible camera
spies on him,

479
00:45:10,986 --> 00:45:13,653
and he cannot desobey.

480
00:45:15,860 --> 00:45:18,609
The boy's name was Kinjo,

481
00:45:19,277 --> 00:45:22,276
he lived in Tokashiki Island,

482
00:45:23,069 --> 00:45:26,315
where you used to go whale-watching.

483
00:45:27,109 --> 00:45:31,185
What could he tell us now, Kinjo?

484
00:45:33,026 --> 00:45:35,479
What could we say to him?

485
00:45:36,943 --> 00:45:38,483
Know what?

486
00:45:38,608 --> 00:45:41,775
When I began to choke, literally choke,

487
00:45:41,900 --> 00:45:46,106
among this horror
where everyone is a persecutor,

488
00:45:46,231 --> 00:45:49,894
I put a flag in the program

489
00:45:50,023 --> 00:45:52,264
that'll prompt a quote.

490
00:45:53,024 --> 00:45:56,022
Too bad for those who don't get it.

491
00:45:56,147 --> 00:46:00,148
You know it.
It was in the Keepsake

492
00:46:00,273 --> 00:46:05,806
where I saved sentences for tough times.

493
00:46:06,855 --> 00:46:08,893
Thinking ahead...

494
00:46:11,647 --> 00:46:14,021
It's Rabbi Huna's admonition.

495
00:46:14,146 --> 00:46:18,091
Maybe most people won't understand.

496
00:46:20,313 --> 00:46:22,350
It's the one that goes:

497
00:46:23,978 --> 00:46:28,102
"God always sides with the persecuted.

498
00:46:29,021 --> 00:46:32,599
If a just man persecutes a just man,

499
00:46:33,020 --> 00:46:35,852
God sides with the persecuted;

500
00:46:35,977 --> 00:46:38,352
if a bad man persecutes a just man,

501
00:46:38,477 --> 00:46:41,519
God sides with the persecuted;

502
00:46:41,644 --> 00:46:43,976
if a bad man persecutes a bad man,

503
00:46:44,101 --> 00:46:46,809
God sides with the persecuted;

504
00:46:46,934 --> 00:46:50,715
and even if a just man
persecutes a bad man,

505
00:46:51,018 --> 00:46:54,715
God sides with the persecuted".

506
00:47:12,806 --> 00:47:16,098
These bullfights, like in Mycenae...

507
00:47:16,223 --> 00:47:17,931
In Spain when there's a bullfight

508
00:47:18,056 --> 00:47:21,389
it's to challenge death,
you stare at the sun,

509
00:47:21,514 --> 00:47:27,297
stare at death in the face, like
in the fascist anthem "Cara al sol".

510
00:47:31,804 --> 00:47:34,261
In Okinawa, it's the opposite:

511
00:47:34,386 --> 00:47:39,377
They say that before death
is a time for playing,

512
00:47:41,928 --> 00:47:43,753
not a time for killing.

513
00:48:49,963 --> 00:48:52,713
- It's a brave animal.
- But it's not in shape.

514
00:48:52,838 --> 00:48:58,463
- Can it do better?
- It's really brave.

515
00:48:58,588 --> 00:49:04,950
- It has no luck.
- It's a brave beast.

516
00:49:40,657 --> 00:49:46,274
If some future ethnologist
gets to see these images,

517
00:49:46,532 --> 00:49:48,740
he'll ponder the funeral rites

518
00:49:48,865 --> 00:49:53,900
of the strange tribes
of the late 20th Century.

519
00:49:54,780 --> 00:49:58,115
I'll be pleased to give details.

520
00:49:58,240 --> 00:50:01,447
Yes, it was customary for such tribes

521
00:50:01,572 --> 00:50:05,322
to address a familiar
and protective spirit

522
00:50:05,447 --> 00:50:08,029
known as a computer to some of them

523
00:50:08,154 --> 00:50:10,571
and as an electronic calculator
to others.

524
00:50:10,696 --> 00:50:13,446
They'd consult on everything,

525
00:50:13,571 --> 00:50:17,986
it kept their memory.
In fact, they no longer had a memory,

526
00:50:18,111 --> 00:50:20,517
it was their memory.

527
00:50:22,611 --> 00:50:25,609
It was accompanied by a whole ritual.

528
00:50:26,778 --> 00:50:30,610
The ethnologist from the future
doesn't know what he's missing,

529
00:50:30,735 --> 00:50:35,485
by not following me in the morning,
between switching the computer on

530
00:50:35,610 --> 00:50:38,776
and coming later to work on it.

531
00:50:38,901 --> 00:50:42,359
He could send a spy camera,

532
00:50:42,484 --> 00:50:46,893
and see me having breakfast
with two cups,

533
00:50:47,858 --> 00:50:51,224
hanging out two towels,

534
00:50:53,734 --> 00:50:57,429
placing two toothbrushes in a glass..

535
00:51:01,358 --> 00:51:06,145
Pardon me, dear ethnologist,
this is not really for you.

536
00:51:07,355 --> 00:51:10,690
It's for Gloria,
when she comes to clean for me,

537
00:51:10,815 --> 00:51:13,432
and for passing friends.

538
00:51:13,731 --> 00:51:15,851
It re-assures them.

539
00:51:16,398 --> 00:51:21,105
They think: "Laura has got someone
in her life. She plays the mistery girl,

540
00:51:21,230 --> 00:51:26,467
but I know the tell-tale signs".

541
00:51:29,854 --> 00:51:33,765
If they suspected my
encounters with you,

542
00:51:35,604 --> 00:51:37,724
they'de be aghast.

543
00:51:41,436 --> 00:51:44,853
In The Girl with the Golden Eyes,
Marsay refers to screen-women,

544
00:51:44,978 --> 00:51:48,971
women you display
to hide the one that matters.

545
00:51:49,727 --> 00:51:54,186
I've got a screen-man, with my cups

546
00:51:54,311 --> 00:51:57,805
and my towels and my toothbrushes.

547
00:51:58,809 --> 00:52:05,848
Only he's the hidden one
and you're invisible.

548
00:52:10,142 --> 00:52:13,306
You can't make a better ménage à troi.

549
00:52:14,058 --> 00:52:17,340
Well. Back to the grind.

550
00:52:51,721 --> 00:52:54,173
The Knowledge-standard...

551
00:52:54,303 --> 00:52:58,095
When you saw the knowledge
available on the net,

552
00:52:58,220 --> 00:53:00,261
you could smile.

553
00:53:00,386 --> 00:53:02,428
But that was exactly their game:

554
00:53:02,553 --> 00:53:10,042
have information ever further
and faster.

555
00:53:10,969 --> 00:53:14,801
In past times, to lend weight to money,

556
00:53:14,926 --> 00:53:18,552
they sought a dense, rare material

557
00:53:18,677 --> 00:53:21,718
to act as a pledge inside coffers.

558
00:53:21,843 --> 00:53:24,175
They chose gold.

559
00:53:24,300 --> 00:53:28,217
Money became invisible and volatile,

560
00:53:28,342 --> 00:53:30,133
so the new power needed a pledge

561
00:53:30,258 --> 00:53:33,966
that was invisible and volatile too.

562
00:53:34,091 --> 00:53:36,424
They found Knowledge.

563
00:53:36,549 --> 00:53:40,299
Atoms of knowledge
came through our screen,

564
00:53:40,424 --> 00:53:44,048
It was into Knowledge's black holes...

565
00:53:44,173 --> 00:53:47,590
that fell this century's dreams
of power. This unending century.

566
00:53:47,715 --> 00:53:51,340
The screen tore into black shapes

567
00:53:51,465 --> 00:53:54,297
reminiscent of other forms,
wherein the century

568
00:53:54,422 --> 00:53:57,338
had made the blueprints
for its own suicide,

569
00:53:57,463 --> 00:54:02,167
engraving images in our minds.
Images of ruins:

570
00:54:02,339 --> 00:54:08,286
The ruins of Coventry and
Berlin, of Dresden and Stalingrad.

571
00:54:09,254 --> 00:54:12,168
The ruins of Okinawa.

572
00:54:40,751 --> 00:54:44,660
Yesterday I set the puzzle
as a screensaver.

573
00:54:45,542 --> 00:54:46,958
Very appropriate.

574
00:54:47,083 --> 00:54:50,584
I have the impression that
you left me in a huge puzzle,

575
00:54:50,709 --> 00:54:52,999
with the discouraging thought that,

576
00:54:53,124 --> 00:54:56,620
in the end, there'd be no image.

577
00:54:57,124 --> 00:55:02,030
Pretty modern.
A puzzle about itself.

578
00:55:03,165 --> 00:55:05,207
Our grandmothers' puzzles were

579
00:55:05,332 --> 00:55:09,705
the Mona Lisa, the Night Watch.

580
00:55:09,830 --> 00:55:14,664
I imagine a perfect gift
for the century's end,

581
00:55:14,789 --> 00:55:19,078
that might be an Yves Klein puzzle.

582
00:55:21,286 --> 00:55:26,663
Strategy games are made
to win back lost battles. No?

583
00:55:26,788 --> 00:55:30,411
Did you really think a player would

584
00:55:30,536 --> 00:55:33,328
just repeat history
the whole night long

585
00:55:33,453 --> 00:55:37,743
and learn he could only play
his part one way?

586
00:55:38,536 --> 00:55:41,652
I tried the Marienbad game.

587
00:55:42,827 --> 00:55:45,535
After a few moves the computer said:

588
00:55:45,660 --> 00:55:48,077
"I won already,

589
00:55:48,202 --> 00:55:51,946
but we may go on if you like".

590
00:55:54,868 --> 00:55:57,570
Death could say that.

591
00:56:02,659 --> 00:56:05,117
The south of Okinawa is an anthill

592
00:56:05,242 --> 00:56:08,450
with thousand of caves and tunnels

593
00:56:08,575 --> 00:56:11,117
fortified by High Command.

594
00:56:11,242 --> 00:56:14,199
The frontline is at Shuri,

595
00:56:14,324 --> 00:56:17,275
where Ushijima's headquarters were.

596
00:56:18,867 --> 00:56:22,615
With him, General Cho,
a hardline nationalist,

597
00:56:22,740 --> 00:56:25,449
involved in the coup d'etat
in Manchuria in 1931,

598
00:56:25,574 --> 00:56:27,531
the Sino-Japanese prelude

599
00:56:27,656 --> 00:56:30,697
to World War Two.

600
00:56:30,822 --> 00:56:36,488
There is also Colonel Yahara,
a man as reflective

601
00:56:36,613 --> 00:56:40,144
as Chao is loud.
He too plays by the book.

602
00:56:43,654 --> 00:56:47,101
Reading the archives, you find proof
the three of them know:

603
00:56:47,321 --> 00:56:49,402
their mission's suicidal.

604
00:56:49,527 --> 00:56:51,735
The battle cannot be won.

605
00:56:51,860 --> 00:56:54,195
Yet there were bombastic bulletins

606
00:56:54,320 --> 00:56:56,985
and tracts proclaiming victory.

607
00:56:57,110 --> 00:57:01,652
Doubters received drastic punishment.

608
00:57:01,777 --> 00:57:03,319
In April and May,

609
00:57:03,444 --> 00:57:05,985
Cho launched mad counter-attacks.

610
00:57:06,110 --> 00:57:07,819
Since the battle is lost,

611
00:57:07,944 --> 00:57:10,693
samourai spirit is what counts.

612
00:57:10,818 --> 00:57:13,318
Japanese soldiers practising
bayonet drill

613
00:57:13,443 --> 00:57:14,859
on live prisoners,

614
00:57:14,984 --> 00:57:17,443
or choking babies in caves

615
00:57:17,568 --> 00:57:20,025
so the enemy don't hear them,

616
00:57:20,150 --> 00:57:22,188
doesn't sound so samourai-like.

617
00:57:22,608 --> 00:57:26,443
But committing suicide with granades

618
00:57:26,568 --> 00:57:30,014
in the subterranean Navy HQ
is truly in the grand tradition.

619
00:57:36,857 --> 00:57:40,316
But Maginot Lines never hold.

620
00:57:40,441 --> 00:57:42,940
Outside, the US attack progresses.

621
00:57:43,065 --> 00:57:46,024
Another famous photo shows
the Tomori lion

622
00:57:46,149 --> 00:57:48,730
surrounded by infantry men.

623
00:57:48,855 --> 00:57:52,522
I wonder what the first GI thought

624
00:57:52,647 --> 00:57:56,722
when he saw that critter.

625
00:58:01,520 --> 00:58:03,563
The lion still guards its village,

626
00:58:03,688 --> 00:58:05,354
since its mission was to protect it.

627
00:58:05,479 --> 00:58:08,603
Visitors never fail

628
00:58:08,728 --> 00:58:12,259
to leave coins in its mouth,
for good luck.

629
00:58:16,894 --> 00:58:19,808
They chuck coins in the tunnels too.

630
00:58:23,394 --> 00:58:26,476
In a bunker like this,
Yahara writes in his diary

631
00:58:26,601 --> 00:58:30,101
that before the final rout,

632
00:58:30,226 --> 00:58:32,768
he took the time
to destroy all his papers

633
00:58:32,893 --> 00:58:37,845
and rearrange the furniture
"to leave a good impression".

634
00:58:43,351 --> 00:58:46,430
I found one Kinjo
in one of your listings,

635
00:58:46,932 --> 00:58:49,974
I was obsessed by that boy

636
00:58:50,099 --> 00:58:52,349
who had killed his family

637
00:58:52,474 --> 00:58:54,932
to obey a tacit order

638
00:58:55,057 --> 00:58:57,849
engraved on his child's mind.

639
00:58:57,974 --> 00:59:01,470
"No one falls into enemy hands alive".

640
00:59:02,015 --> 00:59:05,594
The syllables of his name sum it up.

641
00:59:07,847 --> 00:59:10,169
I was disappointed.

642
00:59:10,472 --> 00:59:13,555
That Kinjo is in Yahara's book,

643
00:59:13,680 --> 00:59:16,846
one of the many boys of Okinawa

644
00:59:16,971 --> 00:59:21,263
drafted under the engaging motto:
"By blood and by iron".

645
00:59:21,388 --> 00:59:24,760
Not even soldiers,

646
00:59:24,885 --> 00:59:29,757
they're just trying to help out,
obeying orders.

647
00:59:30,261 --> 00:59:32,303
Yahara describes going by night

648
00:59:32,428 --> 00:59:35,094
to get sugar-cane, underfire,
for survival.

649
00:59:35,219 --> 00:59:41,831
Then he ran home and
hid under the bed, like a puppy.

650
00:59:43,677 --> 00:59:46,674
Yahara thinks of his own son

651
00:59:47,426 --> 00:59:52,214
and he starts to have doubts
about the War.

652
00:59:57,008 --> 01:00:00,836
But the other Kinjo,
will I ever get to understand him?

653
01:00:01,009 --> 01:00:04,424
I only know it happened
in the Kerama islands,

654
01:00:04,549 --> 01:00:09,882
where we went on a day so glorious.

655
01:00:10,424 --> 01:00:14,381
A massacre seemed inimaginable.

656
01:00:14,506 --> 01:00:17,540
The view over the archipielago.

657
01:00:18,674 --> 01:00:25,256
"The fractal islands on Klein blue",
you said,

658
01:00:25,381 --> 01:00:27,621
simple as ever.

659
01:00:29,421 --> 01:00:33,796
Kannon, Goddess of Mercy's temple,

660
01:00:33,921 --> 01:00:35,546
her statue behind glass

661
01:00:35,671 --> 01:00:39,504
that made her appear

662
01:00:39,629 --> 01:00:43,158
in her place, in the sky.

663
01:00:45,295 --> 01:00:50,200
There was also
a magical Okinawa weaver.

664
01:00:51,336 --> 01:00:54,627
Unavoidably, one calls
on all those myths

665
01:00:54,752 --> 01:00:57,169
the knotted threads of man:

666
01:00:57,294 --> 01:01:01,335
the Parcae, the Norns,

667
01:01:01,460 --> 01:01:04,209
all the figures devised by men to say

668
01:01:04,334 --> 01:01:08,624
life's thread unravels and breaks.

669
01:01:10,584 --> 01:01:13,949
Do they spin Kinjo's life still?

670
01:01:15,333 --> 01:01:20,951
What would Kinjo think before
fractal islands and Klein blue?

671
01:01:22,749 --> 01:01:25,867
Before the Goddess of Mercy?

672
01:01:35,748 --> 01:01:39,541
A few visits to Heiwa Dori,
Naha's indoors market,

673
01:01:39,666 --> 01:01:44,622
and you become aware:
it is run by women.

674
01:01:44,747 --> 01:01:49,205
All are connected with the War.
They are widows and orphans.

675
01:01:49,330 --> 01:01:52,371
Sometimes survivors.

676
01:01:52,496 --> 01:01:54,911
Most little girls of that age

677
01:01:55,036 --> 01:01:57,038
experienced mobilization, propaganda,

678
01:01:57,163 --> 01:02:00,828
a feeling that they too must fight.

679
01:02:00,953 --> 01:02:05,824
The nurses at Himeyuri-no-to
became a symbol.

680
01:02:06,077 --> 01:02:08,661
An obligatory tourist pilgrimage
in Okinawa.

681
01:02:08,786 --> 01:02:12,244
It starts with a cheerful song,

682
01:02:12,369 --> 01:02:14,904
which was their favourite.

683
01:02:48,032 --> 01:02:50,189
Then the photo sessions.

684
01:03:03,239 --> 01:03:04,823
And faces peering into a hole

685
01:03:04,948 --> 01:03:07,530
that looks like a simple hole
in the ground.

686
01:03:07,655 --> 01:03:09,697
This is the entrance
to the Himeyuri cave,

687
01:03:09,822 --> 01:03:12,029
site of the 3rd surgical unit,

688
01:03:12,154 --> 01:03:14,821
where 46 girls died suffocated

689
01:03:14,946 --> 01:03:16,738
during the final attack,

690
01:03:16,863 --> 01:03:19,819
when the Army disbanded
the Nursing Corps

691
01:03:19,944 --> 01:03:22,320
and left them to their fate,

692
01:03:22,445 --> 01:03:25,110
with orders not to surrender.

693
01:03:52,900 --> 01:03:54,567
In the local museum,

694
01:03:54,692 --> 01:03:58,934
there's a diorama of the cave
with sound and light effects.

695
01:04:01,775 --> 01:04:05,149
Next comes a "requiem" room

696
01:04:05,274 --> 01:04:09,232
with portraits of the 206 pupils
and teachers of the Himeyuri College,

697
01:04:09,357 --> 01:04:13,273
and eye-witness accounts.

698
01:04:13,398 --> 01:04:15,024
As could be expected,

699
01:04:15,149 --> 01:04:17,856
the choice of site was controversial.

700
01:04:17,981 --> 01:04:19,980
Was too much made of girls

701
01:04:20,105 --> 01:04:21,814
from the Okinawa elite

702
01:04:21,939 --> 01:04:24,398
when others were forgotten?

703
01:04:24,523 --> 01:04:27,855
As if there were privileged martyrs.

704
01:04:27,980 --> 01:04:31,646
This adds more sadness, this competition
of memory.

705
01:04:31,771 --> 01:04:34,186
My dead are deader than your dead.

706
01:04:34,311 --> 01:04:37,225
We had seen that too.

707
01:04:41,894 --> 01:04:44,436
The Game had kept only the faces.

708
01:04:44,561 --> 01:04:46,469
That was enough.

709
01:05:03,951 --> 01:05:05,951
But to understand what happened,

710
01:05:06,076 --> 01:05:10,697
one must climb down into the caves
with rope and a torch,

711
01:05:11,242 --> 01:05:14,533
then turn out the light
and try to imagine

712
01:05:14,658 --> 01:05:17,116
a teenage girl in the dark,

713
01:05:17,241 --> 01:05:22,074
with rotten corpses and
amputation without anaesthetic.

714
01:05:22,199 --> 01:05:26,240
The sound of maggots in live flesh.

715
01:05:26,365 --> 01:05:28,406
And other sounds,
the shrieks of dying men,

716
01:05:28,531 --> 01:05:30,366
the hungry begging

717
01:05:30,491 --> 01:05:33,406
for amputated limbs to be cooked.

718
01:05:33,531 --> 01:05:36,405
Try to imagine that.

719
01:05:36,530 --> 01:05:39,823
And also the wait for a resolution.

720
01:05:39,948 --> 01:05:43,028
Most likely, liquidation
with flame-throwers.

721
01:06:12,485 --> 01:06:13,859
Soon, Heiwa Dori will get normal traders

722
01:06:13,984 --> 01:06:16,233
like any other.

723
01:06:16,358 --> 01:06:20,683
Until then, the market guards
Okinawa's memory.

724
01:06:24,775 --> 01:06:27,643
Its ladies are grave-keepers.

725
01:06:44,690 --> 01:06:47,936
I wish I could bring good news.

726
01:06:49,065 --> 01:06:52,311
The Network is not what it was.

727
01:06:52,524 --> 01:06:57,014
You said there is something
irretrievably vulgar about success.

728
01:06:57,522 --> 01:07:00,189
OWL must be a success.

729
01:07:00,314 --> 01:07:04,104
You wonder how some people plug in.

730
01:07:04,229 --> 01:07:07,438
A few days ago a man
in an Oberon mask asked me

731
01:07:07,563 --> 01:07:10,430
if I was his baby donkey.

732
01:07:11,605 --> 01:07:14,388
I felt a whiff of nostalgia.

733
01:07:14,685 --> 01:07:17,061
I remembered the time when

734
01:07:17,186 --> 01:07:19,895
you were all just weirdos
in Washington DC,

735
01:07:20,020 --> 01:07:22,436
and thought that secrecy

736
01:07:22,561 --> 01:07:26,809
in this overbugged world meant
entering the most open network,

737
01:07:26,934 --> 01:07:30,715
with passwords to discourage morons.

738
01:07:33,059 --> 01:07:35,518
But there's no discouraging morons.

739
01:07:35,643 --> 01:07:40,299
You were part Robin Hood,
part secret society,

740
01:07:41,683 --> 01:07:45,017
You were on raids for information,

741
01:07:45,142 --> 01:07:47,183
like leaving Sherwood for supplies.

742
01:07:47,308 --> 01:07:53,342
Then you retreated back
to your impenetrable lair.

743
01:07:55,807 --> 01:07:58,891
I have to go out too,

744
01:07:59,016 --> 01:08:04,056
to gather knowledge about Okinawa,

745
01:08:04,181 --> 01:08:10,048
and I feel like a hunted spy,
I'm afraid they're after me.

746
01:08:11,515 --> 01:08:14,050
And I wonder if it isn't true.

747
01:08:14,805 --> 01:08:18,472
Under those pussy-hound masks,

748
01:08:18,597 --> 01:08:23,221
I discern true enemies,

749
01:08:23,346 --> 01:08:28,418
people who want to know too much
or who already know too much.

750
01:08:32,179 --> 01:08:33,928
"Okinawa?

751
01:08:34,053 --> 01:08:41,672
Rings a bell. Wasn't there
a strategy game about that?

752
01:08:43,301 --> 01:08:48,801
Written by some peculiar guy?
Remind me his name..."

753
01:08:48,926 --> 01:08:51,924
Sure I'll give your name!

754
01:08:55,509 --> 01:08:59,468
Now, I don't mention Okinawa.

755
01:08:59,593 --> 01:09:05,091
I sidestep: the end of
the Pacific campaign,

756
01:09:05,717 --> 01:09:08,288
Ernie Pyle's death,

757
01:09:09,425 --> 01:09:12,299
as if Okinawa was a lethal word,

758
01:09:12,424 --> 01:09:17,414
an "open, Sesame". Only I don't know
waht it would open.

759
01:09:18,674 --> 01:09:22,536
How come he knew about the Game?

760
01:09:24,090 --> 01:09:26,544
To whom did you talk?

761
01:09:29,423 --> 01:09:32,172
How stiffing suddenly

762
01:09:32,839 --> 01:09:36,003
these unasked questions.

763
01:10:04,460 --> 01:10:07,752
I get time-ache like headaches.

764
01:10:07,877 --> 01:10:11,376
Here. It spins you inside.

765
01:10:11,501 --> 01:10:14,709
You want to excise it, to get out,

766
01:10:14,834 --> 01:10:17,793
and leave your head to its aches,

767
01:10:17,918 --> 01:10:20,535
you want to go for a stroll.

768
01:10:26,125 --> 01:10:28,583
Time should take care of itself,

769
01:10:28,708 --> 01:10:32,701
leave me to here and now,
talking to cats,

770
01:10:34,582 --> 01:10:38,446
feeling early spring sun on my skin.

771
01:10:39,790 --> 01:10:42,831
No way. Time drills into me.

772
01:10:42,956 --> 01:10:45,248
I suffer electric shocks,

773
01:10:45,373 --> 01:10:47,778
time neuralgia,

774
01:10:50,415 --> 01:10:53,447
the image of a silent house,

775
01:10:53,872 --> 01:10:57,119
a garden in snow, a rainy day,

776
01:10:59,121 --> 01:11:03,328
fondling a horse over a gate.

777
01:11:05,164 --> 01:11:09,735
It is in me but not mine,
a migraine of time,

778
01:11:12,036 --> 01:11:15,119
where time is just pointless pain,

779
01:11:15,244 --> 01:11:20,944
without sentiment or nostalgia,
the sting of time,

780
01:11:21,785 --> 01:11:25,032
the sting of an invisible insect

781
01:11:25,452 --> 01:11:27,940
you can do nothing about.

782
01:11:33,908 --> 01:11:36,776
I was in Vézelay for two days.

783
01:11:37,325 --> 01:11:41,242
I realised I'd forgotten the clue

784
01:11:41,367 --> 01:11:45,200
which distinguishes genuine capitals
from restored ones.

785
01:11:45,325 --> 01:11:49,103
Or vice-versa.

786
01:11:52,657 --> 01:11:58,025
I had the question, but
the answer was a blank.

787
01:12:02,698 --> 01:12:06,028
Could an angel scan my memory

788
01:12:07,030 --> 01:12:09,572
and find the clue

789
01:12:09,697 --> 01:12:14,899
which distinguishes
remembrance from oblivion?

790
01:12:17,738 --> 01:12:19,864
An angel, like in the Jewish legend

791
01:12:19,989 --> 01:12:23,071
you used to love so much:

792
01:12:23,196 --> 01:12:26,361
One second before birth,

793
01:12:26,486 --> 01:12:32,684
we know all about everything.
Plato used to say the same.

794
01:12:33,363 --> 01:12:38,902
But, one second later,
an angel gives us a pat

795
01:12:39,027 --> 01:12:45,603
and erases our memory, so man has
the honor of rediscovery,

796
01:12:46,775 --> 01:12:49,016
if he's up to it.

797
01:12:50,984 --> 01:12:53,234
Does another angel come later

798
01:12:53,359 --> 01:12:57,358
when, willy-nilly, we've gathered
our scraps of memory,

799
01:12:57,483 --> 01:13:03,065
like refugees, and erase
the lot pat by pat?

800
01:13:05,149 --> 01:13:08,691
If I forgot the clue to the capitals,

801
01:13:08,816 --> 01:13:13,189
so vivid last time I was there,

802
01:13:13,649 --> 01:13:18,389
what clues to you will I lose,
one by one?

803
01:13:21,148 --> 01:13:23,440
The Gershwin song we loved,

804
01:13:23,565 --> 01:13:26,134
sung by Sarah Vaughan...

805
01:13:27,355 --> 01:13:32,593
No, no they can't take that away
from me...

806
01:13:32,772 --> 01:13:37,807
The way you this, the way you that...

807
01:13:38,605 --> 01:13:42,385
They can't take that away.

808
01:13:43,939 --> 01:13:47,184
But, yes, angels can.

809
01:13:48,895 --> 01:13:52,307
They can take everything one day.

810
01:13:53,061 --> 01:13:55,763
Here's a piece Florence wrote.

811
01:13:56,434 --> 01:13:59,184
It's in her book of short stories,

812
01:13:59,309 --> 01:14:02,806
To Be Read in an Elevator...

813
01:14:04,726 --> 01:14:06,681
Cocoloco.

814
01:14:06,809 --> 01:14:10,309
It was on an endless tour
in South America

815
01:14:10,434 --> 01:14:15,589
that she bought Cocoloco,
the prettiest of parrots.

816
01:14:15,892 --> 01:14:19,558
Everyday, to exorcise awful shows,

817
01:14:19,683 --> 01:14:24,307
shabby theaters,
dangerous and dirty hotels,

818
01:14:24,432 --> 01:14:28,307
she devised an act with Cocoloco,

819
01:14:28,432 --> 01:14:32,766
which exhaustion and fever
helped her consider brilliant.

820
01:14:32,891 --> 01:14:35,640
Perhaps it was, after all.

821
01:14:35,765 --> 01:14:38,681
She gathered up scraps
of news from a Europe

822
01:14:38,806 --> 01:14:40,473
she loathed

823
01:14:40,598 --> 01:14:43,805
and now regarded as Paradise Lost.

824
01:14:43,930 --> 01:14:46,639
She concieved comic, poetic scenes,

825
01:14:46,764 --> 01:14:49,222
with political satire...

826
01:14:49,347 --> 01:14:53,263
Cocoloco was very good as Yeltsin...

827
01:14:53,388 --> 01:14:55,221
A zaniness reproduced before
startled Indians,

828
01:14:55,346 --> 01:14:58,471
startled but friendly.

829
01:14:58,596 --> 01:15:01,263
Each night took her closer to home.

830
01:15:01,388 --> 01:15:03,846
Closer, in her delirium,

831
01:15:03,971 --> 01:15:06,970
to a triumphal return, with her
and Cocoloco

832
01:15:07,095 --> 01:15:10,009
as kings of TV.

833
01:15:10,554 --> 01:15:12,928
Too exhausted to take notes,

834
01:15:13,053 --> 01:15:16,094
she rehearsed sketches in her head,

835
01:15:16,219 --> 01:15:18,384
with brilliant repartee...

836
01:15:18,509 --> 01:15:20,634
Yes, that was a blank,

837
01:15:20,759 --> 01:15:24,467
but it would come back, she knew.

838
01:15:24,592 --> 01:15:27,425
And Cocoloco on her hand

839
01:15:27,550 --> 01:15:30,509
would look so funny in close-up.

840
01:15:30,634 --> 01:15:33,842
Then Cocoloco died of parrott-disease,

841
01:15:33,967 --> 01:15:36,633
and, back in France,

842
01:15:36,758 --> 01:15:40,336
she realised she'd forgotten it all.

843
01:15:46,424 --> 01:15:49,835
You see, Cocoloco?

844
01:15:51,923 --> 01:15:56,829
We'd have been a great act.

845
01:16:02,547 --> 01:16:07,749
You would have spoken just after me.

846
01:16:09,672 --> 01:16:13,796
You would have said things.

847
01:16:13,921 --> 01:16:19,254
Things as fun as now.

848
01:16:19,379 --> 01:16:23,421
- Pretty Cocoloco.
- Pretty Cocoloco.

849
01:16:23,546 --> 01:16:26,545
We would have been a hit.

850
01:16:26,670 --> 01:16:29,045
We would have been a hit...

851
01:16:29,170 --> 01:16:31,408
You and me in America.

852
01:16:31,835 --> 01:16:33,420
You and me in America.

853
01:16:33,545 --> 01:16:38,958
- You're so sweet, Cocoloco.
- You're so sweet, Cocoloco.

854
01:16:40,417 --> 01:16:43,747
Do you forget stuff too?

855
01:16:44,708 --> 01:16:47,126
Do you ever forget things?

856
01:16:47,251 --> 01:16:51,249
- Do you ever...
- Does the little angel come to you?

857
01:16:51,374 --> 01:16:53,042
Does the little angel...?

858
01:16:53,167 --> 01:16:58,083
- And, with a pat, erase...
- And, with a pat, erase...

859
01:16:58,208 --> 01:17:02,780
- the memory of things?
- The memory of things?

860
01:17:04,291 --> 01:17:07,372
Do you too hover...

861
01:17:10,290 --> 01:17:13,406
between remembrance and oblivion?

862
01:17:14,415 --> 01:17:19,367
Between remembrance and oblivion...
Cocoloco, say something!

863
01:17:20,830 --> 01:17:22,951
Cocoloco.

864
01:17:24,539 --> 01:17:29,289
Cocoloco.

865
01:17:29,414 --> 01:17:33,821
Have you forgotten everything too?
Cocoloco!

866
01:17:35,413 --> 01:17:41,693
You too refuse to speak, Cocoloco?

867
01:17:43,578 --> 01:17:46,742
The angel has erased the lot.

868
01:17:48,785 --> 01:17:50,575
You too.

869
01:17:50,952 --> 01:17:53,157
Cocoloco!

870
01:17:53,994 --> 01:17:55,866
Cocoloco.

871
01:17:56,160 --> 01:17:58,066
All you remember is your name.

872
01:20:25,019 --> 01:20:28,061
This film hasn't been seen in 35 years.

873
01:20:28,186 --> 01:20:31,602
Demoralising, the army censors said.

874
01:20:31,727 --> 01:20:34,309
More moralising was John Wayne

875
01:20:34,434 --> 01:20:37,351
in The Sands of Iwo Jima,
that got shown in wartime

876
01:20:37,476 --> 01:20:39,518
with unexpected results.

877
01:20:39,643 --> 01:20:41,933
The Star turned up in cowboy garb
at a naval hospital,

878
01:20:42,058 --> 01:20:45,142
and got booed!

879
01:20:45,267 --> 01:20:47,975
An episode in a war of images

880
01:20:48,100 --> 01:20:50,808
that soon coincided with real war.

881
01:20:50,933 --> 01:20:53,890
It started here, at Iwo Jima,

882
01:20:54,015 --> 01:20:56,805
with that famous scene.

883
01:20:56,930 --> 01:20:58,580
Or with another scene, in Borneo.

884
01:21:00,640 --> 01:21:08,056
Each scene has its tale.

885
01:21:08,181 --> 01:21:10,931
I know where Gustave is from.

886
01:21:11,056 --> 01:21:13,472
You told me his name was Gustave.

887
01:21:13,597 --> 01:21:15,805
I'd seen him a hundred times.

888
01:21:15,930 --> 01:21:20,264
Nobody had ever filmed
a man burning alive so close,

889
01:21:20,389 --> 01:21:22,847
a lulu for war documentaries.

890
01:21:22,972 --> 01:21:28,679
The unknown soldier, in full kit,
holding his own flame.

891
01:21:28,804 --> 01:21:32,013
He was carted around battlefields,

892
01:21:32,138 --> 01:21:35,928
like a war-artist on tour
with a unique act.

893
01:21:36,053 --> 01:21:39,845
Gustave in the Philippines,
Gustave in Okinawa.

894
01:21:39,970 --> 01:21:43,052
I even saw him in a Vietnam movie,

895
01:21:43,177 --> 01:21:45,761
still burning 20 years later.

896
01:21:45,886 --> 01:21:50,094
I viewed so much newsreel
I knew Gustave at birth.

897
01:21:50,219 --> 01:21:53,009
Filmed in Borneo, by Australians.

898
01:21:53,134 --> 01:21:56,094
The interesting thing is that,
at the end of the original shot,

899
01:21:56,219 --> 01:22:00,633
you can tell he doesn't die.
He gets up again.

900
01:22:00,758 --> 01:22:05,133
You feel he'll get over it

901
01:22:05,258 --> 01:22:07,050
like the napalm girl in Saigon.

902
01:22:07,175 --> 01:22:08,799
That ending has always been cut

903
01:22:08,924 --> 01:22:11,132
in all documentaries.

904
01:22:11,257 --> 01:22:15,417
A born symbol doesn't get out
of it so easily!

905
01:22:15,632 --> 01:22:17,674
He testifies against war,

906
01:22:17,799 --> 01:22:20,091
you cannot weaken his testimony

907
01:22:20,216 --> 01:22:24,381
for the sake of a few frames.
Truth? What is truth?

908
01:22:24,506 --> 01:22:27,715
The truth is, most didn't get up.

909
01:22:27,840 --> 01:22:30,381
So what's so special about this one?

910
01:22:30,506 --> 01:22:33,755
The ethics of imagery?
Is napalm ethical?

911
01:22:33,880 --> 01:22:38,336
Are you in favour of napalm?
Whose side are you on, comrade?

912
01:22:40,797 --> 01:22:44,629
Private Ira Hayes knew his side.

913
01:22:44,754 --> 01:22:49,046
He was a US Marine,
brave and disciplined.

914
01:22:49,171 --> 01:22:52,753
He was told to pose, with five pals,

915
01:22:52,878 --> 01:22:58,586
to re-stage the picture. He
didn't waver. It was for the cause.

916
01:22:58,711 --> 01:23:01,669
Those who had put up the flag

917
01:23:01,794 --> 01:23:06,783
in combat, were gone.
They took six others.

918
01:23:07,336 --> 01:23:12,002
It wasn't much, just a set-up,

919
01:23:12,127 --> 01:23:14,584
there'd be more like it,

920
01:23:14,709 --> 01:23:18,834
the original was uninspiring anyway.

921
01:23:18,959 --> 01:23:21,625
Hayes never got over it.

922
01:23:21,874 --> 01:23:23,707
He wasn't to blame,

923
01:23:23,832 --> 01:23:25,999
he had fought with the best,

924
01:23:26,124 --> 01:23:30,124
but he'd been asked to lie.
Simple soul,

925
01:23:30,249 --> 01:23:32,874
he couldn't live with that lie.

926
01:23:32,999 --> 01:23:35,749
He couldn't tell the truth,

927
01:23:35,874 --> 01:23:39,830
the Corps honor was at stake,
so he took to drink,

928
01:23:39,955 --> 01:23:43,040
and died in poverty.

929
01:23:43,165 --> 01:23:46,581
The picture has become an icon.

930
01:23:46,706 --> 01:23:50,246
It was used in Sarajevo in 1994,

931
01:23:50,371 --> 01:23:53,820
but not to hail the US Marines.

932
01:23:56,914 --> 01:24:00,538
The Army would gladly have done
a replay in Okinawa,

933
01:24:00,663 --> 01:24:02,079
but Marine Corps Public Relations

934
01:24:02,204 --> 01:24:04,163
was unbeatable.

935
01:24:04,288 --> 01:24:07,954
And Okinawa wasn't that simple.

936
01:24:08,079 --> 01:24:12,203
Mabuni Museum shows war as chaotic

937
01:24:12,328 --> 01:24:15,445
and hard to represent,
and unpresentable.

938
01:24:16,245 --> 01:24:19,452
But - as in the books and films -

939
01:24:19,577 --> 01:24:21,952
the smell of battle is missing.

940
01:24:22,077 --> 01:24:26,160
Till we get smellies, like talkies,

941
01:24:26,285 --> 01:24:28,909
war films don't exist. Just as well,

942
01:24:29,034 --> 01:24:32,898
I swear there'd be no audience.

943
01:24:49,741 --> 01:24:53,491
I remember the fear

944
01:24:53,616 --> 01:24:58,156
and I have really
experienced the feeling

945
01:24:58,281 --> 01:25:01,656
of being a part of Japan at war.

946
01:25:01,781 --> 01:25:05,072
That is why I particularly feel,

947
01:25:05,197 --> 01:25:07,240
since my job is film-making,

948
01:25:07,365 --> 01:25:10,864
that Japanese war films are rubbish.

949
01:25:14,030 --> 01:25:15,947
They deal only with themselves,

950
01:25:16,072 --> 01:25:20,029
how they suffered from the war,
how brave and painful it was,

951
01:25:20,154 --> 01:25:23,105
They never show the other side.

952
01:25:23,696 --> 01:25:26,154
Once again, Oshima pointed the way.

953
01:25:26,279 --> 01:25:27,611
Laura went on to study

954
01:25:27,736 --> 01:25:31,070
how each side depicted the enemy.

955
01:25:31,195 --> 01:25:34,063
It was none too pleasant.

956
01:26:08,006 --> 01:26:09,965
We were taught that Westerners

957
01:26:10,090 --> 01:26:14,007
were demons. We were told
if US troops captured us

958
01:26:14,132 --> 01:26:18,380
they'd cut off our noses and ears,
cut off our fingers.

959
01:26:18,505 --> 01:26:24,215
They would drive tanks over our bodies,

960
01:26:24,340 --> 01:26:28,964
and rape our women.

961
01:26:29,089 --> 01:26:34,422
We would suffer horribly, then die.

962
01:26:34,547 --> 01:26:39,088
We were so imbued with all this

963
01:26:39,213 --> 01:26:43,754
that it seemed better

964
01:26:43,879 --> 01:26:48,711
to suppress our loved ones,

965
01:26:48,836 --> 01:26:52,378
than leave them to the enemy,

966
01:26:52,503 --> 01:26:56,920
For them, it would be a consolation

967
01:26:57,045 --> 01:27:01,127
to die by the hand of a loved one.

968
01:27:01,252 --> 01:27:05,919
Filled with this thought,
we lamented and, lamenting,

969
01:27:06,044 --> 01:27:13,118
interrupted our mother's life.

970
01:27:17,708 --> 01:27:22,116
That's where I recognised him: Kinjo.

971
01:27:23,916 --> 01:27:26,248
The boy from the Keramas.

972
01:27:26,373 --> 01:27:32,873
A village elder, a leader,

973
01:27:32,998 --> 01:27:37,331
was snapping off a tree-branch.

974
01:27:37,456 --> 01:27:40,872
I watched him,

975
01:27:40,997 --> 01:27:44,164
intrigued.

976
01:27:44,289 --> 01:27:47,414
Then, on his very hand,

977
01:27:47,539 --> 01:27:50,871
the stick beame a weapon.

978
01:27:50,996 --> 01:27:55,829
As if having a seizure,

979
01:27:55,954 --> 01:28:02,621
he began to beat the life out
of his wife and children,

980
01:28:02,746 --> 01:28:05,621
whom he loved,
using just this piece of wood.

981
01:28:05,746 --> 01:28:10,495
It was terribly shocking,

982
01:28:10,620 --> 01:28:15,035
but telepathically all of us thought

983
01:28:15,160 --> 01:28:18,202
this was the thing to do

984
01:28:18,327 --> 01:28:22,286
and others began to kill
the people they loved most.

985
01:28:22,411 --> 01:28:28,243
They began with children,
with the weak and the old,

986
01:28:28,368 --> 01:28:33,033
with those who lacked the strength
to take their own lives.

987
01:28:33,158 --> 01:28:40,243
So husbands killed wives,

988
01:28:40,368 --> 01:28:45,616
parents killed children,
brothers killed sisters.

989
01:28:45,741 --> 01:28:49,907
They killed them because
they loved them.

990
01:28:50,032 --> 01:28:55,739
Such was the tragedy
of those mass suicides.

991
01:28:55,864 --> 01:29:03,530
It was a real butchery,
and the waters of the river

992
01:29:03,655 --> 01:29:10,447
where they threw the bodies
indiscriminately

993
01:29:10,572 --> 01:29:17,148
became rivers of blood.

994
01:29:17,863 --> 01:29:23,403
As for my own family,

995
01:29:23,528 --> 01:29:29,820
my brother, who was
two years my senior,

996
01:29:29,945 --> 01:29:36,110
and I raised our hand
for the first time

997
01:29:36,235 --> 01:29:42,598
against the mother who had borne us.

998
01:29:43,444 --> 01:29:48,318
At 19, my brother

999
01:29:48,443 --> 01:29:55,568
could not help moaning.
He suffered so much.

1000
01:29:55,693 --> 01:30:02,019
My father went off to die.

1001
01:30:02,399 --> 01:30:08,315
We also killed our younger

1002
01:30:08,440 --> 01:30:10,808
brother and sister.

1003
01:30:13,356 --> 01:30:15,190
Afterwards, he sought
a glorious death in war

1004
01:30:15,315 --> 01:30:17,523
crossing enemy lines:

1005
01:30:17,648 --> 01:30:20,355
He was captured alongside soldiers

1006
01:30:20,480 --> 01:30:22,979
who had called capture dishonorable.

1007
01:30:23,104 --> 01:30:24,939
Mass suicides accompanied

1008
01:30:25,064 --> 01:30:26,397
the advance of US troops.

1009
01:30:26,522 --> 01:30:29,688
Together with Japanese executions

1010
01:30:29,813 --> 01:30:32,104
and casualities of war,

1011
01:30:32,229 --> 01:30:34,979
some 150.000 civilians died in Okinawa,

1012
01:30:35,104 --> 01:30:37,021
a third of the population.

1013
01:30:37,146 --> 01:30:38,688
No other group suffered so,

1014
01:30:38,813 --> 01:30:41,134
except in the Nazi camps.

1015
01:30:48,936 --> 01:30:51,727
Europeans, surviving this,

1016
01:30:51,852 --> 01:30:53,352
might have turned to Buddhism.

1017
01:30:53,477 --> 01:30:55,811
Kinjo found Christianity.

1018
01:30:55,936 --> 01:30:58,645
He became a minister.
He offers his memory

1019
01:30:58,770 --> 01:31:02,809
to help others decipher theirs.

1020
01:31:02,934 --> 01:31:06,143
He wants Japan to acknowledge
its war crimes,

1021
01:31:06,268 --> 01:31:07,934
and mass suicides taught

1022
01:31:08,059 --> 01:31:10,059
in school books,

1023
01:31:10,184 --> 01:31:13,393
not ignored, or called madness.

1024
01:31:13,518 --> 01:31:17,226
He wants what nations and men
are least capable of:

1025
01:31:17,351 --> 01:31:22,254
that memory be faced,
and forgiveness asked.

1026
01:31:31,305 --> 01:31:34,598
If you look in the Bible,

1027
01:31:34,723 --> 01:31:42,722
you'll see confessing your mistakes

1028
01:31:42,847 --> 01:31:45,639
and expressing repentance,

1029
01:31:45,764 --> 01:31:48,554
cleanses people of their past.

1030
01:31:48,679 --> 01:31:55,886
But Japanese mentality,
the way of thought,

1031
01:31:56,011 --> 01:32:03,220
considers that errors
committed in the past

1032
01:32:03,345 --> 01:32:11,345
remain errors forever.
They cannot be erased.

1033
01:32:16,428 --> 01:32:24,428
I decided that my mission must be

1034
01:32:25,384 --> 01:32:31,217
to proclaim the value of human life

1035
01:32:31,342 --> 01:32:38,091
to counter the notion,

1036
01:32:38,216 --> 01:32:42,216
the ideology of the past,

1037
01:32:42,341 --> 01:32:44,673
that held life in such contempt,

1038
01:32:44,798 --> 01:32:47,298
for such was the lie they taught.

1039
01:32:47,423 --> 01:32:50,923
That was the motivation

1040
01:32:51,048 --> 01:32:53,548
for my becoming a missionary,
a Christian minister.

1041
01:32:59,046 --> 01:33:01,671
After the retreat from Shuri,
General Buckner

1042
01:33:01,796 --> 01:33:05,422
sent Ushijima, in his Southern bastion,

1043
01:33:05,547 --> 01:33:09,088
an offer of honorable surrender.

1044
01:33:09,213 --> 01:33:13,917
The Japanese general reacted
with an outburst of laughter.

1045
01:33:14,296 --> 01:33:16,961
Was it laughter, borne on the wind,

1046
01:33:17,086 --> 01:33:20,086
that prompted a frontline gunner?

1047
01:33:20,211 --> 01:33:22,045
Unknowningly, he aimed at Buckner,

1048
01:33:22,170 --> 01:33:25,295
who was examining the ground,
and Simon Bolivar Buckner,

1049
01:33:25,420 --> 01:33:27,252
only US general

1050
01:33:27,377 --> 01:33:29,210
to die in combat,

1051
01:33:29,335 --> 01:33:31,794
failed to convince his enemies,

1052
01:33:31,919 --> 01:33:35,532
and died a few days before them.

1053
01:33:43,043 --> 01:33:47,042
It is said that Ushijima prayed
for Buchner when he died.

1054
01:33:47,167 --> 01:33:50,626
Then he and Cho arranged the ending,

1055
01:33:50,751 --> 01:33:53,749
the only end they could conceive.

1056
01:34:07,122 --> 01:34:11,165
He doesn't know how to harakiri.
You don't say.

1057
01:34:11,290 --> 01:34:16,414
Seppuku is not, in the European sense,

1058
01:34:16,539 --> 01:34:21,747
suicide, but the act
of giving oneself death.

1059
01:34:21,872 --> 01:34:28,413
The act of living through harshest pain
at the end.

1060
01:34:28,538 --> 01:34:31,328
That's what seppuku is.

1061
01:34:31,453 --> 01:34:34,411
So to perform seppuku,

1062
01:34:34,536 --> 01:34:38,953
you must be in good health,
very well-balanced,

1063
01:34:39,078 --> 01:34:43,120
with enough energy
to make a gift of death.

1064
01:34:43,245 --> 01:34:48,702
Pulling a trigger is not enough,
nor is swallowing pills,

1065
01:34:48,827 --> 01:34:52,285
nor stepping out into the void.

1066
01:34:52,410 --> 01:34:57,363
You must touch yourself to the end,

1067
01:34:58,035 --> 01:35:01,530
with living energy.

1068
01:35:15,991 --> 01:35:17,574
What of the piety

1069
01:35:17,699 --> 01:35:20,900
that surrounds
the tombs at Mabuni Hill?

1070
01:35:21,783 --> 01:35:24,198
Hard to believe these quiet people,

1071
01:35:24,323 --> 01:35:26,197
these quiet girls
born thirty years later,

1072
01:35:26,322 --> 01:35:28,614
are nostalgic for imperial times.

1073
01:35:28,739 --> 01:35:32,235
Does sacrifice erase everything?

1074
01:35:38,030 --> 01:35:40,322
When you say "it happened here",

1075
01:35:40,447 --> 01:35:48,154
something deep inside us resurfaces.

1076
01:35:48,279 --> 01:35:55,519
That is why many people come
spontaneously, join hands and pray.

1077
01:35:56,070 --> 01:36:01,486
Myself, knowing or learning
the nature of this place,

1078
01:36:01,611 --> 01:36:05,152
I'd offer incense and pray.

1079
01:36:05,277 --> 01:36:09,022
That's all I need to know.

1080
01:36:14,276 --> 01:36:16,734
One wonders what a Japanese general

1081
01:36:16,859 --> 01:36:20,776
has in mind when he offers
his life to the Emperor.

1082
01:36:20,901 --> 01:36:24,314
Thanks to Yahara, we know.

1083
01:36:25,400 --> 01:36:27,858
The last thing Cho tells him is:

1084
01:36:27,983 --> 01:36:29,650
"Remember the French film

1085
01:36:29,775 --> 01:36:32,191
we saw
in Saigon, in '41?"

1086
01:36:32,316 --> 01:36:34,774
It was Waves of the Danube,

1087
01:36:34,899 --> 01:36:37,442
with extras posing as gypsies.

1088
01:36:37,567 --> 01:36:41,148
And the music Cho heard
while disembowelling himself,

1089
01:36:41,273 --> 01:36:43,149
watching the horizon for the last time,

1090
01:36:43,274 --> 01:36:46,306
was Black Eyes.

1091
01:36:58,064 --> 01:37:00,183
Am I going mad?

1092
01:37:02,145 --> 01:37:04,979
I used to see you everywhere,

1093
01:37:05,104 --> 01:37:08,313
I recognised you from afar,

1094
01:37:08,438 --> 01:37:12,020
I went back to the places we loved,

1095
01:37:12,145 --> 01:37:13,603
the Jardin des Plantes,

1096
01:37:13,728 --> 01:37:15,561
the little farm
at the Bois de Boulogne,

1097
01:37:15,686 --> 01:37:19,977
the shore beneath the Golden Gate

1098
01:37:20,102 --> 01:37:24,102
where Kim Novak feigns suicide
in Vertigo...

1099
01:37:24,227 --> 01:37:28,227
I'd see a man from behind,
looking at parrots,

1100
01:37:28,352 --> 01:37:34,597
or sitting among goats,
or leaning against a rail,

1101
01:37:35,018 --> 01:37:37,055
and it would be you.

1102
01:37:38,434 --> 01:37:44,467
Then I'd come closer,
he'd turn round, be someone else.

1103
01:37:45,183 --> 01:37:48,601
I'd wonder how anyone

1104
01:37:48,726 --> 01:37:50,964
could replace you so fast.

1105
01:37:51,724 --> 01:37:56,926
In my moment of distraction,
not more than a split second...

1106
01:38:00,016 --> 01:38:02,598
Now it's the same in the Network.

1107
01:38:02,723 --> 01:38:06,140
Someone calls, it's you,

1108
01:38:06,265 --> 01:38:09,389
I know by tell-tale signs,

1109
01:38:09,514 --> 01:38:13,847
a special word only we would use.

1110
01:38:13,972 --> 01:38:17,800
Then I'd question him,
and he'd shy away,

1111
01:38:18,180 --> 01:38:23,050
not like you anymore.
Then another sign.

1112
01:38:27,138 --> 01:38:29,542
Is this a game?

1113
01:38:30,553 --> 01:38:33,255
Is it you teasing me?

1114
01:38:38,677 --> 01:38:41,710
One day, one woman knows too much,

1115
01:38:43,385 --> 01:38:48,835
too much about you, about me,
about the Game, about everything.

1116
01:38:50,719 --> 01:38:54,166
We are plugged into the masks gallery.

1117
01:38:54,801 --> 01:39:01,840
I ask her to show me hers
and on the screen I see this.

1118
01:39:54,720 --> 01:39:59,302
The end of the battle is written
in the deep, by Okinawa,

1119
01:39:59,427 --> 01:40:02,802
where Oshima, surveyor of memories,

1120
01:40:02,927 --> 01:40:05,885
filmed underwater graveyards.

1121
01:40:06,010 --> 01:40:08,718
Okinawa was the Japs' sute-ishi,

1122
01:40:08,843 --> 01:40:10,468
their sacrificial pawn.

1123
01:40:10,593 --> 01:40:14,218
If the price was high enough, the US

1124
01:40:14,343 --> 01:40:16,218
would shrink from invading

1125
01:40:16,343 --> 01:40:17,883
Japan's main island

1126
01:40:18,008 --> 01:40:19,883
and peace could be made.

1127
01:40:20,008 --> 01:40:22,633
The reality was, it made the case

1128
01:40:22,758 --> 01:40:25,342
for the Atom Bomb.

1129
01:40:25,467 --> 01:40:29,174
Without Okinawa's resistance,
Hiroshima would not have been,

1130
01:40:29,299 --> 01:40:32,257
and the century would've been different.

1131
01:40:32,382 --> 01:40:34,632
Which means that in all respects,

1132
01:40:34,757 --> 01:40:37,923
our lives were fashioned by events

1133
01:40:38,048 --> 01:40:39,256
that took place in that little island,
between the moment

1134
01:40:39,381 --> 01:40:40,715
when Kinjo killed his family,

1135
01:40:40,840 --> 01:40:44,917
and general Ushijima's self-death.

1136
01:40:54,797 --> 01:40:56,420
Now Laura saw

1137
01:40:56,545 --> 01:40:58,670
the Game couldn't change history.

1138
01:40:58,795 --> 01:41:01,586
It would repeat it, in a loop,

1139
01:41:01,711 --> 01:41:05,086
with respectably futile obstinacy.

1140
01:41:05,211 --> 01:41:07,545
Storing the past so as not to revive it

1141
01:41:07,670 --> 01:41:10,205
was sheer 20th Century.

1142
01:41:14,627 --> 01:41:18,377
She was detached now,
as if she'd come to a limit;

1143
01:41:18,502 --> 01:41:23,408
The Game was not hers anymore,
nor was History.

1144
01:41:25,376 --> 01:41:28,918
I knew she spoke with Masks at night.

1145
01:41:29,043 --> 01:41:30,751
I asked what she wanted, she responded:

1146
01:41:30,876 --> 01:41:33,501
Level Five, of course,
in a tone that made you think

1147
01:41:33,626 --> 01:41:38,042
she was cured, as if for her
the War was over.

1148
01:41:38,167 --> 01:41:40,739
Naturally, I was wrong.

1149
01:41:46,332 --> 01:41:50,874
Last night: fun dialog
with a mask.

1150
01:41:50,999 --> 01:41:53,790
A Harfang owl mask, so I listened.

1151
01:41:53,915 --> 01:41:56,915
Having some knowledge about Harfang,

1152
01:41:57,040 --> 01:41:59,528
in our days, shows some culture.

1153
01:42:00,998 --> 01:42:03,622
Disappointing, as usual.

1154
01:42:03,747 --> 01:42:05,748
When he went for a date

1155
01:42:05,873 --> 01:42:07,747
I really got him:

1156
01:42:07,872 --> 01:42:10,246
"Think of all the time we've saved

1157
01:42:10,371 --> 01:42:13,120
in just five minutes:

1158
01:42:13,245 --> 01:42:17,663
Six months of passion,
two years of jealousy,

1159
01:42:17,788 --> 01:42:23,652
four years' infidelity,
eight of misunderstandings,

1160
01:42:25,745 --> 01:42:28,203
reconciliation one spring,

1161
01:42:28,328 --> 01:42:32,078
one summer of fighting,
one autumn of breaking up,

1162
01:42:32,203 --> 01:42:36,035
one winter of dispair,
just work it out.

1163
01:42:36,160 --> 01:42:40,369
Bye and thanks for the time saved".

1164
01:42:40,494 --> 01:42:42,946
He found nothing to say.

1165
01:42:45,493 --> 01:42:50,944
And you?
Shall I thank you?

1166
01:42:55,783 --> 01:42:58,825
The list I gave him, so as to shine,

1167
01:42:58,950 --> 01:43:02,361
did time have it in store for us?

1168
01:43:09,532 --> 01:43:13,228
I see me, in ten years, without you,

1169
01:43:14,448 --> 01:43:19,152
reading in the paper you've died,

1170
01:43:20,282 --> 01:43:26,644
a feeling of something already seen,
already lost,

1171
01:43:30,697 --> 01:43:34,903
the faraway echo of something
I don't know,

1172
01:43:35,820 --> 01:43:39,944
your absence now
which I wouldn't have known,

1173
01:43:40,821 --> 01:43:44,399
but would have felt within me,

1174
01:43:45,028 --> 01:43:50,017
as if my programmer foresaw it all,

1175
01:43:50,611 --> 01:43:54,474
what happened, what
might have happened.

1176
01:43:58,526 --> 01:44:00,734
Like when you search for a word

1177
01:44:00,859 --> 01:44:03,810
that escapes you.

1178
01:44:05,276 --> 01:44:08,144
"I had it on the tip of my tongue".

1179
01:44:10,901 --> 01:44:15,806
I'd have your death
on the tip of my memory,

1180
01:44:19,901 --> 01:44:22,352
I'd have thought:

1181
01:44:22,941 --> 01:44:25,690
"There was a time when..."

1182
01:44:29,732 --> 01:44:33,566
But then there was another time,
the time of my list,

1183
01:44:33,691 --> 01:44:36,231
from jealousy to deceit,

1184
01:44:36,356 --> 01:44:39,935
and that time would mute our time,

1185
01:44:41,939 --> 01:44:45,684
mute the echo of our life.

1186
01:44:48,105 --> 01:44:52,845
Everything would have been
as though through a wall,

1187
01:44:54,811 --> 01:44:57,644
barely audible...

1188
01:44:58,103 --> 01:45:02,310
Like when rescuers search
through a wall of rubble,

1189
01:45:03,603 --> 01:45:06,471
they always come too late.

1190
01:45:10,894 --> 01:45:15,764
And you?
What would you have kept?

1191
01:45:18,934 --> 01:45:22,798
One day my image would begin to blur,

1192
01:45:24,601 --> 01:45:29,222
you'd realise the scraps of words,

1193
01:45:30,725 --> 01:45:33,100
scraps of life filling your memory,

1194
01:45:33,225 --> 01:45:39,386
were shifting out of focus.

1195
01:45:46,141 --> 01:45:49,303
Must I thank you too?

1196
01:45:55,015 --> 01:45:57,965
Thank you for this gift?

1197
01:46:02,180 --> 01:46:06,431
A life in which
there wasn't enough time

1198
01:46:06,556 --> 01:46:13,297
for something mediocre to slip in,
neither lies nor cruelty.

1199
01:46:14,346 --> 01:46:17,719
So swift that the ordinary gremlins,

1200
01:46:17,844 --> 01:46:20,720
that sneak into everyday life,

1201
01:46:20,845 --> 01:46:23,713
haven't had the chance to get to us.

1202
01:46:25,053 --> 01:46:30,042
They met a shut door:

1203
01:46:34,344 --> 01:46:36,748
"Closed for a death".

1204
01:46:36,926 --> 01:46:39,301
So annoying for them.

1205
01:46:39,426 --> 01:46:41,925
Nothing for them in the will.

1206
01:46:42,050 --> 01:46:45,176
A life, a body, untouched,

1207
01:46:45,301 --> 01:46:50,124
on which I never saw the first signs

1208
01:46:51,800 --> 01:46:54,004
of lovelessness,

1209
01:46:57,591 --> 01:46:59,960
abandon

1210
01:47:00,174 --> 01:47:02,627
or relinquishment.

1211
01:47:07,840 --> 01:47:13,341
A real fairy-tale, one of them
falls asleep

1212
01:47:13,466 --> 01:47:15,834
and never changes.

1213
01:47:16,505 --> 01:47:19,670
There's no greater gift.

1214
01:47:22,006 --> 01:47:24,246
Shall I thank you?

1215
01:47:26,504 --> 01:47:28,495
I thank you.

1216
01:47:29,336 --> 01:47:31,244
Thank you.

1217
01:47:31,670 --> 01:47:33,707
Thank you.

1218
01:47:42,920 --> 01:47:45,324
I never saw Laura again.

1219
01:47:45,585 --> 01:47:48,209
The workshop seemed unchanged,

1220
01:47:48,334 --> 01:47:49,794
the machines were on,

1221
01:47:49,919 --> 01:47:51,710
as if she had just stepped out.

1222
01:47:51,835 --> 01:47:55,833
Our loyal screensaver cat kept watch.

1223
01:47:55,958 --> 01:47:59,876
And the OWL mail page was open.

1224
01:48:00,001 --> 01:48:02,869
Without thinking, I typed in her name.

1225
01:48:09,500 --> 01:48:12,664
He didn't know that either.

Name: Fellinopolis
Subtitle Data:
1
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:07,000
Downloaded from
YTS.MX

2
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:13,000
Official YIFY movies site:
YTS.MX

3
00:00:34,480 --> 00:00:37,840
Under the patronage of

4
00:00:37,960 --> 00:00:41,160
in collaboration with

5
00:00:41,330 --> 00:00:45,880
This film was only made thanks to the work
of director Ferruccio Castronuovo

6
00:00:45,999 --> 00:00:50,775
on the sets of Fellini's "City of Women",
"The Ship Sails On" and "Ginger and Fred".

7
00:00:50,994 --> 00:00:54,840
These films, the "Specials",
were used to promote upcoming films.

8
00:00:55,080 --> 00:00:57,999
Now they've been restored,
after more than 40 years

9
00:00:58,360 --> 00:01:00,279
at the Cineteca Nazionale.

10
00:01:01,239 --> 00:01:03,919
To Ferruccio the greatest gratitude
for this unique tribute

11
00:01:04,080 --> 00:01:06,160
to be carefully preserved.

12
00:01:12,119 --> 00:01:14,319
Get down on your knees to see better.

13
00:01:14,479 --> 00:01:16,080
It's not amusing.

14
00:01:16,160 --> 00:01:19,039
Keep it that way,
we'll add something later.

15
00:01:19,119 --> 00:01:20,119
Go! Quick!

16
00:01:26,560 --> 00:01:30,039
All directors do the shot,
the reverse shot and wide shot,

17
00:01:30,120 --> 00:01:32,720
but with him, this is just the beginning.

18
00:01:38,760 --> 00:01:40,160
Take a seat, ma'am.

19
00:01:40,814 --> 00:01:41,920
How are you?

20
00:01:46,399 --> 00:01:47,800
Look at the camera.

21
00:01:53,240 --> 00:01:56,119
Rosina, who comes from Verrucchio,

22
00:01:56,280 --> 00:01:59,760
is the first one to come out of the heap!

23
00:02:01,560 --> 00:02:03,520
I’m a Bette Davis lookalike.

24
00:02:03,640 --> 00:02:05,560
I’m Lucio Dalla’s double.

25
00:02:08,440 --> 00:02:10,080
Wait! Stop everything!

26
00:02:10,679 --> 00:02:12,920
Slow down!

27
00:02:13,119 --> 00:02:18,720
We stay here, from morning till night,
trapped together. We create a world apart.

28
00:02:18,832 --> 00:02:20,240
It's a "Fellinopolis".

29
00:02:22,279 --> 00:02:23,999
Scene 33/5/5.

30
00:02:50,999 --> 00:02:55,320
Stage 5 in Cinecittà is the ideal place.
The utmost excitement.

31
00:02:55,600 --> 00:02:57,880
Thrilling, entrancing...

32
00:02:58,679 --> 00:03:01,480
That's what I feel
in front of the empty stage.

33
00:03:01,600 --> 00:03:05,680
A space to fill, a world to build.

34
00:03:17,880 --> 00:03:21,240
Please try to hold the positions
you have been given,

35
00:03:21,920 --> 00:03:23,706
Roll camera! Clear the scene!

36
00:03:25,480 --> 00:03:27,600
Too much smoke! Stop it!

37
00:03:28,959 --> 00:03:30,279
Roll camera.

38
00:03:31,080 --> 00:03:32,440
Action, Marcello!

39
00:03:36,360 --> 00:03:37,600
Move forward!

40
00:03:38,239 --> 00:03:40,279
Get out! Get out!

41
00:03:45,520 --> 00:03:48,520
Louder! Shout louder!

42
00:03:48,600 --> 00:03:52,439
Come forward! Come on! Come on!

43
00:03:52,999 --> 00:03:55,679
Go this way! This way! Go!

44
00:03:57,200 --> 00:03:59,119
Ferocious, ferocious!

45
00:04:02,880 --> 00:04:04,640
Stop! Thank you.

46
00:04:05,040 --> 00:04:08,480
Flora Mastroianni, Marcello's wife,

47
00:04:08,760 --> 00:04:12,559
was my friend since school.

48
00:04:13,040 --> 00:04:17,080
It was at her house that I met Fellini.

49
00:04:17,279 --> 00:04:19,400
Get down on your knees to see better.

50
00:04:20,279 --> 00:04:22,039
You recognize him, you scream.

51
00:04:22,120 --> 00:04:24,680
Stand up. Stand up!

52
00:04:34,120 --> 00:04:35,120
There he is!

53
00:04:35,121 --> 00:04:36,121
I first met Fellini on the set
of "Satyricon",

54
00:04:36,122 --> 00:04:37,122
on which I worked as the assistant
of Luigi Schiaccianoce.

55
00:04:37,123 --> 00:04:40,600
I met him in his kingdom, Cinecittà.

56
00:04:43,200 --> 00:04:46,960
I met Federico in 1963.

57
00:04:47,159 --> 00:04:49,200
I used to go RAI television

58
00:04:49,359 --> 00:04:52,799
and ask if there were any chances

59
00:04:52,959 --> 00:04:55,039
to have an internship.

60
00:04:55,200 --> 00:04:57,320
There I met Federico Fellini.

61
00:04:57,479 --> 00:05:00,959
"Excuse me, you make a lot of movies,

62
00:05:01,039 --> 00:05:06,279
may I have a chance to work with you?"

63
00:05:06,399 --> 00:05:07,919
After that meeting,

64
00:05:08,000 --> 00:05:11,760
I worked with him from 1963 to 1993.

65
00:05:11,839 --> 00:05:17,200
You all stand up and you come
just about where you are now.

66
00:05:17,279 --> 00:05:23,440
At one point in my life
I decided to start working in movies.

67
00:05:25,839 --> 00:05:27,800
I had a stroke of luck,

68
00:05:28,120 --> 00:05:30,120
because I met Maurizio Mein.

69
00:05:30,200 --> 00:05:33,760
Please try to hold the positions
you have been given.

70
00:05:33,839 --> 00:05:36,719
He was Fellini's assistant.

71
00:05:37,200 --> 00:05:42,080
I implored him: "Maurizio,
please introduce me to Fellini."

72
00:05:42,359 --> 00:05:45,920
On a Friday afternoon, I got a phone call.

73
00:05:47,520 --> 00:05:50,200
"Ferruccio, are you free
on Monday morning?"

74
00:05:50,279 --> 00:05:50,960
"Yes."

75
00:05:51,080 --> 00:05:54,640
"Then come to Cinecittà.
Fellini wants to meet you".

76
00:05:55,159 --> 00:05:57,640
"Fellini wants to meet me? Bugger off!"

77
00:05:57,839 --> 00:06:00,520
I thought a friend
was playing a joke on me.

78
00:06:00,599 --> 00:06:06,240
"No, I'm Norman,
the production manager of Casanova."

79
00:06:06,440 --> 00:06:09,120
"Casanova"?! Holy shit!

80
00:06:10,440 --> 00:06:13,280
I didn't sleep for two nights.

81
00:06:14,040 --> 00:06:17,440
One afternoon, which I will never forget,

82
00:06:17,640 --> 00:06:19,880
the phone rang and a voice said:

83
00:06:22,279 --> 00:06:27,200
"Good morning,
I am Fellini's assistant director.

84
00:06:27,279 --> 00:06:32,120
The Master would like
to meet you tomorrow morning

85
00:06:32,200 --> 00:06:35,520
in the offices of Stage 5
at Cinecittà film studios."

86
00:06:36,039 --> 00:06:37,599
I took it as a joke

87
00:06:37,680 --> 00:06:40,400
and I answered: "Sure, I'll be there."

88
00:06:42,479 --> 00:06:45,399
Then, luckily, I had some doubt
and the following morning

89
00:06:45,479 --> 00:06:49,080
I went to the offices
of Stage 5 in Cinecittà.

90
00:06:50,399 --> 00:06:54,120
We spoke in his office.

91
00:06:55,799 --> 00:06:59,000
From that day on,
with the exceptional unaffectedness

92
00:06:59,080 --> 00:07:03,320
that he was able
to infuse in any relationship,

93
00:07:04,447 --> 00:07:08,200
I worked with him, we spoke
on the phone, we exchanged views...

94
00:07:08,880 --> 00:07:10,920
nearly every day for 11 years.

95
00:07:34,320 --> 00:07:36,959
I worked in the costume
department laboratory.

96
00:07:36,959 --> 00:07:40,200
I dealt with aging, among other tasks.

97
00:07:40,279 --> 00:07:43,840
I supervised the seamstresses,
the making of stage costumes.

98
00:07:45,959 --> 00:07:51,680
I was Gabriella Pescucci's assistant
for "City of Women".

99
00:07:56,919 --> 00:07:59,080
Bark. You have to bark.

100
00:08:01,599 --> 00:08:04,479
What if we do it yellow
instead of this color?

101
00:08:04,760 --> 00:08:06,000
Golden?

102
00:08:18,200 --> 00:08:23,080
There was a lot to do, we had to create
the feminists' costumes...

103
00:08:23,159 --> 00:08:26,039
We had to invent quite a bit.

104
00:08:39,577 --> 00:08:42,296
Try playing, turn towards me. That's it!

105
00:08:43,079 --> 00:08:44,840
The other way.

106
00:08:44,919 --> 00:08:47,360
Good, that's it. All the way!

107
00:08:48,120 --> 00:08:49,800
Play like this.

108
00:09:01,439 --> 00:09:07,319
Later on, as a set manager,
I was almost always there, at his side.

109
00:09:07,399 --> 00:09:09,920
We got on instantly.

110
00:09:21,319 --> 00:09:24,800
Take a seat, I'll set you up later.

111
00:09:26,640 --> 00:09:27,960
All right. Then?

112
00:09:28,279 --> 00:09:30,600
Thank you.
We'll see you later. Goodbye.

113
00:09:50,600 --> 00:09:53,720
I wanted to tell
the whole story, the work,

114
00:09:53,799 --> 00:09:55,800
the set of Fellini's films.

115
00:10:01,919 --> 00:10:04,120
Lower the trunk!

116
00:10:08,919 --> 00:10:13,360
I started to look for the best
framing I could imagine.

117
00:10:13,439 --> 00:10:15,560
Raise the trunks!

118
00:10:24,079 --> 00:10:26,199
Pull up the trunks!

119
00:10:26,399 --> 00:10:28,760
That's it!
Roll camera, let's go!

120
00:10:29,679 --> 00:10:31,240
Scene 33/3/1.

121
00:10:31,880 --> 00:10:33,640
Don't move!

122
00:10:33,960 --> 00:10:37,720
The challenge of portraying
the story of "City of Women"

123
00:10:39,240 --> 00:10:43,159
didn't prove easy, also
because I didn't know the script.

124
00:10:43,319 --> 00:10:46,480
I didn't know what exactly
Fellini wanted to tell.

125
00:10:46,679 --> 00:10:48,559
The more money, the more rounds!

126
00:10:48,640 --> 00:10:52,160
Inside this shack, you can watch
the most dangerous exercises...

127
00:10:55,079 --> 00:10:57,120
I chose to tell the film

128
00:10:57,279 --> 00:11:02,319
in a much more explicit way

129
00:11:02,422 --> 00:11:05,200
than just doing interviews here and there.

130
00:11:06,640 --> 00:11:10,039
In fact, there's no narrator.

131
00:11:10,520 --> 00:11:11,960
It's all direct sound.

132
00:11:15,199 --> 00:11:17,000
Later we plug them in here.

133
00:11:17,960 --> 00:11:20,600
Bring the pulley back here!

134
00:11:29,439 --> 00:11:31,399
The fateful Saturday comes along,

135
00:11:31,679 --> 00:11:34,279
and Fellini wants
to see the material I shot.

136
00:11:34,760 --> 00:11:40,159
Gianni, I'll arrange the bulbs
to be put here on the sides.

137
00:11:40,240 --> 00:11:43,120
I saw Fellini controlling everything.

138
00:11:43,199 --> 00:11:47,360
He tore up all the photos:
"This is bad... this is bad".

139
00:11:47,600 --> 00:11:49,000
I was shaking.

140
00:11:49,199 --> 00:11:50,520
Fellini's examination,

141
00:11:50,600 --> 00:11:53,679
when check what you shot
at the editing table

142
00:11:54,159 --> 00:11:55,600
is a terrible moment!

143
00:11:55,840 --> 00:11:57,640
He came in and watched.

144
00:12:05,799 --> 00:12:08,439
Every now and then
he turned and looked at me.

145
00:12:09,199 --> 00:12:11,480
I would smile, shyly.

146
00:12:17,559 --> 00:12:19,279
He would restart the Moviola.

147
00:12:19,919 --> 00:12:22,440
Then he'd stop and say:
"Where were you here?"

148
00:12:23,480 --> 00:12:25,439
Take 2-6

149
00:12:25,960 --> 00:12:29,279
Then we saw what was going on
in front of Fellini.

150
00:12:29,640 --> 00:12:31,799
Attention, please! We are ready!

151
00:12:33,159 --> 00:12:34,840
Don't move!

152
