Look, I won't say anything.

1062
01:19:40,083 --> 01:19:44,625
I'm Italian, and sometimes it's best
to have the courage to be a coward.

1063
01:19:45,916 --> 01:19:48,458
When the wave passes, you lower your head

1064

and when you stand up,
you're a little dirty.

1065

Stay if you want. Me, ciao.

1066
01:20:20,833 --> 01:20:26,291
- It won't do you any good. I won't tell!
- I know, Brunolli.

1067

Do you have a VCR somewhere?

1068
01:20:32,250 --> 01:20:33,583
- Yes, in archives.
- Thank you.

1069
01:20:43,166 --> 01:20:45,958
- Hey, Morot. Where's the VCR?
- Evening.

1070
01:20:46,041 --> 01:20:48,375
- It's over there in the back. Why?
- I'd like to see it.

1071
01:20:48,458 --> 01:20:50,500
- Do you know how to use it?
- No, I don't.

1072
01:20:50,583 --> 01:20:51,791
- Is it urgent?
- Yeah.

1073
01:20:56,500 --> 01:20:57,791
That's it.

1074
01:20:57,875 --> 01:20:59,875
�declare in their turn that
on pain of death�

1075
01:20:59,958 --> 01:21:01,583
Go back upstairs.

1076
01:21:14,791 --> 01:21:17,125
Stop. Rewind.

1077
01:21:25,416 --> 01:21:29,416
- That's what we saw last night.
- Yes, this is the original. Fast-forward.

1078
01:21:32,333 --> 01:21:35,000
Stop, stop, stop. Go back.

1079
01:21:38,083 --> 01:21:40,708
Stop.

1080
01:21:41,416 --> 01:21:43,750
- Do you see the newspaper?
- Yeah.

1081

- What's on the paper?
- Well, a car.

1082
01:21:46,541 --> 01:21:49,791
Yes, a Renault GT Turbo.

1083
01:21:49,875 --> 01:21:53,833
- They presented it to the press a week go.
- So?

1084
01:21:53,916 --> 01:21:57,333
So, it's a great car, Morot!
Give me the tape.

1085
01:21:57,416 --> 01:21:59,083
- You're welcome.
- Thank you very much.

1086
01:21:59,166 --> 01:22:03,458
- Rock-solid proof.
- Shut the door.

1087

No, I'm fine, thank you, I'll shave.

1088

The proof
that her document is eight days old.

1089

- That's interesting.
- Here.

1090
01:22:10,833 --> 01:22:12,083
Come in!

1091

Give me five minutes in peace!

1092
01:22:15,125 --> 01:22:17,041
You asked me for a bio

1093

- I didn't ask for anything!
- No, I did.

1094
01:22:19,125 --> 01:22:21,625
Listen Yves, it's not urgent,
we'll see about it tomorrow.

1095
01:22:22,375 --> 01:22:24,541
- Michel Barrer's photos.
- What the hell is going on?

1096
01:22:24,625 --> 01:22:27,333
- What the hell?
- It's my fault.

1097
01:22:27,416 --> 01:22:29,750
But it's urgent. You'll have
Catherine dragged through

1098
01:22:29,833 --> 01:22:32,916
- the mud by that imbecile Barbara.
- No, we're not cutting it.

1099
01:22:33,000 --> 01:22:35,708
What? Why?

1100

- The info, but with no editorial.
- Let me do the editorial!

1101

No Yves, not tonight!
I need more time to think it over.

1102

The paper's ready,

1103

We go to press at 10.
This job is impossible now.

1104
01:22:49,666 --> 01:22:51,958
At least look at this and listen to me!

1105

- Yves, there's no rush!
- Yes, there is!

1106

- Yes, sir?
- Tell my wife I'll meet her there.

1107

What do you have in there?

1108

Proof that the meeting between
the Prime Minister and Djavaoui took place

1109
01:23:10,500 --> 01:23:13,500
eight days ago, not two years ago,
like they want us to believe!

1110

Interesting. Was this just you?

1111
01:23:16,083 --> 01:23:18,916
- For now, yes.
- Keep it fresh, and we'll see tomorrow.

1112
01:23:20,333 --> 01:23:22,750
You can't keep this fresh.

1113
01:23:23,625 --> 01:23:26,666
So we lured Djavaoui to France
and betrayed him. Is that it?

1114
01:23:26,750 --> 01:23:29,875
Let's say we neglected, in quotes,

1115
01:23:29,958 --> 01:23:32,291
to ensure his safety. Here you go.

1116
01:23:33,416 --> 01:23:37,375
- The mistake was to deny the meeting.
- It's always their first instinct.

1117
01:23:38,750 --> 01:23:43,000
Come in early tomorrow
and we'll see how we can handle this.

1118
01:23:43,083 --> 01:23:45,375
But Djavaoui, no one cares.

1119
01:23:45,458 --> 01:23:49,750
On the other hand, Catherine
against the Prime Minister is funny.

1120
01:23:58,916 --> 01:24:01,833
Hey, Yves.
I thought it was over, you and Catherine.

1121
01:24:01,916 --> 01:24:04,583
Let's just say that for once

1122
01:24:05,625 --> 01:24:08,875
Get an interview with Catherine.
Exclusive.

1123
01:24:13,250 --> 01:24:17,625
Catherine? Yes. Good news.

1124
01:24:17,708 --> 01:24:20,375
No, not exactly.

1125

Yes. I'll explain. I'm leaving right away.

1126
01:24:42,458 --> 01:24:44,333
- Bravo!
- Yes!

1127

Who says so?

1128
01:24:51,000 --> 01:24:53,375
- So you're feeling better?
- Yes, much better.

1129
01:24:53,458 --> 01:24:55,041
This will warm your hands up.

1130

- Sorry, it's a little noisy tonight.
- It's okay. Give us the same thing.

1131
01:24:58,541 --> 01:25:00,041
- Be nice.
- Yes.

1132
01:25:00,125 --> 01:25:04,166
But we're gonna have fun, we'll fight.
We're gonna fight together!

1133
01:25:04,250 --> 01:25:08,041
- We'll fight against whom?
- Not against, for!

1134
01:25:08,833 --> 01:25:11,583
So that these little politicians
stop saying

1135
01:25:11,666 --> 01:25:13,625
whatever they want with impunity.

1136
01:25:14,958 --> 01:25:18,125
So that your TV friends won't live
with their heads in a noose anymore!

1137
01:25:29,083 --> 01:25:31,041
- Here you are.
- Thank you.

1138
01:25:31,875 --> 01:25:32,750
- Here.
- To honor.

1139
01:25:32,833 --> 01:25:34,541
The lost honor of Catherine Carr�.

1140
01:25:36,000 --> 01:25:37,416
You're going to get it back.

1141
01:25:38,416 --> 01:25:40,541
As poor Mar�che used to say.

1142
01:25:41,333 --> 01:25:44,750
Yes. But� Are you sure about Villechaise?

1143
01:25:46,000 --> 01:25:47,875
Ah, for a case like this, absolutely, yes.

1144
01:25:47,958 --> 01:25:50,500
As long as he has readers,
he will be a free man.

1145
01:25:50,583 --> 01:25:53,208
And since we have readers, knock on wood.

1146
01:25:53,875 --> 01:25:55,916
- You're going to go for it.
- There are two methods.

1147
01:25:56,000 --> 01:25:59,000
The photo with the headline.

1148
01:25:59,625 --> 01:26:03,291
- Shock treatment.
- Or we go slower, 10 lines,

1149
01:26:03,375 --> 01:26:06,291
"Catherine Carr�
alleges she has proof," etc.

1150
01:26:06,375 --> 01:26:10,000
"When questioned,
she refused to deny or confirm�"

1151
01:26:10,583 --> 01:26:12,458
That's the drip-drip method.

1152
01:26:12,541 --> 01:26:15,083
We'll see tomorrow with Villechaise,
won't we? It'll be fun.

1153
01:26:15,166 --> 01:26:19,625
A national hero, Ms. Carr�
pushes the Prime Minister to his limit!

1154
01:26:21,500 --> 01:26:24,750
- He'll never forgive me.
- Nor will his spokesperson.

1155
01:26:25,708 --> 01:26:29,333
- No network will hire me after this.
- No one anywhere.

1156
01:26:30,291 --> 01:26:34,500
And in six months�
Everyone will have forgotten me.

1157
01:26:38,583 --> 01:26:39,666
Not me.

1158
01:26:41,083 --> 01:26:42,291
Not me.

1159
01:26:45,875 --> 01:26:49,208
You are beautiful. I like you.

1160
01:26:51,333 --> 01:26:52,166
I am happy.

1161
01:26:52,250 --> 01:26:56,000
Tango, Jeannot! Tango, Jeannot!

1162
01:26:56,083 --> 01:26:57,916
Yeah!

1163
01:26:58,000 --> 01:26:59,250
Come on, let's work a little?

1164
01:27:01,541 --> 01:27:02,833
Mr. Dorget! Telephone.

1165
01:27:03,500 --> 01:27:04,791
Excuse me.

1166
01:27:19,416 --> 01:27:22,250
- Can you turn on the lights?
- Right away.

1167
01:27:22,333 --> 01:27:23,708
Go ahead, Jeannot!

1168
01:27:23,791 --> 01:27:26,708
Take the cabin on the other side.
Hold on, sir. Please hold on.

1169
01:27:26,791 --> 01:27:29,291
- Isn't that Catherine Carr�, over there?
- Yes, it is.

1170
01:27:29,375 --> 01:27:31,166
- Hello, Yves?
- Yes, I'm here, listening.

1171
01:27:31,250 --> 01:27:33,250
What are you doing in Honfleur?

1172

Well, I have something to ask you,
something annoying.

1173
01:27:38,416 --> 01:27:40,708
- Something bad has happened.
- What's happened?

1174
01:27:40,791 --> 01:27:43,583
I need someone to cover Amman.
How well do you know the Middle East?

1175
01:27:43,666 --> 01:27:47,875
You scared me. I thought you didn't want
the Catherine interview anymore.

1176
01:27:47,958 --> 01:27:49,583
Sorry, go ahead.

1177
01:27:49,666 --> 01:27:52,833
- Yves, have you been drinking or what?
- I haven't been drinking.

1178
01:27:52,916 --> 01:27:54,000
You have to go to Jordan.

1179
01:28:12,166 --> 01:28:14,041
Are you Catherine Carr�?

1180
01:28:15,041 --> 01:28:16,750
- Yes.
- Yes?

1181
01:28:16,833 --> 01:28:18,333
Please�

1182
01:28:20,041 --> 01:28:22,875
Things are cracking down in Amman.
I need you to cover it.

1183
01:28:22,958 --> 01:28:25,208
- When do I leave?
- Tomorrow.

1184
01:28:25,291 --> 01:28:28,875
There's a flight at 2 pm.
I'll get you an open ticket, either way.

1185
01:28:28,958 --> 01:28:30,791
- Tomorrow? I can't.
- Why?

1186
01:28:30,875 --> 01:28:33,083
Because I'm not going
to leave Catherine right now.

1187
01:28:33,166 --> 01:28:36,250
Look, Catherine can wait!
It's not that urgent.

1188
01:28:39,166 --> 01:28:41,500
- Thank you.
- You're welcome.

1189
01:28:42,958 --> 01:28:44,250
Thank you.

1190
01:28:46,125 --> 01:28:48,083
All of them?

1191
01:28:49,000 --> 01:28:50,791
For Charlotte.

1192
01:28:50,875 --> 01:28:54,166
- No, try someone else.
- I am trying, but there's no one.

1193
01:28:54,958 --> 01:28:56,958
You're such a pain in the ass.

1194
01:28:58,208 --> 01:29:00,375
But I don't care about Jordan.

1195
01:29:00,458 --> 01:29:03,958
Nobody cares about Jordan, by the way!

1196
01:29:05,375 --> 01:29:07,916
I'm bringing Catherine's interview

1197
01:29:08,791 --> 01:29:10,666
Just wait and see.

1198

No, it's going to make a lot of noise,
you'll see.

1199
01:29:16,000 --> 01:29:18,416
I won't see anything!
Because tomorrow you're on a plane.

1200
01:29:18,500 --> 01:29:21,416
No! No, I won't go.

1201
01:29:27,875 --> 01:29:31,250
That bastard Villechaise
wants to send me to Jordan.

1202
01:29:31,333 --> 01:29:34,000
Go ahead.
What's happening there is interesting.

1203
01:29:34,083 --> 01:29:36,333
No, I'm interested in
what's going on here.

1204
01:29:36,416 --> 01:29:38,541
Come on. First question.

1205
01:29:38,625 --> 01:29:43,333
Catherine Carr�,
did you apologize to the minister?

1206
01:29:43,916 --> 01:29:46,000
- No.
- No.

1207
01:29:46,625 --> 01:29:50,375
Do you plan to apologize publicly
when you go back on the air?

1208
01:29:50,875 --> 01:29:53,916
I will not apologize for making a mistake
that I did not make.

1209
01:29:55,583 --> 01:29:57,666
In your job, it is a mistake

1210
01:29:57,750 --> 01:30:00,125
to get a member of the government
in hot water, right?

1211
01:30:01,500 --> 01:30:04,291
He got himself into trouble
by denouncing an untruth

1212
01:30:04,375 --> 01:30:05,833
and I only rectified it.

1213
01:30:08,375 --> 01:30:11,666
You know that if you maintain
your version of events,

1214
01:30:13,583 --> 01:30:15,916
you will be fired from the newspaper?

1215
01:30:17,541 --> 01:30:19,833
- I've already taken that risk.
- Yes, that's good.

1216
01:30:20,416 --> 01:30:22,375
You have to be specific about it.

1217
01:30:23,500 --> 01:30:26,125
You're going to make a splash.
Resign, maybe.

1218
01:30:26,208 --> 01:30:28,416
No. I won't quit.

1219
01:30:29,166 --> 01:30:32,458
Anyway, you will be replaced
by someone more docile.

1220
01:30:33,000 --> 01:30:35,791
No, not "docile".
Don't write "docile". We're not docile.

1221
01:30:35,875 --> 01:30:38,958
Understanding. Is "understanding" okay?

1222
01:30:39,041 --> 01:30:41,666
It's up to each person to judge
how to do this kind of job.

1223
01:30:42,666 --> 01:30:44,000
Yes.

1224
01:30:45,166 --> 01:30:47,041
One of our colleagues said to me:

1225
01:30:47,833 --> 01:30:50,583
"Sometimes you have to have the courage
to be a coward."

1226
01:30:50,666 --> 01:30:53,375
"You lower your head, the wave passes,

1227
01:30:53,458 --> 01:30:55,916
and when you get up,
you're a little dirty, and that's it."

1228
01:30:56,458 --> 01:30:58,875
- Who told you that?
- It doesn't matter.

1229
01:30:59,958 --> 01:31:01,833
So what do you say to that?

1230
01:31:01,916 --> 01:31:05,916
- You need something snappy.
- "The courage to be a coward�"

1231
01:31:09,625 --> 01:31:11,541
I should have had that.

1232
01:31:12,375 --> 01:31:14,166
That's not going to work at all.

1233
01:31:15,666 --> 01:31:16,666
What's wrong with it?

1234
01:31:17,583 --> 01:31:19,750
Well, because it sound like
you regret what you did!

1235
01:31:21,125 --> 01:31:23,833
Yes, but I do regret it,
what do you think?

1236
01:31:23,916 --> 01:31:27,500
That I should congratulate myself?
It's the biggest mistake of my life.

1237
01:31:28,125 --> 01:31:32,125
I had everything.
Everything that makes me happy.

1238
01:31:32,708 --> 01:31:36,166
And to� I don't know, to impress you, to�

1239
01:31:36,875 --> 01:31:38,666
Playing the vestal virgin of the news,

1240
01:31:38,750 --> 01:31:41,875
to the hardcore journalist,
to be harder and purer than you,

1241
01:31:41,958 --> 01:31:44,833
I just screwed everything up.

1242
01:31:47,291 --> 01:31:50,333
Yes. I regret it, yes.

1243
01:31:53,166 --> 01:31:54,458
No, that's not true.

1244
01:31:56,250 --> 01:31:57,708
You want my truth, right?

1245
01:31:59,750 --> 01:32:03,166
Well, that's the truth.

1246
01:32:05,833 --> 01:32:07,208
Catherine!

1247
01:32:22,791 --> 01:32:25,125
If I could fix it everything, I would.

1248
01:32:28,416 --> 01:32:29,583
I'd get on hands and knees.

1249
01:32:31,375 --> 01:32:35,250
- You would?
- Yes.

1250
01:32:35,750 --> 01:32:40,166
Don't give me a lesson in virtue,
I'm not willing to hear it.

1251
01:32:43,125 --> 01:32:44,833
I am unhappy, Yves.

1252
01:32:47,833 --> 01:32:49,291
I am unhappy.

1253
01:33:12,208 --> 01:33:16,041
Here. With this,

1254
01:33:17,416 --> 01:33:19,458
you've got the minister
by the short hairs.

1255
01:33:21,041 --> 01:33:22,416
If you want to negotiate.

1256
01:33:25,166 --> 01:33:28,750
Tell him you'll give up the tape
as long as you get your job back.

1257
01:33:29,916 --> 01:33:32,833
You can even ask for a raise
while you're at it.

1258
01:33:36,000 --> 01:33:37,625
That's called blackmail.

1259
01:33:39,958 --> 01:33:41,791
It's tried and true.

1260
01:34:00,041 --> 01:34:01,750
Yves, come on.

1261
01:34:03,791 --> 01:34:05,875
If you leave now, Catherine,
we will never see each other again.

1262
01:34:06,458 --> 01:34:07,791
We will.

1263
01:34:09,083 --> 01:34:09,958
No.

1264
01:34:11,416 --> 01:34:12,375
Never.

1265
01:35:23,750 --> 01:35:25,458
Can you give me a ride?

1266
01:35:26,583 --> 01:35:28,208
- Where are you going?
- To Jordan.

1267
01:35:28,291 --> 01:35:30,750
- I'm not headed that way.
- To Paris. Is that okay?

1268
01:35:30,833 --> 01:35:31,708
Get in.

1269
01:35:41,041 --> 01:35:44,083
- The news? Are you interested?
- Yes.

1270
01:35:45,750 --> 01:35:50,458
In Brussels, the representatives
of Nuremberg have not yet agreed�

1271
01:35:52,583 --> 01:35:55,750
Another terrorist attack in Beirut,
a bomb explodes in the city center�

1272
01:35:55,833 --> 01:35:57,625
I hope it's calmer in Jordan.

1273
01:35:59,208 --> 01:36:03,666
In a statement, Matignon said
that the Catherine Carr� case is closed.

1274
01:36:03,750 --> 01:36:07,333
The management of the channel
confirms that the popular journalist

1275
01:36:07,416 --> 01:36:12,000
will tell on air tonight
how she was victim of an impostor.

1276
01:36:12,083 --> 01:36:14,250
What does that mean, an impostor?

1277
01:36:15,083 --> 01:36:18,916
An impostor is a man who tries
to pass himself off as something he isn't.

1278
01:36:20,041 --> 01:36:23,291
A man� or a woman.

1279
01:36:26,250 --> 01:36:29,083
I hope you enjoy your evening with us,

1280
01:36:29,166 --> 01:36:31,416
at 8 pm, the news, Catherine Carr�.

1281
01:36:43,125 --> 01:36:44,583
Good evening.

1282
01:36:45,375 --> 01:36:47,666
Good evening.

1283
01:36:47,750 --> 01:36:51,416
Qualifiers began this morning�

1284
01:36:51,500 --> 01:36:55,083
The afternoon news�

1285
01:39:13,291 --> 01:39:15,833
Subtitle translation by: Adam Lozier

Name: The History of Metal and Horror
Subtitle Data:
1
00:04:15,429 --> 00:04:18,083
Hello and welcome

2
00:04:18,258 --> 00:04:21,173
to the history of gardening.
In this video,

3
00:04:21,348 --> 00:04:23,268
I will show you how to build
a garden of your own

4
00:04:23,350 --> 00:04:25,787
by using techniques
from thousands of years ago.

5
00:04:26,614 --> 00:04:27,702
Let us begin.

6
00:04:28,180 --> 00:04:29,660
In 10,000 BC...

7
00:04:39,322 --> 00:04:41,411
Attention, Private.

8
00:04:41,585 --> 00:04:44,022
You're about to learn
the history of the US Military,

9
00:04:44,196 --> 00:04:47,809
the meanest, the baddest, the most
powerful military the world has ever seen.

10
00:04:47,983 --> 00:04:49,419
Time to untuck your manhood.

11
00:04:49,593 --> 00:04:51,203
Listen up,
you miserable son of a...

12
00:05:07,263 --> 00:05:11,398
Welcome to the history
of proctology.

13
00:06:13,503 --> 00:06:17,377
What is the history
of metal and horror?

14
00:06:18,203 --> 00:06:19,596
Let's find out.

15
00:06:35,395 --> 00:06:39,224
Throughout this film,
we will examine the origins

16
00:06:39,399 --> 00:06:42,053
of both heavy metal and horror,

17
00:06:42,750 --> 00:06:46,406
and how the two ultimately
became intertwined.

18
00:06:47,058 --> 00:06:50,192
Have you ever noticed
how fans of metal,

19
00:06:50,366 --> 00:06:51,672
more often than not,

20
00:06:52,194 --> 00:06:55,066
are also fans of horror,
and vice versa.

21
00:06:55,632 --> 00:06:57,504
With the help of some friends,

22
00:06:57,678 --> 00:07:00,507
we will dig deep
into these genres

23
00:07:00,681 --> 00:07:03,597
and uncover their roots
and evolution.

24
00:07:04,162 --> 00:07:06,600
In order to understand
how this all began,

25
00:07:06,774 --> 00:07:09,254
let us step into the darkness

26
00:07:09,429 --> 00:07:13,345
and explore
the history of horror.

27
00:07:14,782 --> 00:07:16,871
All cultures value storytelling.

28
00:07:17,045 --> 00:07:18,394
Storytelling is one of our,

29
00:07:18,568 --> 00:07:20,614
our major impulses
as human beings.

30
00:07:20,788 --> 00:07:22,920
There are also the dark side,
the tales,

31
00:07:23,094 --> 00:07:24,792
the warnings
that we need to share,

32
00:07:24,966 --> 00:07:26,446
the verboten,
"We must not go there."

33
00:07:26,620 --> 00:07:29,057
Even in the pictographs,

34
00:07:29,231 --> 00:07:32,626
as far back as we could go,
were horror stories.

35
00:07:32,800 --> 00:07:35,324
As long as
there has been storytelling,

36
00:07:35,498 --> 00:07:40,111
people have used monsters to
explain things they don't understand

37
00:07:40,285 --> 00:07:43,245
and to express things they
don't know how to articulate.

38
00:07:43,419 --> 00:07:47,989
If the Bible is a base text for
most of European civilization,

39
00:07:48,163 --> 00:07:52,036
we've wanted the same kind of
mix of, like, horror and gore,

40
00:07:52,210 --> 00:07:55,126
as well as morally
uplifting stuff ever since.

41
00:07:55,300 --> 00:07:58,478
The dark side
of we, what we have,

42
00:07:58,652 --> 00:08:01,742
that's an internal part of us,
started to externalize it.

43
00:08:01,916 --> 00:08:05,180
And characters became
the dark side.

44
00:08:05,354 --> 00:08:10,098
It all stems
from Greek classical tragedy,

45
00:08:10,707 --> 00:08:15,538
and splits off
into Roman melodrama,

46
00:08:15,712 --> 00:08:20,021
then up through
Medieval morality plays

47
00:08:20,195 --> 00:08:23,067
into Elizabethan
revenge tragedy,

48
00:08:23,241 --> 00:08:27,245
then into Edwardian times
where they write melodramas.

49
00:08:27,419 --> 00:08:30,945
One of the ways in which you can
talk about very real things

50
00:08:31,772 --> 00:08:35,906
or very controversial things
is to dress them up as monsters.

51
00:08:36,080 --> 00:08:41,129
So, you get
to Frankenstein, 1818,

52
00:08:41,303 --> 00:08:43,697
And in one sense,
it's a very literal story

53
00:08:43,871 --> 00:08:47,614
about a guy
who stitches together

54
00:08:47,788 --> 00:08:51,269
another being
out of corpse parts,

55
00:08:51,443 --> 00:08:55,970
and runs a huge jolt of electricity
through him, and creates a monster.

56
00:08:56,144 --> 00:08:59,321
The Strange Case Of Dr. Jekyll
and Mr. Hyde is published in 1886,

57
00:08:59,495 --> 00:09:03,847
which is five years after the
Ripper murders had terrorized

58
00:09:04,021 --> 00:09:06,763
not just London
but the whole world.

59
00:09:06,937 --> 00:09:10,506
Jack the Ripper is the archetype
of all subsequent slashers.

60
00:09:10,680 --> 00:09:12,987
Name me a slasher movie
that doesn't draw

61
00:09:13,161 --> 00:09:16,207
on some aspect of,
of Jack the Ripper.

62
00:09:16,381 --> 00:09:21,256
And, of course, Bram Stoker was the
theater impresario who put that on stage.

63
00:09:21,430 --> 00:09:22,953
Bram Stoker'sDracula,

64
00:09:23,606 --> 00:09:26,435
not the first vampire story
by any means.

65
00:09:26,609 --> 00:09:28,916
You've had things
like Varney the Vampire,

66
00:09:29,090 --> 00:09:32,397
which was part of a
penny-dreadful story that came out.

67
00:09:32,572 --> 00:09:35,487
But Bram Stoker broke
really new ground,

68
00:09:35,662 --> 00:09:37,577
uh, by using old tropes.

69
00:09:37,751 --> 00:09:42,277
Film then was the natural place
to take over.

70
00:09:42,451 --> 00:09:45,497
In silent films,
and then in talkies.

71
00:09:45,672 --> 00:09:50,590
That structure
of how is the good guy

72
00:09:50,764 --> 00:09:52,853
gonna defeat the externalization

73
00:09:53,027 --> 00:09:54,898
of what the dark side in him

74
00:09:55,072 --> 00:09:57,292
in a character
has been realized?

75
00:09:57,466 --> 00:09:59,424
We can hate that person,

76
00:09:59,599 --> 00:10:03,211
who is really ourselves
externalized.

77
00:10:04,168 --> 00:10:07,519
That's the structure
of melodrama and horror.

78
00:10:07,694 --> 00:10:12,612
So much of it to me is the art direction,
and that's what those films were.

79
00:10:12,786 --> 00:10:15,155
You know, because for me, in
those films, that's what determines

80
00:10:15,179 --> 00:10:17,138
what makes them classic
and what doesn't.

81
00:10:21,011 --> 00:10:25,059
Well, of course, uh, my
great-grandfather being Lon Chaney Sr.

82
00:10:25,233 --> 00:10:29,063
Was very well renowned
in the horror genre.

83
00:10:29,237 --> 00:10:31,500
You can look at him,
and you see his influence

84
00:10:31,674 --> 00:10:33,676
all over Hollywood
even to this day.

85
00:10:33,850 --> 00:10:37,201
And he was the founding father
of the entire genre.

86
00:10:37,375 --> 00:10:41,510
In early 1930s, you have the very famous
versions of Draculaand Frankenstein,

87
00:10:41,684 --> 00:10:45,775
which set the look of the
monsters for generations to come.

88
00:10:45,949 --> 00:10:49,953
The character Dracula described
by Bram Stoker in his book

89
00:10:50,127 --> 00:10:53,827
was a, a horrific,
ugly kind of a being.

90
00:10:54,349 --> 00:10:57,134
Whereas my father brought
his own interpretation.

91
00:10:57,308 --> 00:10:59,702
He did his own makeup,
his mode of dress,

92
00:10:59,876 --> 00:11:03,053
his form of speech, his eyes.

93
00:11:03,227 --> 00:11:06,840
My dad's portrayal really
inspired a whole movement.

94
00:11:07,014 --> 00:11:10,713
The Goth movement has got even
carried over into the music world

95
00:11:10,887 --> 00:11:12,672
with, for example, Bauhaus.

96
00:11:12,846 --> 00:11:16,632
It was, uh, you know,
a dark, sinister,

97
00:11:16,806 --> 00:11:19,156
evil personification

98
00:11:19,983 --> 00:11:25,206
that crossed both worlds
from the films to music.

99
00:11:25,380 --> 00:11:28,644
And the same with Frankenstein
and Boris Karloff.

100
00:11:28,818 --> 00:11:31,865
You have the square head,
you have the bolts in the neck,

101
00:11:32,039 --> 00:11:34,432
the ragged coat that comes down

102
00:11:34,606 --> 00:11:38,480
because his arms are clearly taken
from somebody with very long arms.

103
00:11:38,654 --> 00:11:41,483
It was so different

104
00:11:41,657 --> 00:11:45,182
from anything the audiences
had ever seen before.

105
00:11:45,356 --> 00:11:48,272
It was startling.
Pushed so many envelopes.

106
00:11:48,446 --> 00:11:50,144
It was mesmerizing
because, you know,

107
00:11:50,318 --> 00:11:52,755
that film has
no music whatsoever.

108
00:11:52,929 --> 00:11:54,801
Only in the beginning
and in the end.

109
00:11:54,975 --> 00:11:57,542
And so when you really,
really think about it,

110
00:11:57,717 --> 00:12:01,895
it's a very, like,
empty-sounding film, you know,

111
00:12:02,069 --> 00:12:03,723
and I was intrigued by that.

112
00:12:03,897 --> 00:12:05,986
It just sucked me in, and I,

113
00:12:06,160 --> 00:12:08,553
I've just been in,
in this world ever since.

114
00:12:08,728 --> 00:12:12,514
I like the scene where the
little girl gives him the flower,

115
00:12:12,688 --> 00:12:16,170
and then he picks her up and
fucking hums her. I love that.

116
00:12:16,344 --> 00:12:20,261
I like the moment that he
realizes that he's a fucking monster,

117
00:12:20,435 --> 00:12:23,351
and that he's been reanimated
and forced to live.

118
00:12:23,525 --> 00:12:25,919
That's how we feel,
forced to live.

119
00:12:26,484 --> 00:12:29,270
And then, of course,
Chaney Jr. did The Wolf Man.

120
00:12:29,444 --> 00:12:33,535
And so, it was this wonderful
chain of horror films

121
00:12:33,709 --> 00:12:38,192
that captured the imagination
of film fans around the world.

122
00:12:38,366 --> 00:12:41,108
When Gramps would talk
about The Wolf Man,

123
00:12:41,282 --> 00:12:44,894
or roles that he would play, I
always thought they were so cool

124
00:12:45,068 --> 00:12:46,983
because he was
such a wonderful storyteller.

125
00:12:47,157 --> 00:12:49,037
People asked him,
"What was your favorite role?"

126
00:12:49,072 --> 00:12:50,900
And of course,
I think The Wolf Man

127
00:12:51,074 --> 00:12:53,250
has to come first
for me personally,

128
00:12:53,424 --> 00:12:57,124
It was a role meant
for my grandfather to make.

129
00:12:57,298 --> 00:13:01,302
My favorites by far, if anybody
knows me, it's the Universal Monsters.

130
00:13:01,476 --> 00:13:02,956
That's my whole life.

131
00:13:03,130 --> 00:13:05,523
Dracula, Frankenstein,
Invisible Man,

132
00:13:05,697 --> 00:13:10,093
The Mummy, Creature, Wolf Man.
I love those series.

133
00:13:10,267 --> 00:13:14,097
But I loved all the classic, uh,
Universal Monster movies that I saw.

134
00:13:14,271 --> 00:13:16,186
I love the Creature
from the Black Lagoon.

135
00:13:16,360 --> 00:13:18,188
Love the giant monster movies.

136
00:13:18,362 --> 00:13:21,191
They're awesome.
Tarantula, that kind of thing.

137
00:13:21,670 --> 00:13:25,369
I, at first, really didn't know
what to make of horror movies.

138
00:13:25,543 --> 00:13:28,895
I was very frightened.
But in later years,

139
00:13:29,721 --> 00:13:33,900
I've got to really enjoy
the '50s creature movies.

140
00:13:34,074 --> 00:13:37,599
My favorite of that time
was probably Them!

141
00:13:38,469 --> 00:13:39,949
You know, about giant ants.

142
00:13:40,123 --> 00:13:42,691
So I first started
getting interested in horror

143
00:13:42,865 --> 00:13:46,608
because I really was engaged
in those kind of creature movies

144
00:13:46,782 --> 00:13:49,306
and those kind of Atomic Age
fear movies.

145
00:13:49,480 --> 00:13:52,919
Are Japanese monster movies
considered horror films?

146
00:13:53,093 --> 00:13:56,748
'Cause that's, that's, that's
where my heart, true heart lies.

147
00:13:56,923 --> 00:14:00,187
It's like Godzilla
Vs. King Kongand stuff.

148
00:14:00,361 --> 00:14:02,754
- Yeah.
- -Just all the, like, model type of scenes

149
00:14:02,929 --> 00:14:07,020
and guys in lizard suits,
I love that stuff.

150
00:14:10,110 --> 00:14:12,939
With the evolution
of teen culture in the 1950s,

151
00:14:13,113 --> 00:14:16,203
you had, for the first time,
forms of entertainment

152
00:14:16,377 --> 00:14:18,509
that were unique
to young people.

153
00:14:18,683 --> 00:14:23,297
And I don't think it was for almost
20 years or a generation after that,

154
00:14:23,471 --> 00:14:26,648
the people really realized
the amount of room they had

155
00:14:26,822 --> 00:14:28,650
to spread out
and express themselves.

156
00:14:28,824 --> 00:14:31,435
One of the things that also
develops in the 1950s in the UK

157
00:14:31,609 --> 00:14:33,350
is the Hammer House of Horror.

158
00:14:33,524 --> 00:14:37,441
Nobody has quite mastered
branding like Hammer did.

159
00:14:37,615 --> 00:14:40,880
Like, if you see
Hammer House of Horror

160
00:14:43,926 --> 00:14:45,797
on a movie,
you know what you're getting.

161
00:14:45,972 --> 00:14:47,688
Curse Of Frankenstein,
and Teenage Frankenstein,

162
00:14:47,712 --> 00:14:49,560
and I would watch them,
of course, covering my face,

163
00:14:49,584 --> 00:14:51,934
but I had to see what
Frankenstein looked like, you know.

164
00:14:52,108 --> 00:14:55,329
My introduction to horror
came through Hammer.

165
00:14:55,503 --> 00:14:59,768
So that was my introduction,
really, to Dracula and Frankenstein,

166
00:15:00,551 --> 00:15:02,989
and then kind of
worked backwards

167
00:15:03,163 --> 00:15:07,428
discovering the, the classic Universal
movies, um, subsequent to that.

168
00:15:11,388 --> 00:15:13,390
You can't really talk
about horror

169
00:15:13,564 --> 00:15:15,653
without talking about
Hitchcock and Psycho.

170
00:15:15,827 --> 00:15:18,700
It helps set the paradigm
for our subsequent obsession

171
00:15:18,874 --> 00:15:20,093
with serial killers in film.

172
00:15:20,267 --> 00:15:21,964
I always loved Hitchcock.

173
00:15:22,138 --> 00:15:24,575
I thought that
his stuff was amazing

174
00:15:24,749 --> 00:15:27,056
because, you know,
there was, uh, attention

175
00:15:27,230 --> 00:15:31,539
to the, uh, just the whole
story line that, you know...

176
00:15:31,713 --> 00:15:35,064
Like, the Bates Motel,
you know, it was a creepy hotel.

177
00:15:35,238 --> 00:15:39,286
Dude's mom's dead, and, you know,
he cross-dresses and kills people.

178
00:15:39,460 --> 00:15:42,289
That's really cool when you can
have a story that's that simple.

179
00:15:42,463 --> 00:15:45,770
They did such a good job
in the early days of, mm,

180
00:15:45,945 --> 00:15:49,252
you know, "Don't come if you
have a problem with your heart,"

181
00:15:49,426 --> 00:15:51,863
and these great gimmicks
about that, you know,

182
00:15:52,038 --> 00:15:54,605
"There will be a nurse
in attendance, and..."

183
00:15:54,779 --> 00:15:56,129
Of course, that sucked us in.

184
00:15:56,303 --> 00:15:58,479
You know,
we wanted to go see that.

185
00:15:59,045 --> 00:16:01,656
They're coming
to get you, Barbara.

186
00:16:01,830 --> 00:16:04,374
Towards the tail end of the '60s,
you have Night Of The Living Dead,

187
00:16:04,398 --> 00:16:06,139
and it's a terrifying movie.

188
00:16:06,313 --> 00:16:09,403
Not only because it introduces
a new type of monster,

189
00:16:09,577 --> 00:16:14,799
but because it suggests
that we as human beings,

190
00:16:14,974 --> 00:16:16,976
at some point,
we'll lose agency,

191
00:16:17,150 --> 00:16:18,716
we'll lose sentience.

192
00:16:18,890 --> 00:16:21,371
Jesus Christ. It's, like,
right in your face, like...

193
00:16:21,545 --> 00:16:23,721
Which is not typical
of a black and white movie.

194
00:16:23,895 --> 00:16:26,309
You just sort of, "Oh, it's black and
white. It's probably going to be slow.

195
00:16:26,333 --> 00:16:27,813
I've heard it's great,
but we'll see."

196
00:16:27,856 --> 00:16:29,466
And then it just explodes.
You know,

197
00:16:29,640 --> 00:16:31,680
like, "Holy fuck." You know,
and it's just, it's on.

198
00:16:31,773 --> 00:16:34,384
Zombies weren't very frightening

199
00:16:34,558 --> 00:16:36,212
until we made
Night Of The Living Dead.

200
00:16:36,386 --> 00:16:38,432
You've lost a loved one,

201
00:16:38,606 --> 00:16:42,262
but now that loved one's out
to get you, actually devour you.

202
00:16:42,436 --> 00:16:45,743
And if you get bitten by one,
you can turn into one.

203
00:16:45,917 --> 00:16:51,184
In a way, it combines the
vampire myth and the zombie myth.

204
00:16:51,358 --> 00:16:53,490
We saw a lot of horror stories,

205
00:16:53,664 --> 00:16:55,971
like, during the,
the war in Nam.

206
00:16:56,145 --> 00:16:58,147
It was a big time
for horror films,

207
00:16:58,321 --> 00:17:01,672
and that all came out of that Nam
period and our return from Nam.

208
00:17:01,846 --> 00:17:04,216
Blood and destruction on television
had become so commonplace

209
00:17:04,240 --> 00:17:06,088
that it couldn't help
but make it into the films.

210
00:17:06,112 --> 00:17:08,549
And I think
that had a profound effect

211
00:17:08,723 --> 00:17:12,944
on why horror gets so gory
in the 1970s.

212
00:17:13,119 --> 00:17:16,339
Because people have seen it
in the real world.

213
00:17:16,513 --> 00:17:18,167
My two favorite movies are

214
00:17:18,341 --> 00:17:19,951
Texas Chainsaw Massacre
I and II.

215
00:17:20,126 --> 00:17:22,389
I just remember this scene
in Texas Chainsaw

216
00:17:22,563 --> 00:17:24,130
when, when, uh,

217
00:17:24,782 --> 00:17:27,568
what I believe is Kurt or
whatever is going into the house,

218
00:17:27,742 --> 00:17:30,179
and he just whacks him
in the head as...

219
00:17:30,353 --> 00:17:33,617
And he just falls. You see
his legs kicking. Hits him again.

220
00:17:33,791 --> 00:17:36,577
And this, the slamming
of that door was just like,

221
00:17:36,751 --> 00:17:40,189
"What the fuck was that?"

222
00:17:40,363 --> 00:17:42,931
Leatherface and his situation
are kind of emblematic

223
00:17:43,105 --> 00:17:45,760
of extreme elements in life,

224
00:17:45,934 --> 00:17:48,241
and that may be part
of his appeal.

225
00:17:48,415 --> 00:17:52,462
In a way, Chainsaw Massacre
is about the end of the world,

226
00:17:52,636 --> 00:17:56,553
and I think that might be
part of Leatherface

227
00:17:56,727 --> 00:18:00,731
and Chainsaw Massacre'sappeal
in heavy metal.

228
00:18:00,905 --> 00:18:03,778
That it really is apocalyptic,

229
00:18:03,952 --> 00:18:06,520
and Leatherface
is an apocalyptic character,

230
00:18:06,694 --> 00:18:10,263
and I think there,
you begin to see an overlap

231
00:18:10,437 --> 00:18:12,700
in the interests
of a lot of heavy metal music.

232
00:18:12,874 --> 00:18:15,877
The Exorcist.
I was both kind of

233
00:18:16,051 --> 00:18:17,618
terrified by it
and shocked by it,

234
00:18:17,792 --> 00:18:21,187
and, and, uh, moved, uh,
disturbed, and compelled.

235
00:18:21,361 --> 00:18:23,580
Totally wanted to see more.

236
00:18:23,754 --> 00:18:26,670
Just the, the tone of it
and the denigration

237
00:18:26,844 --> 00:18:29,238
of the priest by Regan
and all of that.

238
00:18:29,412 --> 00:18:31,675
Just the way she looked, man.
It was just fucked up.

239
00:18:31,849 --> 00:18:35,114
You know what I mean? And
her voice, it was just, it was scary.

240
00:18:35,288 --> 00:18:37,203
I don't know.
I think it scared everybody.

241
00:18:39,683 --> 00:18:44,340
My mom took me to see the
original Jaws when I was really young,

242
00:18:44,514 --> 00:18:47,822
and it scarred me for life.

243
00:18:47,996 --> 00:18:52,000
It traumatized me. I mean, I
was f... I was fucked because I...

244
00:18:53,219 --> 00:18:55,980
Even in a pool, at that... and when I
was younger, I was, like, freaking out.

245
00:18:56,004 --> 00:18:58,124
"It's like a fucking pool.
Like, what's gonna happen?"

246
00:18:58,180 --> 00:19:00,878
But I don't know. It's just weird
the way it just did that to me.

247
00:19:01,052 --> 00:19:04,317
Like, that first scene when she
goes out swimming in the night,

248
00:19:04,491 --> 00:19:06,145
yeah, that never left me.
So that was a...

249
00:19:07,494 --> 00:19:09,452
That's one fear
that I still have.

250
00:19:09,626 --> 00:19:11,237
The first VHS tape
I ever had to have

251
00:19:11,411 --> 00:19:12,194
was Dawn Of The Dead,

252
00:19:12,368 --> 00:19:13,368
and I used to let it play

253
00:19:13,456 --> 00:19:14,849
over and over all day long.

254
00:19:15,023 --> 00:19:16,938
I must have watched it
thousands of times.

255
00:19:17,112 --> 00:19:18,853
It was always on,

256
00:19:19,027 --> 00:19:21,638
and I don't know why
that gave me such comfort,

257
00:19:21,812 --> 00:19:24,859
just having Dawn Of The Dead
playing constantly, but it did.

258
00:19:25,033 --> 00:19:30,081
Dawn Of The Deadwas, you know, like, one of
the big first splatter fest involving zombies.

259
00:19:30,256 --> 00:19:32,475
I mean, now, I mean,
everything is zombies.

260
00:19:32,649 --> 00:19:35,130
This is...
Now we're in the zombie decade.

261
00:19:35,304 --> 00:19:37,848
Uh, a lot of it has to do with the
number one show on television,

262
00:19:37,872 --> 00:19:40,614
Walking Dead,
with my protégé, Greg Nicotero.

263
00:19:40,788 --> 00:19:44,835
So that, obviously,
is an influence of my stuff.

264
00:19:45,009 --> 00:19:48,143
Phantasm. The first one really
left an impression on me.

265
00:19:48,317 --> 00:19:50,319
But the part
that scared me the most,

266
00:19:50,493 --> 00:19:52,800
'cause I didn't, um, understand,

267
00:19:52,974 --> 00:19:55,213
and when it was explained
to me, it, like, kind of hit home.

268
00:19:55,237 --> 00:19:56,978
The ball goes
in the guy's forehead,

269
00:19:57,152 --> 00:19:58,936
and it drills in,
and he falls down.

270
00:19:59,110 --> 00:20:01,939
I mean, he's obviously dead.
But they show him that he pees.

271
00:20:03,245 --> 00:20:06,117
And then I asked,
like, "Why is he peeing?"

272
00:20:06,292 --> 00:20:08,511
He said, "Well, you release
your bowels after you die."

273
00:20:09,686 --> 00:20:13,473
I was like, "Well, I'm gonna
shit my pants when, when I die."

274
00:20:13,647 --> 00:20:15,668
That's terrifying. That scared
the bejesus out of me.

275
00:20:15,692 --> 00:20:17,955
That was just more evidence
of actual death.

276
00:20:18,129 --> 00:20:20,567
The Omen. The first, um...
Both of them were really good,

277
00:20:20,741 --> 00:20:23,352
but I like the one with
Gregory Peck and Lee Remick.

278
00:20:23,526 --> 00:20:26,268
I thought that the story
was really well written

279
00:20:26,442 --> 00:20:31,012
and very, very scary
and very evil and creepy.

280
00:20:31,186 --> 00:20:33,536
The Omen, that was the only one

281
00:20:33,710 --> 00:20:36,931
that really made me
have some, uh, nightmares

282
00:20:37,105 --> 00:20:39,150
as, uh, as far as
I can remember.

283
00:20:39,325 --> 00:20:43,111
The, uh, connection
with horror and myself

284
00:20:43,285 --> 00:20:46,201
really does start
with Halloween, you know,

285
00:20:46,375 --> 00:20:49,030
in terms of any active interest
in the genre.

286
00:20:49,204 --> 00:20:52,860
I don't think they had any idea
how big Myers himself would be.

287
00:20:53,034 --> 00:20:55,428
That character
has become pretty big.

288
00:20:55,602 --> 00:20:58,692
It's a hell of a franchise, and
I'm proud to be a part of it.

289
00:20:58,866 --> 00:21:02,565
Michael Myers, uh,
became a famous creature

290
00:21:02,739 --> 00:21:05,307
because he wore a mask, and
because he was completely evil.

291
00:21:05,481 --> 00:21:06,917
He's really a simple character.

292
00:21:07,091 --> 00:21:09,659
He doesn't have
much of a backstory

293
00:21:09,833 --> 00:21:11,357
to land the movies that I did.

294
00:21:11,531 --> 00:21:14,273
He is just a force of evil
out to get you.

295
00:21:14,447 --> 00:21:18,364
The idea of an expressionless,
blank, uh, human being

296
00:21:18,538 --> 00:21:20,931
is really pretty devastating.

297
00:21:21,105 --> 00:21:22,977
It is almost like,
"What is he thinking?

298
00:21:23,151 --> 00:21:26,023
What's going on
in that strange person's brain

299
00:21:26,197 --> 00:21:29,026
that we can't decipher,
'cause we can't look inside."

300
00:21:29,200 --> 00:21:31,246
Alien, when it came out,

301
00:21:31,420 --> 00:21:33,204
you didn't see
much of the monster.

302
00:21:33,988 --> 00:21:36,904
But it was all
the build up to it.

303
00:21:37,078 --> 00:21:39,167
And then landing on that planet,

304
00:21:39,341 --> 00:21:41,212
and then the Facehugger,

305
00:21:41,387 --> 00:21:43,432
that, that scared
the shit out of me.

306
00:21:43,606 --> 00:21:45,652
The movie
that affected me the most,

307
00:21:46,305 --> 00:21:49,612
that I actually jumped out
of my chair was Salem's Lot.

308
00:21:50,744 --> 00:21:53,312
And I'm watching it, and they
keep talking about Mr. Barlow.

309
00:21:53,486 --> 00:21:56,271
Three quarters through the
movie, you don't see Mr. Barlow,

310
00:21:56,445 --> 00:22:00,841
and then all of a sudden,
the entire scream is Barlow.

311
00:22:01,320 --> 00:22:05,062
And it's the most evil-looking
vampire of all time.

312
00:22:05,236 --> 00:22:08,892
The '80s has to be possibly
the greatest era of horror,

313
00:22:09,066 --> 00:22:13,723
because you have a lot of great
minds working within the genre.

314
00:22:13,897 --> 00:22:18,554
You have amazing advances in special
effects, which mean that you could...

315
00:22:18,728 --> 00:22:22,732
Literally, something like
The Thing, which is '82,

316
00:22:22,906 --> 00:22:27,128
shows stuff that people
had never even imagined.

317
00:22:27,302 --> 00:22:31,088
Rob Bottin's effects were just
so ahead of their time,

318
00:22:31,262 --> 00:22:34,657
and still to this day, probably
the best practical makeup

319
00:22:34,831 --> 00:22:36,224
ever done in a movie.

320
00:22:36,398 --> 00:22:38,400
One scene I remember
from my childhood was

321
00:22:38,574 --> 00:22:42,012
um, in The Thing, the thing
is eating, um, the dogs,

322
00:22:42,186 --> 00:22:45,712
and to me, I, I saw that,
and it was so horrifying

323
00:22:45,886 --> 00:22:48,802
as a child to see
that kind of, you know, carnage.

324
00:22:48,976 --> 00:22:50,369
The Shining, man.

325
00:22:51,239 --> 00:22:55,417
My God, that film
is a lesson in isolation

326
00:22:55,896 --> 00:23:00,161
and how maddening
your, your, your mind can go

327
00:23:00,335 --> 00:23:04,165
when you're just completely cut
off from outside stimuli, you know,

328
00:23:04,339 --> 00:23:05,862
and you're left
to your own devices

329
00:23:06,036 --> 00:23:08,604
in this fucking monstrous,

330
00:23:08,778 --> 00:23:12,086
basically just a fucking castle,
you know.

331
00:23:12,956 --> 00:23:14,523
Anyone would go fucking mad.

332
00:23:14,697 --> 00:23:17,265
When they first realize,
you know, that he's losing...

333
00:23:17,439 --> 00:23:18,875
You first see it in the film.

334
00:23:19,049 --> 00:23:22,139
You know, he's, he's going,
his mind is gone.

335
00:23:22,313 --> 00:23:24,054
You know, and it's like
he's sitting there.

336
00:23:24,228 --> 00:23:26,293
- And then she starts thumbing...
- That's too much like real life.

337
00:23:26,317 --> 00:23:28,668
Thumbing through the shit,
you know.

338
00:23:28,842 --> 00:23:31,642
"All work and no play," like, you
know, the big stack, and you're like,

339
00:23:31,801 --> 00:23:35,283
"Oh, it's on now, man,"
you know.

340
00:23:35,457 --> 00:23:37,522
'Cause that is... it has to be
one of the greatest movies

341
00:23:37,546 --> 00:23:39,156
ever made from every aspect.

342
00:23:39,330 --> 00:23:40,525
You know, the actors,
and the casting,

343
00:23:40,549 --> 00:23:41,709
and the photo and everything.

344
00:23:41,811 --> 00:23:43,422
- Yeah.
- But still I meet people,

345
00:23:43,596 --> 00:23:45,756
when people don't dig it,
I find it hard to trust them.

346
00:23:45,902 --> 00:23:47,600
Yeah.

347
00:23:47,774 --> 00:23:49,471
The Shininghas
this cult following,

348
00:23:49,645 --> 00:23:50,820
which is great.

349
00:23:50,994 --> 00:23:52,953
I feel fortunate
to have been in it.

350
00:23:53,127 --> 00:23:55,521
And, uh, I guess,
my guess would be that

351
00:23:55,695 --> 00:23:58,480
it was probably playing on cable
when all those guys were kids.

352
00:23:58,654 --> 00:24:03,180
And so, they were probably
frightened by it like many other people.

353
00:24:03,354 --> 00:24:05,531
The third Omenmovie,
when he's in the, in the room

354
00:24:05,705 --> 00:24:07,228
with the statue of Jesus.

355
00:24:08,229 --> 00:24:11,450
"Show man instead the raptures
of Thy kingdom." Oh, it's so...

356
00:24:11,624 --> 00:24:13,843
Ooh, when he puts his hands
on the thing, and it bleeds,

357
00:24:14,017 --> 00:24:16,897
and they make the, the blood, you
know, symbolize Jesus crying, whatever.

358
00:24:17,368 --> 00:24:20,371
Oh, I would have just let him
wi... the anti-Christ win.

359
00:24:20,546 --> 00:24:22,591
Halloween III,
Season Of The Witch.

360
00:24:22,765 --> 00:24:24,165
And people
either love it or hate it

361
00:24:24,201 --> 00:24:25,681
because it doesn't have
Michael Myers.

362
00:24:25,768 --> 00:24:27,335
But that didn't bother me at all

363
00:24:27,509 --> 00:24:28,989
when I was a kid,
I was so young,

364
00:24:29,163 --> 00:24:31,252
I wasn't kind of expecting
to see Michael Myers.

365
00:24:31,426 --> 00:24:33,515
And I look at it
as a separate movie.

366
00:24:33,689 --> 00:24:35,386
As a movie, a standalone movie.

367
00:24:35,561 --> 00:24:37,084
Halloween Illis incredible.

368
00:24:37,258 --> 00:24:39,739
And I always liked it
as a standalone movie.

369
00:24:39,913 --> 00:24:42,481
Not because I was the assassin
ripping people's heads off

370
00:24:42,655 --> 00:24:44,570
mind you, but, anyway...

371
00:24:44,744 --> 00:24:48,051
Evil Dead Part I, Sam Raimi.

372
00:24:49,531 --> 00:24:50,967
Atmosphere,

373
00:24:51,794 --> 00:24:53,100
attitude,

374
00:24:53,274 --> 00:24:55,885
gore, soundtrack,

375
00:24:56,059 --> 00:24:58,366
hands down, got to be...

376
00:25:03,023 --> 00:25:05,504
the The Black Rainbow of horror.

377
00:25:06,505 --> 00:25:09,986
To me, the real,
the real classics,

378
00:25:10,160 --> 00:25:12,554
the ones that came out,
like that Basket Case,

379
00:25:12,728 --> 00:25:15,818
my friends and I still talk
about Belial to this day.

380
00:25:15,992 --> 00:25:18,792
And when it was cool, then you
could show the girls to get them scared.

381
00:25:18,908 --> 00:25:21,191
And then plus, still, you went
through the classics, you know,

382
00:25:21,215 --> 00:25:23,130
all the Friday the 13th
and that sort of thing.

383
00:25:23,304 --> 00:25:26,263
People wanted to see
violence and blood,

384
00:25:26,437 --> 00:25:28,614
and the people that were bad,

385
00:25:28,788 --> 00:25:32,095
that were having premarital sex,
and drinking,

386
00:25:32,269 --> 00:25:35,795
and smoking pot or whatever die.

387
00:25:35,969 --> 00:25:39,581
As soon as they say, "Jason,"
everybody knows the hockey mask.

388
00:25:39,755 --> 00:25:44,717
I don't think that was expected, uh, when
part one came out, part two, part three,

389
00:25:44,891 --> 00:25:48,982
but when the first person, which was
Richard, that donned the hockey mask,

390
00:25:49,156 --> 00:25:51,288
I think it was just one
of those things that took off.

391
00:25:51,462 --> 00:25:54,422
This is a character
that had six movies

392
00:25:55,249 --> 00:25:58,557
uh, before I ever got involved,

393
00:25:58,731 --> 00:26:01,472
and so everybody knew the
character's name around the world.

394
00:26:02,038 --> 00:26:04,780
It was almost like
each successive movie

395
00:26:05,389 --> 00:26:07,522
had to do honor
to the previous ones

396
00:26:07,696 --> 00:26:12,788
by coming up with inventive,
crazy, over-the-top kills.

397
00:26:12,962 --> 00:26:15,574
People are still looking back
saying, "Well, that's Leatherface.

398
00:26:15,748 --> 00:26:20,100
That's Jason, Michael Myers,
and Freddie, of course."

399
00:26:20,274 --> 00:26:23,886
One of my favorite movies is the
Nightmare On Elm Street, the first one.

400
00:26:24,713 --> 00:26:27,542
I still get scared of that fucking
movie. It's, that was so awesome.

401
00:26:27,716 --> 00:26:31,502
The first one was actually
the most interesting for me.

402
00:26:31,677 --> 00:26:33,548
Just the dynamics of the film,

403
00:26:33,722 --> 00:26:38,335
of this whole town
keeping a secret, this guilt.

404
00:26:38,901 --> 00:26:43,253
That kind of was like a
representation of humanity, uh,

405
00:26:43,427 --> 00:26:46,430
keeping secrets and not letting
certain things out.

406
00:26:46,605 --> 00:26:49,520
I think there's a big reputation
of that and how it can come back

407
00:26:49,695 --> 00:26:53,176
to have these repercussions
on, on them.

408
00:26:53,350 --> 00:26:54,874
You're a vampire, Michael.

409
00:26:55,048 --> 00:26:57,180
My own brother.
A goddamn shit-sucking vampire.

410
00:26:57,354 --> 00:27:01,315
Lost Boysis one of my
all-time favorites movies ever.

411
00:27:01,489 --> 00:27:04,753
And the connection
between rock and roll,

412
00:27:04,927 --> 00:27:07,626
long-haired dudes,
leather dudes,

413
00:27:07,800 --> 00:27:10,411
hot chicks, great music,

414
00:27:10,585 --> 00:27:12,413
and killing people
because you have to

415
00:27:12,587 --> 00:27:15,459
'cause you're a vampire
in beautiful California.

416
00:27:15,634 --> 00:27:19,028
That was, like, one of the first ones
that really made it cool and young,

417
00:27:19,202 --> 00:27:21,291
uh, with, with the,
with vampires.

418
00:27:21,465 --> 00:27:23,487
I'm really fond of a movie
called Prince Of Darkness.

419
00:27:23,511 --> 00:27:25,339
This is, like, tremendous.

420
00:27:25,513 --> 00:27:27,036
That ending has to be
one of my most

421
00:27:27,210 --> 00:27:28,472
favorite endings in the world.

422
00:27:28,647 --> 00:27:31,345
I recommend that movie highly.

423
00:27:31,519 --> 00:27:33,913
It scared me, and I thought
about it for a while.

424
00:27:34,087 --> 00:27:36,002
John Carpenter and I
were good friends.

425
00:27:36,524 --> 00:27:39,570
And I said, "I wanna come down
and watch you do some of the filming."

426
00:27:39,745 --> 00:27:41,505
And he says, "Okay, yeah,
just come on down."

427
00:27:41,572 --> 00:27:43,618
I put Alice
in Prince Of Darkness

428
00:27:43,792 --> 00:27:45,533
basically because he showed up.

429
00:27:45,707 --> 00:27:47,666
I said, "Oh, here. Get in here."

430
00:27:47,840 --> 00:27:50,146
He says, "You know that thing
you do with the mic stand,

431
00:27:50,320 --> 00:27:54,107
where you stick it through the guy on
stage and it comes out the other end?

432
00:27:54,281 --> 00:27:55,911
"Could we do that with a bicycle
through this guy?"

433
00:27:55,935 --> 00:27:57,284
And I went, "Sure."

434
00:27:57,458 --> 00:28:00,461
Next thing I know,
now, I'm in the movie.

435
00:28:00,635 --> 00:28:03,290
It was a lot of fun to work
with him. He's a great guy.

436
00:28:04,073 --> 00:28:05,814
Hellraiseris another
massive great film,

437
00:28:05,988 --> 00:28:07,749
and I remember watching that
for the first time

438
00:28:07,773 --> 00:28:09,731
and being totally blown away
with it.

439
00:28:09,905 --> 00:28:11,951
And it had this kind
of pornography to it.

440
00:28:12,125 --> 00:28:13,755
Especially the second one
as well. They took it

441
00:28:13,779 --> 00:28:15,379
a little stage further
in the second one.

442
00:28:15,519 --> 00:28:18,914
And I think it was,
uh, sort of S-M, bondage,

443
00:28:19,088 --> 00:28:22,004
demonic, dark fantasy, I guess.

444
00:28:22,178 --> 00:28:24,528
There is nothing like it,

445
00:28:24,703 --> 00:28:27,140
I don't think, anywhere else
in horror movies.

446
00:28:27,314 --> 00:28:29,359
It's human. It's not human.

447
00:28:30,099 --> 00:28:32,362
And then there's
this little matter

448
00:28:32,536 --> 00:28:35,322
of having a whole bunch of nails
banged into your head,

449
00:28:35,496 --> 00:28:38,629
which sounds like,
sounds like a crazy idea.

450
00:28:38,804 --> 00:28:40,980
Pet Sematary. Big film.

451
00:28:41,154 --> 00:28:44,331
I remember very, very clearly
when, you know, it sort of came out

452
00:28:44,505 --> 00:28:47,508
and, and how it was spoken about

453
00:28:47,682 --> 00:28:51,381
amongst the, the friends that I had
that were allowed to sort of watch.

454
00:28:51,555 --> 00:28:53,688
I mean, we were eight years old
at that point,

455
00:28:54,645 --> 00:28:56,365
So it was like,
"Have you seen Pet Sematary?

456
00:28:56,517 --> 00:28:59,955
"It's like the, the most
frightening film ever."

457
00:29:00,129 --> 00:29:02,915
That scene in Pet Sematary
with the, the sister

458
00:29:03,089 --> 00:29:05,744
who's got spinal meningitis,
that's a real thing.

459
00:29:05,918 --> 00:29:08,838
And you watch that and, you know,
you get, like, goose... I get goosebumps

460
00:29:08,921 --> 00:29:11,290
even thinking about it, 'cause
that's this classic scene of that movie.

461
00:29:11,314 --> 00:29:12,315
Terrifying, you know.

462
00:29:12,489 --> 00:29:14,927
Stephen King is a Ramones fan,

463
00:29:15,101 --> 00:29:19,061
and, uh, we did the video,
"Pet Sematary,"

464
00:29:19,235 --> 00:29:21,629
where me, Joey,
and the rest of the band

465
00:29:22,586 --> 00:29:25,807
are, uh, going down
into the grave.

466
00:29:25,981 --> 00:29:27,853
Dee Dee decided
to write the song,

467
00:29:28,027 --> 00:29:29,308
and then it ended up
in the movies.

468
00:29:29,332 --> 00:29:30,899
So did
"Sheena Is a Punk Rocker."

469
00:29:31,073 --> 00:29:33,293
In the truck
while the guy's driving,

470
00:29:33,467 --> 00:29:35,991
and then the baby comes out
on the highway and...

471
00:29:36,165 --> 00:29:39,603
No!

472
00:29:39,778 --> 00:29:42,234
Once White Zombie got... started
going, it was starting to get from records,

473
00:29:42,258 --> 00:29:44,043
and there was money to be had,

474
00:29:44,217 --> 00:29:46,175
I started directing
the music videos,

475
00:29:46,349 --> 00:29:50,571
and I, "Okay, okay.
This will be my sort of in."

476
00:29:50,745 --> 00:29:53,617
So, when the opportunity
came up to make a film,

477
00:29:53,792 --> 00:29:55,924
which was House Of 1000 Corpses,
it was like...

478
00:29:56,098 --> 00:29:57,658
That's why that movie,
of all my movies,

479
00:29:57,708 --> 00:30:00,233
has the most elements
of, like, music video.

480
00:30:00,407 --> 00:30:03,236
He had this little movie called
House Of 1000 Corpses

481
00:30:03,410 --> 00:30:05,760
that had been green-lit
by Universal Studios.

482
00:30:06,456 --> 00:30:09,546
And he asked me if I wanted to
play, uh, this character, Otis Driftwood.

483
00:30:09,720 --> 00:30:11,244
And I said, "Yeah."

484
00:30:11,418 --> 00:30:13,376
And then, of course,
that then, you know,

485
00:30:13,550 --> 00:30:17,032
got refined and amplified
in Devil's Rejects.

486
00:30:17,206 --> 00:30:19,121
Devil's Rejects,
still such a killer movie.

487
00:30:19,295 --> 00:30:22,124
And so glad Sid Haig was
introduced to the world again

488
00:30:22,298 --> 00:30:24,387
as Captain Spaulding character.
Maybe...

489
00:30:25,345 --> 00:30:26,999
Probably the coolest character
to come out

490
00:30:27,173 --> 00:30:29,392
and I really, like,
since the old guys.

491
00:30:29,566 --> 00:30:32,918
I see how people

492
00:30:33,092 --> 00:30:36,138
have been affected
by what it is that I do,

493
00:30:36,312 --> 00:30:39,011
and it's, it's,
it's very flattering.

494
00:30:39,185 --> 00:30:43,711
Captain Spaulding triggered
the rebellious nature of people

495
00:30:43,885 --> 00:30:47,933
because he just, Spaulding
just does not give a shit, okay?

496
00:30:48,411 --> 00:30:51,066
And that is kind of
the attitude that goes along

497
00:30:51,240 --> 00:30:54,287
with metal and horror,

498
00:30:54,461 --> 00:30:58,160
is like, "You know,
I'm gonna do what I'm gonna do.

499
00:30:58,334 --> 00:31:00,989
If you don't like it,
tough shit, okay?"

500
00:31:01,163 --> 00:31:03,078
I think what makes
effective horror is that

501
00:31:03,252 --> 00:31:06,429
it registers the anxiety of the
humans that are watching them.

502
00:31:06,603 --> 00:31:08,214
That's what horror does best.

503
00:31:08,388 --> 00:31:09,737
It makes meaning in the same way

504
00:31:09,911 --> 00:31:12,522
melodrama and great opera
makes meaning.

505
00:31:12,696 --> 00:31:15,786
It thrives on humans' anxiety.

506
00:31:15,961 --> 00:31:17,005
Horror films,

507
00:31:17,919 --> 00:31:20,574
politically, philosophically,

508
00:31:20,748 --> 00:31:25,709
emotionally,
psychologically, spiritually,

509
00:31:26,710 --> 00:31:28,930
depending on the film
and the person,

510
00:31:29,104 --> 00:31:32,238
there is a horror film
that has affected them

511
00:31:32,412 --> 00:31:35,371
and never, ever
left their psyche.

512
00:31:35,545 --> 00:31:38,418
And no other field does that.

513
00:31:39,288 --> 00:31:42,683
And there you have a little
history of the art of horror.

514
00:31:42,857 --> 00:31:44,815
We've heard
from many heavy metal artists

515
00:31:44,990 --> 00:31:47,644
as they shared with us
their favorite horror films.

516
00:31:47,818 --> 00:31:49,908
Let's take a step back
and find out

517
00:31:50,778 --> 00:31:54,390
when their obsession
with the genre first began.

518
00:31:55,565 --> 00:31:59,308
On Saturday, you and your
buddies would go to the east town,

519
00:31:59,482 --> 00:32:01,702
and Mom would drop you off
in the morning,

520
00:32:01,876 --> 00:32:04,096
and it would be
It Came From Outer Space

521
00:32:04,270 --> 00:32:05,836
and The Brain That Wouldn't Die.

522
00:32:06,011 --> 00:32:08,839
And that was
the rite of passage.

523
00:32:09,014 --> 00:32:11,146
That's how you, that,
we grew up on those movies.

524
00:32:11,320 --> 00:32:14,367
The first, uh, monster movie
that I saw was

525
00:32:14,541 --> 00:32:17,587
7th Voyage Of Sinbad,
uh, with the cyclops.

526
00:32:18,588 --> 00:32:22,636
Every time I'd wake up, I think
he'd be, uh, out my window

527
00:32:23,202 --> 00:32:25,508
ready to just, you know,
put his head through it.

528
00:32:25,682 --> 00:32:28,903
It was movies like that
that really, uh,

529
00:32:29,077 --> 00:32:32,080
left an impression in, in me
as a young boy.

530
00:32:32,254 --> 00:32:35,040
When you are a 10-year-old,
you have an 11-year-old friend

531
00:32:35,214 --> 00:32:38,304
who has a 12-year-old friend that
has a 13-year-old, so, so on and so on,

532
00:32:38,478 --> 00:32:41,524
from that 18-year-old that had
Cannibal Holocaust, you know, so...

533
00:32:42,308 --> 00:32:44,155
The first... Uh, no, I didn't see
that. I didn't want to,

534
00:32:44,179 --> 00:32:45,876
but you know
the, the whole principle.

535
00:32:46,051 --> 00:32:48,662
I got introduced
to weird shit too early.

536
00:32:48,836 --> 00:32:53,188
They used to have big, giant, like, kind
of coffee table books about horror movies,

537
00:32:53,362 --> 00:32:55,930
and I, I would always ask for
those for Christmas, you know.

538
00:32:56,104 --> 00:32:59,151
And I subscribed to Famous
Monstersmagazine, Forrest Ackerman.

539
00:32:59,325 --> 00:33:03,416
Before I knew anything else, I was always
really, really, really into horror movies.

540
00:33:03,590 --> 00:33:08,551
I think as a kid, we all get
excited about Halloween

541
00:33:08,725 --> 00:33:10,814
and, and the different types
of monsters

542
00:33:10,989 --> 00:33:12,512
and watching cartoons and stuff.

543
00:33:12,686 --> 00:33:15,645
We kind of graduated
into stuff like, you know,

544
00:33:15,819 --> 00:33:19,214
watching Dracula,
the Wolf Man, Frankenstein,

545
00:33:19,388 --> 00:33:21,738
The Mummy,
the Creature Of Black Lagoon.

546
00:33:21,912 --> 00:33:24,002
You know,
all these classic flicks.

547
00:33:24,176 --> 00:33:26,197
Strangely enough, when I was in,
like, second grade or something,

548
00:33:26,221 --> 00:33:28,484
they brought in a,
the big reels and showed us

549
00:33:28,658 --> 00:33:31,835
Phantom Of The Opera, the silent
version, which seems like an odd thing.

550
00:33:32,010 --> 00:33:33,620
It was very exciting,
but it seemed like,

551
00:33:33,794 --> 00:33:35,511
seems like an odd movie
for a bunch of second graders.

552
00:33:35,535 --> 00:33:37,363
My dad used to call it
the Super Saturday,

553
00:33:37,537 --> 00:33:39,254
and I was like, "Well, how many
days of Super Saturday?"

554
00:33:39,278 --> 00:33:41,976
He's like, "Two more days,"
and I'm like, "Yes."

555
00:33:42,150 --> 00:33:47,460
It was just all this, just
almost like overload of cartoons

556
00:33:47,634 --> 00:33:50,898
and the Groovie Goolies were
on. I was obsessed with that show.

557
00:33:51,072 --> 00:33:54,728
It didn't seem that different to me, the
Bugs Bunny or the Frankenstein. Like,

558
00:33:54,902 --> 00:33:57,557
it really was a natural
kind of thing, you know.

559
00:33:57,731 --> 00:34:00,864
So, uh, that's really was
the monsters in Addams Family.

560
00:34:01,039 --> 00:34:03,128
Like, that's really kind
of where, where it started.

561
00:34:03,302 --> 00:34:04,912
I was raised
in foster homes as a kid.

562
00:34:05,086 --> 00:34:06,686
There was a little TV
in the living room,

563
00:34:06,827 --> 00:34:09,047
and on Saturday nights,
there was this show,

564
00:34:09,221 --> 00:34:11,223
and the show was called
Jeepers Creepers.

565
00:34:11,397 --> 00:34:14,095
And it showed all these,
the really bad, you know,

566
00:34:14,269 --> 00:34:16,489
Plan 9 From Outer Space,
you know.

567
00:34:16,663 --> 00:34:18,162
It's a good way
to dump the foster kids.

568
00:34:18,186 --> 00:34:19,709
We just watched
monster movies all day.

569
00:34:19,883 --> 00:34:21,929
I remember from a very early age

570
00:34:22,103 --> 00:34:24,540
watching Chiller Theatre
and Creature Features,

571
00:34:24,714 --> 00:34:27,239
which were, like, on Channel 5

572
00:34:27,413 --> 00:34:29,545
and/or Channel 11
on Saturday mornings.

573
00:34:29,719 --> 00:34:33,332
So, of course, like most kids, I
was watching cartoons on Saturdays,

574
00:34:33,506 --> 00:34:35,508
but I was also watching
horror movies,

575
00:34:36,074 --> 00:34:37,597
uh, because my mom did.

576
00:34:37,771 --> 00:34:39,618
My mom loved horror movies
since she was little.

577
00:34:39,642 --> 00:34:44,386
Uh, when I was small,
I mean, probably four or five,

578
00:34:44,560 --> 00:34:46,910
I was, uh, we would
watch Creature Features

579
00:34:47,085 --> 00:34:50,827
and, um, Chiller Theatre
with the fucking, the hand.

580
00:34:51,001 --> 00:34:53,265
I think it had six fingers.
We always tried to count it.

581
00:34:53,917 --> 00:34:55,745
Sometimes even The 4:30 Movie.
Remember that?

582
00:34:55,919 --> 00:34:58,096
Then they would have,
like, Dracula

583
00:34:58,270 --> 00:35:00,228
on The 4:30 Movie,
or Frankenstein.

584
00:35:00,402 --> 00:35:02,926
We build
all those Aurora models.

585
00:35:03,536 --> 00:35:07,105
Like crazy. I must have built
five of each of them, you know.

586
00:35:07,279 --> 00:35:09,281
That's... just loved that shit.

587
00:35:09,455 --> 00:35:11,631
They had this TV show
called Ghost Host Theatre.

588
00:35:11,805 --> 00:35:16,897
I believe it came on somewhere
10:00-ish to, like, 4:00-ish,

589
00:35:17,071 --> 00:35:19,421
and it would play, like,
two to three horror movies.

590
00:35:19,595 --> 00:35:21,704
I remember a few times they
played, like, Godzilla, you know,

591
00:35:21,728 --> 00:35:23,947
then The Blob,
and we used to just watch them.

592
00:35:24,122 --> 00:35:26,472
And that made me
wanna watch more movies.

593
00:35:26,646 --> 00:35:31,216
They had this thing called
the Sunday Morning Movie,

594
00:35:31,390 --> 00:35:33,870
that mixed with Twilight Zone

595
00:35:34,044 --> 00:35:38,048
mixed with Outer Limits
mixed with Night Gallery.

596
00:35:38,223 --> 00:35:40,660
That was a lot of ammo
to throw at a child,

597
00:35:40,834 --> 00:35:43,271
and, and, uh, uh,

598
00:35:43,445 --> 00:35:45,534
I, I adored it, I loved it.

599
00:35:45,708 --> 00:35:48,276
I know that it must have been
when I was around three,

600
00:35:48,450 --> 00:35:51,323
because I remember
it was our in our old apartment.

601
00:35:51,497 --> 00:35:54,935
I know that we saw Funhouse.
I was so afraid.

602
00:35:55,109 --> 00:35:57,590
I mean, there's this,
like, robotic clown

603
00:35:57,764 --> 00:36:00,245
that comes through a tunnel
with, like, a corpse.

604
00:36:00,419 --> 00:36:04,118
That, that's, that is still,
like, stuck with me forever.

605
00:36:04,292 --> 00:36:07,077
I, I think I took chances in
horror when I was really young.

606
00:36:07,252 --> 00:36:08,992
I started watching
Faces Of Death,

607
00:36:09,167 --> 00:36:10,951
and the reality ones
that you see

608
00:36:11,125 --> 00:36:13,345
people getting chopped up,
shit like that.

609
00:36:13,910 --> 00:36:16,790
I don't know how the fuck I got a
hold of them, but it kind of warped me.

610
00:36:18,611 --> 00:36:19,960
But that's what
I liked watching.

611
00:36:20,134 --> 00:36:22,267
My dad took us
to see Poltergeist.

612
00:36:22,441 --> 00:36:26,009
I was, like, maybe six or
something when that movie came out,

613
00:36:26,184 --> 00:36:28,795
and, uh, he took us to see it
'cause we just asked him to.

614
00:36:28,969 --> 00:36:30,275
And he was like, "Okay."

615
00:36:30,449 --> 00:36:32,146
He wasn't like,
"This is inappropriate

616
00:36:32,320 --> 00:36:34,627
for a six-year-old at all."

617
00:36:34,801 --> 00:36:37,673
I would stay up late
in my, um, in my bedroom,

618
00:36:37,847 --> 00:36:40,023
and I had a tiny black and white
television, you know,

619
00:36:40,198 --> 00:36:43,549
that you had to, that I'd get the
reception and to stay up late and watch.

620
00:36:44,114 --> 00:36:47,988
They would show trailers
for Friday The 13th I and II.

621
00:36:48,162 --> 00:36:50,817
And the fact that it was,
the TV was in black and white,

622
00:36:50,991 --> 00:36:52,775
and, and, and gritty and grainy

623
00:36:53,341 --> 00:36:54,951
just made it even more scary.

624
00:36:55,125 --> 00:36:56,605
To me, this was actually more,

625
00:36:56,779 --> 00:36:58,477
it seemed more of a documentary,

626
00:36:58,651 --> 00:37:00,783
'cause I didn't know
that movies didn't happen.

627
00:37:01,306 --> 00:37:03,525
You know, I just figured
people had cameras,

628
00:37:03,699 --> 00:37:05,875
and they just happened
to be around

629
00:37:06,049 --> 00:37:07,529
when all this bad stuff
was happening.

630
00:37:07,573 --> 00:37:09,401
There were these orange books,

631
00:37:09,575 --> 00:37:10,967
and they were the monster books,

632
00:37:11,141 --> 00:37:12,882
like, you know,
Frankenstein, Dracula,

633
00:37:13,056 --> 00:37:16,321
Invisible man,
uh, Wolf Man, King Kong,

634
00:37:16,495 --> 00:37:20,107
and, and it was made by
this company called Crestwood.

635
00:37:20,281 --> 00:37:23,371
And I loved these books. I would
check them out every single day.

636
00:37:23,545 --> 00:37:25,417
Check them out
every day, every day.

637
00:37:25,591 --> 00:37:27,114
And I, I just worshipped
these books.

638
00:37:27,288 --> 00:37:28,768
So my mom got me the whole set.

639
00:37:29,508 --> 00:37:33,251
And, um, that's what really got
me into it at such a young age.

640
00:37:33,425 --> 00:37:36,645
I was around, uh, eight years
old, and I saw, um,

641
00:37:36,819 --> 00:37:39,431
one of the first Draculafilms
in a walk-in theater.

642
00:37:39,605 --> 00:37:41,520
We went shopping
with my mom or something.

643
00:37:41,694 --> 00:37:43,304
She dropped us off
at the theater.

644
00:37:43,478 --> 00:37:45,611
We walked in there,
and Christopher Lee comes

645
00:37:45,785 --> 00:37:48,440
rising out of the carpet,
and we went, "Aah!"

646
00:37:48,614 --> 00:37:51,617
It just was, just, just that opening
scene where I was, like, horrified.

647
00:37:51,791 --> 00:37:55,229
It must have been
about 1981 or 1982.

648
00:37:55,403 --> 00:37:58,928
We went to my Aunt Donna's house
to watch American Werewolf In London.

649
00:37:59,102 --> 00:38:01,516
My dad was like, "You're gonna
love this movie. I read about it.

650
00:38:01,540 --> 00:38:03,340
It's supposed to be
this cool werewolf movie."

651
00:38:03,498 --> 00:38:05,892
And, of course,
the transformation scene

652
00:38:06,066 --> 00:38:08,286
just blew my mind.
It was the greatest thing ever.

653
00:38:08,460 --> 00:38:13,291
The recurring dream sequences
were, were literally truly terrifying.

654
00:38:13,465 --> 00:38:16,424
Especially with the Nazi werewolves
that burst into the living room

655
00:38:16,598 --> 00:38:19,819
and, like, you know, just totally
gunned down the entire family.

656
00:38:19,993 --> 00:38:22,343
Really, really freaked me out.

657
00:38:22,517 --> 00:38:25,041
You know, that's what began
my love affair with horror was that.

658
00:38:25,215 --> 00:38:28,871
I think that was the defining
moment. It was like riding, you know,

659
00:38:29,045 --> 00:38:30,569
a dangerous switchback railway.

660
00:38:30,743 --> 00:38:33,572
It was like,
"Wow, I wanna go again."

661
00:38:33,746 --> 00:38:37,706
Started watching Dark Shadows
when I was probably about three.

662
00:38:37,880 --> 00:38:39,926
It was a serial,
like a soap opera,

663
00:38:40,100 --> 00:38:41,101
like General Hospital.

664
00:38:41,275 --> 00:38:43,669
It ran from '66 to '71,

665
00:38:43,843 --> 00:38:46,541
and it was about a vampire
named Barnabas Collins.

666
00:38:46,715 --> 00:38:48,978
So I started watching horror,
and my mother watched it,

667
00:38:49,152 --> 00:38:52,547
and so probably, yeah,
about three or four years old.

668
00:38:53,287 --> 00:38:56,464
I was probably about, uh,

669
00:38:56,638 --> 00:38:58,423
I'm gonna say five or six,

670
00:38:58,597 --> 00:39:01,774
and my mom took me
to see Buck Rogers.

671
00:39:01,948 --> 00:39:04,187
Like, you know the movie with,
uh, with Gil Gerard, right?

672
00:39:04,211 --> 00:39:06,866
Like the,
the disco sci-fi flick.

673
00:39:07,040 --> 00:39:09,477
My mom was like, "Well,
you know, he liked Star Wars.

674
00:39:09,651 --> 00:39:11,044
Maybe he'll like this,
you know."

675
00:39:11,218 --> 00:39:13,481
The trailer
for the original Halloween

676
00:39:13,655 --> 00:39:15,309
was attached to the movie,

677
00:39:15,483 --> 00:39:17,833
and I was so transfixed.

678
00:39:18,878 --> 00:39:19,966
That was it for me.

679
00:39:20,706 --> 00:39:25,406
Whether it is literature,
painting, or film,

680
00:39:25,580 --> 00:39:27,930
there is always
a dark side to art.

681
00:39:28,801 --> 00:39:32,892
Let us take a look
at the darker side of music.

682
00:39:33,545 --> 00:39:36,635
Let us explore
the history of metal.

683
00:39:38,463 --> 00:39:40,769
Music, right? I mean,
music was around forever.

684
00:39:40,943 --> 00:39:43,990
But the origins of metal
are from the blues.

685
00:39:44,164 --> 00:39:49,430
Robert Johnson could get
credited for inventing rock and roll.

686
00:39:49,604 --> 00:39:51,650
When you see
in the '60s and '70s,

687
00:39:51,824 --> 00:39:55,305
the emergence of progressive
rock and heavy metal.

688
00:39:55,480 --> 00:39:57,320
Things were louder,
things were more dangerous.

689
00:39:57,482 --> 00:40:00,006
Metal is under
the rock umbrella,

690
00:40:00,180 --> 00:40:04,489
but metal, metal, metal started
with Black Sabbath.

691
00:40:04,663 --> 00:40:06,142
Black Sabbath
when they first started

692
00:40:06,316 --> 00:40:08,120
was a band called Earth,
and they were a blues band,

693
00:40:08,144 --> 00:40:10,079
and they kind of took that,
even Led Zeppelin as well,

694
00:40:10,103 --> 00:40:12,888
they kind of took those themes
and that style of music,

695
00:40:13,062 --> 00:40:16,631
and put it into this different
kind of musical genre.

696
00:40:16,805 --> 00:40:19,286
The song "Black Sabbath,"
the album Black Sabbath.

697
00:40:19,460 --> 00:40:21,177
There was stuff that was
heavy music before that,

698
00:40:21,201 --> 00:40:24,987
but to me, that's the official
birth of heavy metal.

699
00:40:25,161 --> 00:40:29,296
They fused horror
and, and heavy music together.

700
00:40:29,470 --> 00:40:32,081
You know, Black Sabbath
was a Boris Karloff film, right?

701
00:40:32,255 --> 00:40:34,455
You know, that's where they got
the name, from the film,

702
00:40:34,606 --> 00:40:37,566
and they combined it with heavy music,
and that's how heavy metal was born.

703
00:40:37,609 --> 00:40:39,151
Black Sabbathwas playing
in a movie theater.

704
00:40:39,175 --> 00:40:40,370
There was a line
around the block,

705
00:40:40,394 --> 00:40:41,743
and they were all looking like,

706
00:40:41,917 --> 00:40:43,658
"People wanna be scared.
Look at that line."

707
00:40:43,832 --> 00:40:45,965
Let's change it. And they got
the name from the movie.

708
00:40:46,139 --> 00:40:48,422
You know, that's when they made
a turn from Earth to Black Sabbath.

709
00:40:48,446 --> 00:40:50,448
Anybody who says that
Black Sabbath didn't fucking

710
00:40:50,622 --> 00:40:52,667
invent heavy metal
is a fucking idiot.

711
00:40:52,841 --> 00:40:55,148
You shut your mouth, dick bags.

712
00:40:55,844 --> 00:40:58,760
I'll give credit where credit is
due to bands who have helped,

713
00:40:59,282 --> 00:41:01,371
but Black Sabbath
set the template.

714
00:41:01,546 --> 00:41:02,808
After Black Sabbath, I mean,

715
00:41:02,982 --> 00:41:05,201
there was bands
like Judas Priest.

716
00:41:05,375 --> 00:41:07,639
You know,
little later, Iron Maiden.

717
00:41:07,813 --> 00:41:10,076
I mean, these bands took

718
00:41:10,250 --> 00:41:13,601
what Sabbath started doing
and made it faster.

719
00:41:13,775 --> 00:41:15,342
I mean, you can say
metal to somebody,

720
00:41:15,516 --> 00:41:18,606
and it could mean anything
from Poison and Bon Jovi

721
00:41:18,780 --> 00:41:23,219
to Carcass to Slayer
to Metallica to Guns N' Roses.

722
00:41:23,393 --> 00:41:25,753
You had the birth of thrash.
You had the influence, I think,

723
00:41:25,874 --> 00:41:27,441
of punk and hardcore
on it as well.

724
00:41:27,615 --> 00:41:29,051
That sort of meshed in
a little bit.

725
00:41:29,225 --> 00:41:32,141
And now you have probably
20 sub-genres of it,

726
00:41:32,315 --> 00:41:34,970
that it means something different
to so many different people.

727
00:41:35,144 --> 00:41:36,885
So, I think it's just,
it's just had

728
00:41:37,059 --> 00:41:39,105
so many bastard children
along the way.

729
00:41:40,280 --> 00:41:41,977
Isn't history fascinating?

730
00:41:42,761 --> 00:41:45,459
Now that you've learned a
little history of metal and horror,

731
00:41:46,286 --> 00:41:49,985
let us see how horror
influenced the musicians.

732
00:41:50,682 --> 00:41:52,858
Let the convergence begin.

733
00:41:54,120 --> 00:41:56,775
In the '50s and early '60,
there were actually, uh,

734
00:41:56,949 --> 00:42:00,387
there were all kind of, like,
minor hits, like novelty rock things,

735
00:42:00,561 --> 00:42:02,607
but they were actually
quite a bit of them.

736
00:42:02,781 --> 00:42:05,392
Started then. It's where
the horror rock started.

737
00:42:05,566 --> 00:42:08,047
I guess the first one
that really got me was

738
00:42:08,221 --> 00:42:11,224
was Screamin' Jay Hawkins, who
had wrote "I Put A Spell On You."

739
00:42:11,398 --> 00:42:13,922
Bryan Ferry's done it.
Marilyn Manson's done it.

740
00:42:14,096 --> 00:42:16,229
It will be done
a hundred more times.

741
00:42:16,403 --> 00:42:18,797
Screaming Lord Sutch,
I knew him as the guy

742
00:42:18,971 --> 00:42:21,531
who appeared in photographs
with the toilet seat around his neck.

743
00:42:21,582 --> 00:42:24,846
I met him on the top
of a double-decker bus,

744
00:42:25,412 --> 00:42:28,981
and he impressed me
as a very intelligent man

745
00:42:30,156 --> 00:42:33,072
who knew exactly
how to market himself.

746
00:42:35,161 --> 00:42:37,032
I guess, as a music fan,
a lot of the time,

747
00:42:37,206 --> 00:42:39,513
you kind of proceed in, in

748
00:42:40,166 --> 00:42:44,344
"What the fuck" moments when
something new suddenly comes along,

749
00:42:44,518 --> 00:42:46,694
and I have
a very fixed memory of that.

750
00:42:46,868 --> 00:42:50,655
Watching Top Of The Pops
and on comes this

751
00:42:51,438 --> 00:42:54,006
creature with his head on fire,

752
00:42:54,180 --> 00:42:56,225
and I was absolutely mesmerized,

753
00:42:56,399 --> 00:43:00,055
and that was The Crazy World
Of Arthur Brown.

754
00:43:00,229 --> 00:43:03,319
Although this shock that we were
actually putting out there

755
00:43:03,493 --> 00:43:06,801
was to get beneath
the daily level of the mind

756
00:43:06,975 --> 00:43:09,412
that every, you know,
that numbs everybody.

757
00:43:09,587 --> 00:43:14,766
The education gives you that,
that, uh, daily existence demands

758
00:43:14,940 --> 00:43:16,985
of what is there beneath that,

759
00:43:17,159 --> 00:43:20,423
so that that was what,
what it was about.

760
00:43:20,598 --> 00:43:23,818
So I made characters. One of the
characters was the God of Hellfire.

761
00:43:23,992 --> 00:43:26,734
It was very shocking
at that time.

762
00:43:28,214 --> 00:43:29,781
It isn't now.

763
00:43:29,955 --> 00:43:31,957
We did some shows together.
It was kind of great.

764
00:43:32,131 --> 00:43:34,133
He had one of the best voices
of anybody.

765
00:43:34,307 --> 00:43:36,396
He had the greatest range.

766
00:43:36,570 --> 00:43:38,964
You know,
he could sing way up here

767
00:43:39,138 --> 00:43:41,662
and way down here
like an operatic voice.

768
00:43:41,836 --> 00:43:43,708
So, I always really liked
Arthur Brown.

769
00:43:43,882 --> 00:43:45,884
Arthur, Arthur Brown was,
was great.

770
00:43:46,058 --> 00:43:48,234
Alice, yeah, you know,
I could see that.

771
00:43:48,408 --> 00:43:52,020
And I could see that also,
he took it in his own direction

772
00:43:52,194 --> 00:43:54,022
and made something great
out of it.

773
00:43:54,196 --> 00:43:56,503
I think Alice can take you
to another place

774
00:43:56,677 --> 00:44:00,072
because of all the creepy,
macabre kind of stuff.

775
00:44:00,246 --> 00:44:04,380
He had everything that I wanted 'cause
I really wanted it to be horror influence.

776
00:44:04,554 --> 00:44:06,252
There was a darkness
to the other bands,

777
00:44:06,426 --> 00:44:08,602
and it's kind of
get the elements,

778
00:44:08,776 --> 00:44:11,692
but the Alice Cooper stuff,
it's just, like, right there.

779
00:44:11,866 --> 00:44:14,739
You know, "Ballad of Dwight
Fry," it's so right there.

780
00:44:14,913 --> 00:44:19,178
Alice Cooper, you know, is
an iconic example of, of horror.

781
00:44:19,352 --> 00:44:21,702
His stage show is
and always will be amazing.

782
00:44:21,876 --> 00:44:24,836
It's a, you know,
a real-life horror show.

783
00:44:25,401 --> 00:44:28,404
Where everybody was Peter Pan,
Alice needed to be Captain Hook.

784
00:44:29,188 --> 00:44:31,190
You know, you had
so many rock heroes out there,

785
00:44:31,364 --> 00:44:33,164
and I kept going,
"Where's the rock villains?"

786
00:44:33,453 --> 00:44:35,020
There really aren't
any villains.

787
00:44:35,194 --> 00:44:39,067
So a rock audience,
seeing a Broadway play,

788
00:44:39,677 --> 00:44:42,375
fully blown up,
but it's a horror show.

789
00:44:42,549 --> 00:44:44,769
And it's really well done
with lights,

790
00:44:44,943 --> 00:44:47,336
and characters, and, and music.

791
00:44:48,642 --> 00:44:50,644
It shocked everybody.
It was very shocking.

792
00:44:50,818 --> 00:44:53,212
But he is a little bit
spooky on stage.

793
00:44:53,386 --> 00:44:55,040
He's got that
monster thing going,

794
00:44:55,214 --> 00:44:58,173
and it's macabre, and
the chopping up of the heads,

795
00:44:58,347 --> 00:45:02,221
