and hanging himself, and cutting
his own head off, and all that stuff.

796
00:45:02,395 --> 00:45:05,050
I could see even way back
when in the '70s,

797
00:45:05,224 --> 00:45:08,618
they started bringing in
these monsters with music.

798
00:45:08,793 --> 00:45:10,533
I remember, like,
when I was six years old,

799
00:45:10,708 --> 00:45:14,233
my dad... opened this magazine,
he's like,

800
00:45:14,929 --> 00:45:16,583
"This is the fucking shit, man."

801
00:45:16,757 --> 00:45:18,977
It was a, it was
a big picture of Kiss.

802
00:45:19,151 --> 00:45:22,241
He showed me videos, and I was
like, "Oh, it's amazing."

803
00:45:22,415 --> 00:45:24,765
When I first
got into Kiss in '75,

804
00:45:25,853 --> 00:45:27,899
you know, I was already
into horror movies,

805
00:45:28,073 --> 00:45:31,467
and I was well into comic books
and music, and I was into rock,

806
00:45:31,641 --> 00:45:34,514
so Kiss was kind of,
like, the whole package.

807
00:45:34,688 --> 00:45:36,646
Off the brown aisle
scoop the Kiss.

808
00:45:36,821 --> 00:45:41,042
To me, that was the epitome
of horror, originality.

809
00:45:41,216 --> 00:45:42,696
The beginnings.

810
00:45:42,870 --> 00:45:46,439
I respect that
because they did it first.

811
00:45:46,613 --> 00:45:48,373
My best friend in the business
is Rob Zombie.

812
00:45:48,441 --> 00:45:50,922
Rob and I are good friends,
and he's a director now.

813
00:45:51,096 --> 00:45:55,404
I mean, he directs horror. And he has
the same attitude towards horror that I do.

814
00:45:56,057 --> 00:45:57,537
That it's comedy.

815
00:45:57,711 --> 00:45:59,365
Well, just the way
Rob Zombie looks

816
00:45:59,539 --> 00:46:01,386
and the way his band looks
and the way his stages

817
00:46:01,410 --> 00:46:03,804
and these robots and these
things that he's doing.

818
00:46:03,978 --> 00:46:06,198
He really, I think,
embodies everything

819
00:46:06,372 --> 00:46:08,243
that it is to merge
metal and horror.

820
00:46:08,417 --> 00:46:09,679
When I was in White Zombie,

821
00:46:09,854 --> 00:46:11,377
I mean,
just the name itself was...

822
00:46:12,639 --> 00:46:15,381
from a great Lugosi film, and
I thought the name is so classic.

823
00:46:15,555 --> 00:46:18,079
It's like, "Oh, it's so obvious.
This is like Black Sabbath.

824
00:46:18,253 --> 00:46:20,453
It's like White Zombie.
It's the perfect name for band."

825
00:46:20,603 --> 00:46:23,060
Even before there was a band, I
was like, "If there's ever a band,

826
00:46:23,084 --> 00:46:25,130
this is what I wanna call it."
I knew that forever.

827
00:46:25,304 --> 00:46:27,915
And then once I was on my own,
and I could do whatever I wanted,

828
00:46:28,089 --> 00:46:30,449
that's when like, "Oh, I'm
gonna have giant robots on stage.

829
00:46:30,570 --> 00:46:33,529
I'm gonna have all kinds of creatures.
I'm gonna have giant screens."

830
00:46:33,703 --> 00:46:35,444
Whatever I thought of
was what I did.

831
00:46:35,618 --> 00:46:38,230
Lyrically, horror definitely
has had a big influence,

832
00:46:38,404 --> 00:46:41,973
uh, on what I've done in
my life, that's, that's for sure.

833
00:46:42,147 --> 00:46:45,454
The song "Among The Living,"
the title track of the album,

834
00:46:45,628 --> 00:46:47,848
is about,
based off of The Stand.

835
00:46:48,022 --> 00:46:49,763
And it's about Randall Flagg in,

836
00:46:49,937 --> 00:46:51,547
um, the Stephen King character.

837
00:46:51,721 --> 00:46:55,638
The song "Lone Justice,"
off of Spreading the Disease,

838
00:46:55,813 --> 00:46:57,858
influenced by
The Dark Towerseries.

839
00:46:58,032 --> 00:47:00,600
I wrote about things I knew,
and that was

840
00:47:00,774 --> 00:47:02,863
King books and comics and,

841
00:47:03,037 --> 00:47:05,823
uh, that was it.

842
00:47:05,997 --> 00:47:08,913
We had a song, "I Don't Wanna
Go Down To The Basement,"

843
00:47:09,087 --> 00:47:11,002
Texas Chainsaw Massacre.

844
00:47:11,176 --> 00:47:13,482
So, we were influenced
by those movies,

845
00:47:13,656 --> 00:47:15,876
to be able to write about them.

846
00:47:16,050 --> 00:47:18,183
Lizzie Borden?
Who's this girl, you know?

847
00:47:18,357 --> 00:47:20,402
What does she want,
you know? Even though

848
00:47:20,576 --> 00:47:24,406
it was the O.J. Simpson trial
of that time,

849
00:47:24,580 --> 00:47:26,017
a lot of kids never heard of it.

850
00:47:26,582 --> 00:47:28,082
And now, of course,
they're doing movies and stuff

851
00:47:28,106 --> 00:47:29,977
of the real Lizzie Borden.

852
00:47:30,151 --> 00:47:34,590
I saw The Omen. And when
Thorn wipes the kid's cheek

853
00:47:34,764 --> 00:47:37,419
with the fox blood, 'cause
he killed his first hound,

854
00:47:37,593 --> 00:47:39,378
I just love that, you know.

855
00:47:39,552 --> 00:47:41,206
And so, I brought that
into my show.

856
00:47:41,380 --> 00:47:42,990
And I do that
all over the world,

857
00:47:43,164 --> 00:47:45,471
and every kid wants blood
on their faces.

858
00:47:45,645 --> 00:47:47,212
When we did
our "Sandpaper" video,

859
00:47:47,386 --> 00:47:49,016
we thought we should do
a homage to Evil Dead.

860
00:47:49,040 --> 00:47:51,040
You know, what if our band
was possessed by demons,

861
00:47:51,129 --> 00:47:53,044
people who know Evil Dead
will go,

862
00:47:53,218 --> 00:47:55,350
"That's a homage
to Evil Dead. We like this."

863
00:47:55,524 --> 00:47:58,179
There was always that vibe too.

864
00:47:58,353 --> 00:48:02,575
If it was cheaply done,
well done, made it even scarier.

865
00:48:02,749 --> 00:48:06,709
Everything about what we do
is completely influenced

866
00:48:06,884 --> 00:48:09,408
by horror movies or comics.

867
00:48:09,582 --> 00:48:13,064
There's a character in Redneck
Zombies called the Tobacco Man,

868
00:48:13,238 --> 00:48:15,936
and he wears a hood, and I think
you're supposed to think

869
00:48:16,110 --> 00:48:18,025
that he's got, like, cancer
or something.

870
00:48:18,199 --> 00:48:22,638
He's, like, rotting, and that was
where we got the idea for that.

871
00:48:22,812 --> 00:48:25,467
Over the years,
I've got various requests

872
00:48:25,641 --> 00:48:30,472
to work, um, with metal bands,
usually through my agent.

873
00:48:30,646 --> 00:48:34,433
The only one of those that ever
came to fruition was Cradle of Filth.

874
00:48:34,607 --> 00:48:36,348
Well, we did an album
called Midian,

875
00:48:36,522 --> 00:48:40,221
which is based
on Clive Barker's book Cabal,

876
00:48:40,395 --> 00:48:42,963
which then was obviously
the Nightbreedmovie.

877
00:48:43,137 --> 00:48:45,618
So we thought that if we're
gonna have a narrative in it,

878
00:48:45,792 --> 00:48:49,535
it would be good to have someone
from the Clyde Barker world of horror.

879
00:48:49,709 --> 00:48:52,494
It was great
to have dug himself,

880
00:48:52,668 --> 00:48:56,281
and, and we immediately, like,
affected his voice to sound like Pinhead...

881
00:48:56,455 --> 00:49:00,067
So I did four albums
with Cradle.

882
00:49:00,241 --> 00:49:02,241
I was suggesting that
they should change their name

883
00:49:02,330 --> 00:49:04,463
to Doug Bradley
and Cradle of Filth.

884
00:49:04,637 --> 00:49:08,119
When I discovered metal, I was
just a few years into my sort of

885
00:49:09,120 --> 00:49:12,297
being very much into horror,
as soon as I discovered metal,

886
00:49:12,471 --> 00:49:17,171
I totally embraced it and totally
understood how one embraced the other.

887
00:49:17,345 --> 00:49:21,001
Everything we've done has
that vampiric element to it as well.

888
00:49:21,175 --> 00:49:22,611
Not so much for Korn,
but I did, uh,

889
00:49:22,785 --> 00:49:25,527
I had a alter ego J Devil
when I was doing DJing.

890
00:49:25,701 --> 00:49:27,181
And I did a song
called "Lick Me,"

891
00:49:27,355 --> 00:49:29,662
and it takes samples
from The Exorcist.

892
00:49:29,836 --> 00:49:33,405
When the little girl was banging
herself. She's goes "Lick me!"

893
00:49:33,579 --> 00:49:35,739
So, I mean, uh, shit like that,
using samples like that

894
00:49:35,798 --> 00:49:37,931
and stuff like that
are really intense.

895
00:49:38,105 --> 00:49:41,282
I used the music,
a lot of metal music,

896
00:49:41,456 --> 00:49:43,937
for listening to
in between violent scenes.

897
00:49:44,111 --> 00:49:45,765
It just helps my energy.

898
00:49:45,939 --> 00:49:49,203
I used one song
in particular a lot,

899
00:49:49,377 --> 00:49:51,379
and that was "Enter Sandman,"

900
00:49:51,553 --> 00:49:53,816
my favorite
Metallica song still.

901
00:49:54,295 --> 00:49:56,471
For years and years,
I've been a fan of Metallica.

902
00:49:57,037 --> 00:49:58,256
I just think they're awesome.

903
00:49:58,821 --> 00:50:02,738
And, uh, love their, uh, album,
uh, "Enter Sandman."

904
00:50:02,912 --> 00:50:04,436
That one is unbelievable.

905
00:50:04,610 --> 00:50:06,177
I've had my guitar, you know,

906
00:50:06,351 --> 00:50:08,309
I clicked my guitar in,
you know,

907
00:50:08,483 --> 00:50:10,833
and I noodle sometimes
when I'm watching movies.

908
00:50:11,008 --> 00:50:12,879
Sometimes I find myself

909
00:50:13,575 --> 00:50:16,187
kind of, like, playing
to the flow of the film,

910
00:50:16,361 --> 00:50:19,799
and I kind of... trying to anticipate
what's gonna happen next.

911
00:50:19,973 --> 00:50:22,715
I'll write a riff,
and I go, "Oh, goddamn.

912
00:50:22,889 --> 00:50:26,110
That sounds like Godzilla
walking through Tokyo, you know?"

913
00:50:27,154 --> 00:50:29,074
If you're writing heavy metal
and you have a riff

914
00:50:29,200 --> 00:50:31,289
that sounds like Godzilla
is walking through Tokyo,

915
00:50:31,463 --> 00:50:33,769
that's yum.
You're on the right track.

916
00:50:33,943 --> 00:50:36,555
Wendy O. Williams, you know, who
we're named after,

917
00:50:36,729 --> 00:50:38,426
the band is an ode to Wendy O.

918
00:50:38,600 --> 00:50:41,299
You know, it's like
just blowing up the cars

919
00:50:41,473 --> 00:50:44,563
and chainsawing things in half

920
00:50:44,737 --> 00:50:49,785
and making it a real horror
show, um, and real shocking.

921
00:50:49,959 --> 00:50:53,137
And I think that that, uh, obviously
has been a huge influence.

922
00:50:53,311 --> 00:50:56,096
We were very influenced
by horror and a lot of the songs

923
00:50:56,270 --> 00:50:58,577
that we wrote were about,
you know, serial killers

924
00:50:58,751 --> 00:51:02,320
and real-life experiences
that would scare you.

925
00:51:02,494 --> 00:51:04,844
And I think that horror

926
00:51:05,018 --> 00:51:08,500
and the things that scare us are still
a running theme in all of our songs.

927
00:51:08,674 --> 00:51:11,329
The fact that we do metal
of a darker and heavier sort

928
00:51:11,503 --> 00:51:13,026
make us slightly close
to horror movie

929
00:51:13,200 --> 00:51:15,289
and then maybe them
to Teletubbies, I don't know.

930
00:51:15,463 --> 00:51:16,899
Sometimes we try
to scare people,

931
00:51:17,074 --> 00:51:18,988
make people uncomfortable

932
00:51:19,163 --> 00:51:20,270
in the stuff
we are trying to tell.

933
00:51:20,294 --> 00:51:22,209
And lots of that imagery

934
00:51:22,383 --> 00:51:24,124
comes from horror movie,
then obviously.

935
00:51:24,298 --> 00:51:26,605
Well, Skinny Puppy
started as, uh,

936
00:51:26,779 --> 00:51:29,651
an electronic band that didn't
wanna just stand up on stage

937
00:51:29,825 --> 00:51:32,828
and do a little dance because
electronic music can be quite sterile.

938
00:51:33,002 --> 00:51:37,050
So our weekends were composed of
taking a lot of hallucinogenics

939
00:51:37,224 --> 00:51:39,835
and watching horror film,
after horror film, after horror film

940
00:51:40,009 --> 00:51:41,663
until they actually
blended together.

941
00:51:41,837 --> 00:51:44,013
Fulci really hit me hard
because there is

942
00:51:44,188 --> 00:51:46,059
an abstract nature to his films

943
00:51:46,233 --> 00:51:49,715
that I didn't understand, but in
the altered state that we were in,

944
00:51:49,889 --> 00:51:55,112
it was incredibly effective of
inducing inspiration for stage effects.

945
00:51:55,677 --> 00:52:00,595
I think if you grow up enough with listening
to horror themes and stuff like that,

946
00:52:01,074 --> 00:52:02,597
within your music,

947
00:52:02,771 --> 00:52:05,818
let you be writing
darker material.

948
00:52:06,297 --> 00:52:09,343
It's gonna come out of you. It's
gonna come out of you, you know?

949
00:52:09,952 --> 00:52:12,303
Uh, Necrophagia,
the stuff I wrote for them.

950
00:52:12,477 --> 00:52:14,479
The Christ Inversion.

951
00:52:14,957 --> 00:52:18,178
Bands like that,
I've always, you know...

952
00:52:18,700 --> 00:52:19,745
Not to mention...

953
00:52:21,355 --> 00:52:23,357
the name of the second band's
uh, record is

954
00:52:23,531 --> 00:52:25,185
Vulgar Display of Power.

955
00:52:26,839 --> 00:52:28,145
And I ripped that off...

956
00:52:29,363 --> 00:52:30,669
from The Exorcist.

957
00:52:31,409 --> 00:52:34,238
That's much too vulgar
display of power, Karras.

958
00:52:34,412 --> 00:52:36,022
My band,
Charred Walls of the Damned,

959
00:52:36,196 --> 00:52:37,676
we've made a couple of videos,

960
00:52:37,850 --> 00:52:39,895
and they were both horror theme.

961
00:52:40,069 --> 00:52:42,942
One was called "Ghost Town"
and one was called "Zerospan."

962
00:52:43,116 --> 00:52:45,379
These music videos
offer a chance to make a,

963
00:52:45,553 --> 00:52:47,729
you know, three or
four-minute short horror film.

964
00:52:47,903 --> 00:52:49,992
When we did, um...

965
00:52:51,037 --> 00:52:52,995
an album based
on Dante Alighieri's,

966
00:52:53,170 --> 00:52:54,736
uh, The Divine Comedy.

967
00:52:55,215 --> 00:52:58,000
It was about the story
of Dante traveling from,

968
00:52:58,175 --> 00:53:00,351
you know, hell
through purgatory to paradise.

969
00:53:00,525 --> 00:53:03,180
We had a video
"Convicted in Life,"

970
00:53:03,354 --> 00:53:07,532
and it was using a lot
of imagery from that actual book

971
00:53:07,706 --> 00:53:09,360
that translated
into this imagery.

972
00:53:09,534 --> 00:53:11,710
That was really incredible
in what he was writing,

973
00:53:11,884 --> 00:53:15,192
and he used that in the imagery
of the actual video.

974
00:53:15,844 --> 00:53:17,844
I love all the dark side
of things, I actually have

975
00:53:17,890 --> 00:53:19,848
another thrash band
with my sons, Hatriot.

976
00:53:20,022 --> 00:53:23,722
And we did a song
about the Countess Báthory,

977
00:53:23,896 --> 00:53:25,830
called "And Your Children
to Be Damned," and we were

978
00:53:25,854 --> 00:53:28,422
completely drenched in blood
through the whole video.

979
00:53:28,596 --> 00:53:30,996
And people didn't like it. But
I liked it because I was like,

980
00:53:31,120 --> 00:53:33,098
"Well, I never got to be in a
horror movie, so I wanted to be

981
00:53:33,122 --> 00:53:34,863
drenched in blood
and something."

982
00:53:35,037 --> 00:53:37,649
So I made the director drench us
all in blood and it was cool.

983
00:53:37,823 --> 00:53:39,651
So it's, it's,
it's always been a part of it.

984
00:53:39,825 --> 00:53:43,132
I write... my stuff is usually
about that, that, that,

985
00:53:43,307 --> 00:53:45,352
that darker side of things,
you know?

986
00:53:45,526 --> 00:53:47,417
We had a band a long time ago
that existed for, like, a minute

987
00:53:47,441 --> 00:53:48,834
called Haunted Garage.

988
00:53:49,008 --> 00:53:51,053
The lead singer's name is
Dukey Flyswatter.

989
00:53:51,228 --> 00:53:54,840
He ended up being in Jim Rose
Circus Sideshow thing for a while.

990
00:53:55,014 --> 00:53:57,295
So they're still doing it
out there, and he's still, like,

991
00:53:57,451 --> 00:54:00,038
he's done a bunch of acting, a
bunch of, like, low-grade horror movies

992
00:54:00,062 --> 00:54:02,432
and stuff, so they're still out
there doing stuff. So it's funny.

993
00:54:02,456 --> 00:54:04,458
They're kind of
on the same wavelength as GWAR,

994
00:54:04,632 --> 00:54:06,373
but they were
a little more psychological.

995
00:54:06,547 --> 00:54:08,984
It was like they would perform
autopsies on stage.

996
00:54:09,158 --> 00:54:11,900
Like, I mean,
it was dark, dark shit.

997
00:54:12,074 --> 00:54:13,748
But I can remember seeing that,
and just being

998
00:54:13,772 --> 00:54:16,818
like, "Whoa!" You know?
"What the hell is this?"

999
00:54:16,992 --> 00:54:21,736
We, like, dove right into the
whole concept that we were, like, uh,

1000
00:54:21,910 --> 00:54:25,218
a B horror movie on steroids,

1001
00:54:25,392 --> 00:54:28,569
Ghost is just like Papa.

1002
00:54:28,743 --> 00:54:30,703
The singer's got his face
painted up like a skull,

1003
00:54:30,876 --> 00:54:32,617
and he's dressed
like the priest.

1004
00:54:32,791 --> 00:54:35,750
That's awesome, you know,
that's like horror rock

1005
00:54:35,924 --> 00:54:37,484
or shock rock,
or what everyone call it.

1006
00:54:37,622 --> 00:54:40,581
We tend to go
retrospectively back

1007
00:54:40,755 --> 00:54:45,064
in order to recreate a lot of visual
elements that we just find pleasing.

1008
00:54:45,717 --> 00:54:47,517
As much as we were influenced
by horror films,

1009
00:54:47,675 --> 00:54:49,895
it was also a fascination

1010
00:54:50,069 --> 00:54:53,028
with, uh, musicals, actually.

1011
00:54:53,202 --> 00:54:55,944
Simple example is obviously
The Phantom of the Opera.

1012
00:54:56,423 --> 00:54:57,772
You don't know who's underneath,

1013
00:54:57,946 --> 00:54:59,818
and it could be
whatever you like.

1014
00:55:00,340 --> 00:55:02,995
Marilyn and I jousted in the
press when he first came out

1015
00:55:03,169 --> 00:55:07,260
because he was
the, uh, Priest in the satanic,

1016
00:55:07,434 --> 00:55:09,871
you know, Anton LaVey's thing,
all that whole thing.

1017
00:55:10,394 --> 00:55:11,394
And I'm Christian.

1018
00:55:11,917 --> 00:55:12,917
And, you know,

1019
00:55:13,745 --> 00:55:15,137
I, I kind of, uh,

1020
00:55:15,312 --> 00:55:17,488
our theology
didn't match up at all.

1021
00:55:17,662 --> 00:55:20,839
And then we toured together.
And had a great time.

1022
00:55:21,013 --> 00:55:23,885
I think the scariest thing
about Marilyn was the videos.

1023
00:55:24,364 --> 00:55:27,236
The girl that did the videos
was really good.

1024
00:55:27,759 --> 00:55:30,544
Really cemented
what Marilyn was about there.

1025
00:55:30,718 --> 00:55:33,808
I have been kissed
by Marilyn Manson.

1026
00:55:33,982 --> 00:55:36,420
You don't get over that
in a hurry.

1027
00:55:36,594 --> 00:55:38,552
I recently met Jeordie White,

1028
00:55:38,726 --> 00:55:41,642
who actually is
in the Marilyn Manson's group.

1029
00:55:41,816 --> 00:55:44,776
He was influenced
by the horror genre.

1030
00:55:45,254 --> 00:55:47,344
As was, I guess, Marilyn.

1031
00:55:47,518 --> 00:55:48,519
We're more...

1032
00:55:49,476 --> 00:55:52,392
interested in, like,
the chaos, and the shock,

1033
00:55:52,566 --> 00:55:56,135
and the sexuality,
and confusion,

1034
00:55:56,309 --> 00:55:59,399
which is always somewhere
between Texas Chainsaw Massacre

1035
00:55:59,573 --> 00:56:01,923
and the Pink Flamingos
and John Waters' movie.

1036
00:56:02,097 --> 00:56:04,926
You know, those are the movies
that we would watch to get inspired by.

1037
00:56:05,100 --> 00:56:08,408
I really loved the whole,

1038
00:56:08,930 --> 00:56:11,150
the dark, outrageous,

1039
00:56:11,324 --> 00:56:13,631
cool look, great songs.

1040
00:56:14,632 --> 00:56:17,025
So I was really, um,
into the band

1041
00:56:17,199 --> 00:56:20,551
before I got into the band,
and luckily, you know,

1042
00:56:20,725 --> 00:56:22,727
it just, everything just
came together.

1043
00:56:22,901 --> 00:56:26,252
I don't wanna look like
a regular dude.

1044
00:56:26,426 --> 00:56:27,949
And I, I love,

1045
00:56:28,733 --> 00:56:32,171
you know, the makeup, like Jack
Pierce would do, all the Universal stuff,

1046
00:56:32,345 --> 00:56:36,697
and I really, really was so
influenced by him and his genius.

1047
00:56:36,871 --> 00:56:39,308
And luckily, being with Zombie,

1048
00:56:39,483 --> 00:56:41,354
it's just exactly what I grew up

1049
00:56:41,528 --> 00:56:43,661
loving and wanting to be,

1050
00:56:43,835 --> 00:56:46,185
and it's like a monster
with a guitar.

1051
00:56:46,838 --> 00:56:48,709
Wednesday 13
is really good at it.

1052
00:56:48,883 --> 00:56:51,016
He's fantastic.
Nobody turns a pun like he does

1053
00:56:51,190 --> 00:56:52,757
when it comes to horror,
you know?

1054
00:56:52,931 --> 00:56:55,194
And his music is great.
He's passionate about it.

1055
00:56:55,368 --> 00:56:56,693
And I think that's one
of the things you have to be.

1056
00:56:56,717 --> 00:56:58,197
You have to be passionate
about it.

1057
00:56:58,371 --> 00:57:01,243
The first Murderdolls single
that we did, uh,

1058
00:57:01,418 --> 00:57:04,551
was a song called "Dead In
Hollywood," which originally was,

1059
00:57:04,725 --> 00:57:07,336
was on Frankenstein Drag Queens'
third album.

1060
00:57:07,511 --> 00:57:09,591
And it was originally called
"Hooray for Horrorwood,"

1061
00:57:09,687 --> 00:57:13,342
which I got from famous monsters
or creepy magazine

1062
00:57:13,517 --> 00:57:15,127
because there's a line
where it says,

1063
00:57:15,301 --> 00:57:18,783
"You can knock on Ed Wood,
but it won't do you no good.

1064
00:57:18,957 --> 00:57:20,785
Hey, Leatherface,
remove my face."

1065
00:57:20,959 --> 00:57:23,614
And we had a part in the video
where Joe's a woman.

1066
00:57:23,788 --> 00:57:26,094
And he rips the face off,
and he's screaming,

1067
00:57:26,268 --> 00:57:28,183
You know? So we did
a little homage to that.

1068
00:57:28,357 --> 00:57:30,708
As far as horror goes
with what Wednesday 13

1069
00:57:30,882 --> 00:57:33,537
is it's just like,
"I'm just getting started."

1070
00:57:33,711 --> 00:57:35,626
And I'm really
just getting started with it.

1071
00:57:35,800 --> 00:57:40,021
I have ideas and things that
I've never seen anybody do before

1072
00:57:40,195 --> 00:57:42,197
that I want to, to try.

1073
00:57:42,371 --> 00:57:43,677
Slayer, obviously

1074
00:57:44,199 --> 00:57:45,984
one of my favorite bands.

1075
00:57:46,506 --> 00:57:49,074
Extremely horror influence
throughout the year.

1076
00:57:49,248 --> 00:57:50,554
Many, many songs written

1077
00:57:50,728 --> 00:57:53,600
about horrible things,
serial killers.

1078
00:57:53,774 --> 00:57:55,950
And if a band could be
a horror movie, it would...

1079
00:57:56,124 --> 00:57:57,204
For me, it would be Slayer.

1080
00:57:57,343 --> 00:57:58,343
Jack the Ripper.

1081
00:57:58,387 --> 00:57:59,127
There's a lot of people

1082
00:57:59,301 --> 00:58:00,433
that have stories

1083
00:58:00,607 --> 00:58:03,654
based on that particular killer.

1084
00:58:03,828 --> 00:58:07,484
When you think about Iron Maiden Killers,
same thing. Eddie, with his hatchet.

1085
00:58:07,658 --> 00:58:10,443
There's, uh, several songs that
they have about that whole period,

1086
00:58:10,617 --> 00:58:13,707
roaming the streets, "Murders
In the Rue Morgue," stuff like that.

1087
00:58:13,881 --> 00:58:16,481
A band that's doing really
interesting work right now is Behemoth.

1088
00:58:16,536 --> 00:58:19,147
It's kind of half artsy
and half horror movie.

1089
00:58:19,670 --> 00:58:21,256
You know, they're working
with this company named

1090
00:58:21,280 --> 00:58:23,120
and they're just doing
an amazing graphic work.

1091
00:58:23,195 --> 00:58:24,195
And we talked to Nergal.

1092
00:58:24,239 --> 00:58:25,284
He's obviously a massive,

1093
00:58:25,458 --> 00:58:26,938
massive fan of horror stuff.

1094
00:58:27,721 --> 00:58:30,724
So they're kind of incorporating
with... the lyrics with these crazy images.

1095
00:58:30,898 --> 00:58:32,813
That imagery has
always been there, you know?

1096
00:58:32,987 --> 00:58:34,728
The, the demons and the, uh,

1097
00:58:34,902 --> 00:58:37,252
all of that shit, you know?
It kind of goes hand in hand.

1098
00:58:37,426 --> 00:58:39,994
Type O Negative,
'cause they're just rule.

1099
00:58:40,168 --> 00:58:41,953
I would say
they were horror influenced.

1100
00:58:42,127 --> 00:58:43,432
- Totally.
- Yeah.

1101
00:58:43,607 --> 00:58:45,347
Dudes like Frankenstein, man.

1102
00:58:45,522 --> 00:58:47,393
Another band that has been

1103
00:58:47,567 --> 00:58:49,917
influential in many ways,

1104
00:58:50,091 --> 00:58:54,052
um, that I also strongly, like,
connect with, with, you know,

1105
00:58:54,226 --> 00:58:56,750
horror metal is definitely
The Misfits.

1106
00:58:57,359 --> 00:58:59,231
It might not be
super apparent in our music,

1107
00:58:59,405 --> 00:59:03,278
but it, it's melodically
and attitude-wise, it's...

1108
00:59:04,018 --> 00:59:07,239
I've always been
very influenced by Misfits.

1109
00:59:07,413 --> 00:59:11,069
It was the best combination of
punk and horror that I'd ever heard.

1110
00:59:11,635 --> 00:59:13,811
I mean, it doesn't get
much better than "Vampira."

1111
00:59:13,985 --> 00:59:15,726
It doesn't get much better
than "Skulls."

1112
00:59:15,900 --> 00:59:17,704
It doesn't get much better
than "Horror Business."

1113
00:59:17,728 --> 00:59:20,165
"Psycho '78,"
unless you saw the movie,

1114
00:59:20,339 --> 00:59:22,559
how the hell are you gonna
put that together, you know?

1115
00:59:22,733 --> 00:59:24,517
That's the stuff
that I love, man.

1116
00:59:24,691 --> 00:59:28,260
- It's that, that wry little...
- you know?

1117
00:59:28,434 --> 00:59:29,957
When I first heard
the Misfits, I heard

1118
00:59:30,131 --> 00:59:31,698
the music first, I...

1119
00:59:31,872 --> 00:59:34,527
Pretty cool. But then when I saw
what they looked like,

1120
00:59:35,223 --> 00:59:37,269
I was like,
"Okay, I totally get it.

1121
00:59:37,443 --> 00:59:39,488
I totally get
where they are coming from."

1122
00:59:39,663 --> 00:59:42,361
I saw the album, you know,
their Mars, you know?

1123
00:59:42,535 --> 00:59:44,624
And the background
is a bat-rat-spider-crab

1124
00:59:44,798 --> 00:59:46,234
from Angry Red Planet.

1125
00:59:46,408 --> 00:59:48,628
I just thought
it was the most coolest thing,

1126
00:59:48,802 --> 00:59:51,544
'cause that's what
I wanted to do, you know?

1127
00:59:51,718 --> 00:59:54,068
It's just imagery. It's art.
It's, you know,

1128
00:59:54,242 --> 00:59:56,288
I can't write about puppies,
flowers, and rainbows.

1129
00:59:56,462 --> 00:59:57,637
Nobody's going to buy it.

1130
00:59:57,811 --> 00:59:59,552
And you want
that 15-year-old kid

1131
00:59:59,726 --> 01:00:01,641
to read the lyrics, and be like,

1132
01:00:01,815 --> 01:00:05,079
"Sick. These guys are fucked-up.
This is nuts." You know? And...

1133
01:00:05,776 --> 01:00:07,908
It's all just imagery, man.
It's, it's art.

1134
01:00:08,692 --> 01:00:10,650
I remember when I was
probably like 19 or 20,

1135
01:00:10,824 --> 01:00:13,348
my friend was telling me, "You
gotta go see this bang GWAR."

1136
01:00:13,522 --> 01:00:16,202
I just heard they dress up of these
costumes, and it's a crazy show.

1137
01:00:16,351 --> 01:00:18,351
And then, When they still had
the girl in the band,

1138
01:00:18,484 --> 01:00:20,355
she wound up giving birth
on stage to a baby,

1139
01:00:20,529 --> 01:00:21,985
and they put it
through the wood chipper.

1140
01:00:22,009 --> 01:00:23,689
I thought that was
the greatest thing ever.

1141
01:00:23,881 --> 01:00:24,988
- And then...
- Did you take a date?

1142
01:00:25,012 --> 01:00:26,274
Huh? No, I didn't have a date.

1143
01:00:26,448 --> 01:00:27,848
Yeah. No girl wanted
to go see that.

1144
01:00:27,885 --> 01:00:29,445
GWAR for somebody
who is so over the top

1145
01:00:29,538 --> 01:00:31,584
and so silly
that it just worked.

1146
01:00:32,106 --> 01:00:33,412
It's pretty obvious

1147
01:00:34,152 --> 01:00:35,240
that it has...

1148
01:00:36,415 --> 01:00:38,983
comic books, horror films,

1149
01:00:39,636 --> 01:00:40,985
bloodlust,

1150
01:00:41,550 --> 01:00:43,161
Dungeons and Dragons,

1151
01:00:43,944 --> 01:00:45,511
Soupy Sales.

1152
01:00:46,251 --> 01:00:48,383
The horror expression
on someone's face

1153
01:00:48,557 --> 01:00:49,950
when, when we murder them

1154
01:00:50,124 --> 01:00:51,909
and they're bleeding and dying,

1155
01:00:52,083 --> 01:00:54,607
and, and it's just
a really happy moment.

1156
01:00:54,781 --> 01:00:58,437
But horror is, uh, you know,
it's a great genre. We love it.

1157
01:00:58,611 --> 01:01:00,918
It's a great way
to make meaning, and we're lucky

1158
01:01:01,092 --> 01:01:03,529
to be a part of... I don't know
what the fuck I'm saying.

1159
01:01:03,703 --> 01:01:06,227
There's a band that I really
love called Cannibal Corpse,

1160
01:01:06,401 --> 01:01:08,273
and they do a lot of horror,
kind of, like,

1161
01:01:08,795 --> 01:01:12,059
lyrics about chopping up people
and all that kind of stuff.

1162
01:01:12,233 --> 01:01:13,974
Every one of their words
in their songs

1163
01:01:14,148 --> 01:01:16,107
are like mini horror stories.

1164
01:01:16,281 --> 01:01:19,240
Mini killing stories,
murder stories.

1165
01:01:19,414 --> 01:01:23,723
Real sick, twisted,
bloody, gory tales

1166
01:01:23,897 --> 01:01:27,379
told in three-minute
blast beats.

1167
01:01:27,553 --> 01:01:31,209
And with these lyrics that are
like, "Oh, my God, a comic book."

1168
01:01:31,383 --> 01:01:33,515
We'd look at our stuff
as just like...

1169
01:01:34,603 --> 01:01:36,301
um, brutal...

1170
01:01:37,128 --> 01:01:41,045
metal soundtrack over horror
stories, you know? Horror movies.

1171
01:01:41,219 --> 01:01:43,619
Some of them being graphic,
some of them being psychological,

1172
01:01:43,787 --> 01:01:45,907
and some of them, you know,
some of our songs are just

1173
01:01:46,006 --> 01:01:47,486
fucking Fulci.
You know what I mean?

1174
01:01:47,660 --> 01:01:49,531
Some of them are,
you know, dead alive.

1175
01:01:49,706 --> 01:01:51,229
Just, you know,
just blood and gore.

1176
01:01:51,403 --> 01:01:53,492
And some of them are
more psychological.

1177
01:01:53,666 --> 01:01:55,189
You know, where it's just,

1178
01:01:55,363 --> 01:01:58,323
you know, it's the, the, the f...
The horror and the fear,

1179
01:01:58,497 --> 01:02:00,629
certain things and,
and them happening.

1180
01:02:00,804 --> 01:02:04,895
King Diamond is probably very
underrated when it comes to that stuff,

1181
01:02:05,069 --> 01:02:07,462
But look at his albums,
his albums or movies.

1182
01:02:07,636 --> 01:02:09,290
And he will paint that all day.

1183
01:02:09,464 --> 01:02:14,295
King is probably
the heir apparent to Alice.

1184
01:02:14,469 --> 01:02:17,124
But I do believe that Alice
heavily influenced him.

1185
01:02:17,603 --> 01:02:20,214
Portal, hands down.

1186
01:02:20,388 --> 01:02:23,957
They to me, sound like

1187
01:02:24,828 --> 01:02:28,701
the chaotic, swaying...

1188
01:02:30,137 --> 01:02:32,531
off kilter world

1189
01:02:32,705 --> 01:02:36,013
that Lovecraft invented

1190
01:02:36,187 --> 01:02:39,581
and their lyrics are fucking...

1191
01:02:40,539 --> 01:02:41,932
genius.

1192
01:02:42,106 --> 01:02:44,935
I'm sorry. Hands down, Portal.

1193
01:02:45,109 --> 01:02:48,634
Death is one of the bands. All the
old Death songs and, and, and, um,

1194
01:02:48,808 --> 01:02:51,593
you know, "Scream Bloody Gore"
is reanimated, you know.

1195
01:02:51,768 --> 01:02:54,771
Um, and then they have the song "Evil
Dead," you know? So extremely gore.

1196
01:02:54,945 --> 01:02:57,599
Definitely you can see
throughout that whole album.

1197
01:02:57,774 --> 01:03:02,256
We're at Knotfest, idiot. Of course,
Slipknot stands out as a horror band.

1198
01:03:02,430 --> 01:03:04,669
They've been around for a long
fucking time paying their dues.

1199
01:03:04,693 --> 01:03:06,478
I mean, it's fucking good shit.

1200
01:03:06,652 --> 01:03:08,785
Yeah, they're badass musicians.

1201
01:03:09,437 --> 01:03:13,224
And they're fucking, their masks are
pretty sick. They're pretty scary, right?

1202
01:03:13,398 --> 01:03:16,140
I mean, they're not as scary
as us, but they're pretty scary.

1203
01:03:16,314 --> 01:03:18,925
I think Slipknot's probably the
best example of a modern-day band

1204
01:03:19,099 --> 01:03:21,232
that's kind of adapted
that Kiss imagery.

1205
01:03:21,406 --> 01:03:23,625
It also gives them
a uniform look, which I liked.

1206
01:03:23,800 --> 01:03:25,821
There was that thing about Kiss. I mean,
even though they had these garish costumes,

1207
01:03:25,845 --> 01:03:28,108
they were a gang.
You could see this.

1208
01:03:28,282 --> 01:03:30,154
I think,
because I was a horror fan,

1209
01:03:30,328 --> 01:03:32,939
and all the guys in the band
were horror fans,

1210
01:03:33,113 --> 01:03:36,551
we knew how to set that tone.

1211
01:03:36,725 --> 01:03:39,380
We knew how to set that mood
of foreboding, you know,

1212
01:03:39,554 --> 01:03:41,469
and just closing people in.

1213
01:03:41,643 --> 01:03:44,733
You know, the masks, there's
always been this byproduct

1214
01:03:44,908 --> 01:03:46,648
where people have always assumed

1215
01:03:46,823 --> 01:03:49,521
that we started wearing them
for shock value.

1216
01:03:49,695 --> 01:03:52,132
But it was always
so much more artistic than that.

1217
01:03:52,306 --> 01:03:54,439
It was about letting
that other person out,

1218
01:03:54,613 --> 01:03:58,486
which I think is very much in line
with why Michael Myers wore it.

1219
01:03:58,660 --> 01:04:01,707
He put it on
so he could let that beast out.

1220
01:04:01,881 --> 01:04:04,710
This music is coming
from a person inside me

1221
01:04:04,884 --> 01:04:07,887
that I may not be able to show
the world around me.

1222
01:04:08,453 --> 01:04:11,282
So I put this mask on.
And then all of a sudden, boom.

1223
01:04:11,456 --> 01:04:13,197
There he is.

1224
01:04:19,377 --> 01:04:23,337
Metal and horror work so well
together, don't they?

1225
01:04:24,599 --> 01:04:25,949
Don't they, Christopher?

1226
01:04:29,387 --> 01:04:31,955
Oh, yes, I can see you.

1227
01:04:35,132 --> 01:04:36,307
How are you doing this?

1228
01:04:37,743 --> 01:04:41,007
Let's just say
I'm not a prerecorded video.

1229
01:04:41,747 --> 01:04:43,227
I am a messenger.

1230
01:04:44,184 --> 01:04:46,970
Have a seat, so we may continue

1231
01:04:47,579 --> 01:04:48,579
your lesson.

1232
01:04:54,020 --> 01:04:57,154
You are the lone survivor
of the apocalypse, Christopher.

1233
01:04:58,372 --> 01:05:02,028
The last one to acquire the
knowledge that I have to share.

1234
01:05:03,638 --> 01:05:04,857
I'm the only survivor?

1235
01:05:06,163 --> 01:05:07,294
Yes.

1236
01:05:08,034 --> 01:05:11,559
You're the lone survivor
of an empty, desolate world.

1237
01:05:12,212 --> 01:05:13,866
The last remaining human...

1238
01:05:15,433 --> 01:05:16,956
to absorb this knowledge.

1239
01:05:19,089 --> 01:05:21,134
Hasn't there been enough horror
in the world?

1240
01:05:21,918 --> 01:05:23,789
This is hell.

1241
01:05:24,790 --> 01:05:26,879
We all need an escape
from time to time.

1242
01:05:27,401 --> 01:05:29,186
It's entertainment, Christopher.

1243
01:05:29,360 --> 01:05:31,710
Let us move forward.

1244
01:05:31,884 --> 01:05:33,930
We will now cover
a few segments,

1245
01:05:34,104 --> 01:05:38,238
starting with the use of
horror artwork on album covers.

1246
01:05:38,891 --> 01:05:41,589
And the creation
of horror film soundtracks.

1247
01:05:42,068 --> 01:05:44,636
Then, we will take a look
at the meeting grounds

1248
01:05:44,810 --> 01:05:47,639
for the fans of metal and horror

1249
01:05:48,205 --> 01:05:50,294
in the form of conventions.

1250
01:05:50,468 --> 01:05:51,730
Here we go.

1251
01:05:52,426 --> 01:05:56,082
What I liked was
the horror movie imagery

1252
01:05:56,256 --> 01:05:58,693
on the stage,
on the album covers.

1253
01:05:58,867 --> 01:06:01,609
I mean, Iron Maiden, still one
of my all-time favorite bands.

1254
01:06:01,783 --> 01:06:03,524
One of my
top three favorite bands,

1255
01:06:03,698 --> 01:06:06,745
with thebest marketing idea
ever. Of Eddie.

1256
01:06:06,919 --> 01:06:09,008
You see the imagery of Eddie,
you know what it is.

1257
01:06:09,182 --> 01:06:12,446
Every album,
Eddie's got a new, uh, look.

1258
01:06:12,620 --> 01:06:14,622
They go to space,
Somewhere in Time.

1259
01:06:14,796 --> 01:06:16,973
They go to Egypt, Powerslave,
he's the mummy Eddie.

1260
01:06:17,147 --> 01:06:18,757
You go to Canada,
He's a Mountie.

1261
01:06:18,931 --> 01:06:20,802
You go to Russia,
he's a Bolshevik.

1262
01:06:20,977 --> 01:06:23,109
Anywhere you go
around the world,

1263
01:06:23,283 --> 01:06:26,199
Eddie can be something
from that culture

1264
01:06:26,373 --> 01:06:28,114
that comes directly
from horror movies.

1265
01:06:28,288 --> 01:06:30,608
We've seen Eddie so much,
but he's a zombie with long hair.

1266
01:06:31,161 --> 01:06:33,554
But he's Eddie.
He's become so classic.

1267
01:06:33,728 --> 01:06:35,489
Well, I remember
the first Iron Maiden record.

1268
01:06:35,513 --> 01:06:36,905
As little kids, we took our,

1269
01:06:37,080 --> 01:06:38,840
well, me and my friends,
uh, went on our bikes

1270
01:06:38,864 --> 01:06:41,016
to this record store, um,
and I saw the first Iron Maiden.

1271
01:06:41,040 --> 01:06:43,080
I'm like, "This has to be good.
Look at this cover."

1272
01:06:43,216 --> 01:06:45,479
And it was like $7.99.
I'm gonna take a chance on it.

1273
01:06:45,653 --> 01:06:48,133
Like, I get back home and listen
to it and it was amazing so...

1274
01:06:48,787 --> 01:06:51,227
Th... It'll definitely, a cover
would definitely do it for me.

1275
01:06:51,311 --> 01:06:55,185
I bought that record without knowing it
at, at all what Iron Maiden sounded like.

1276
01:06:55,968 --> 01:06:58,057
But I see a zombie on the cover.

1277
01:06:58,231 --> 01:07:00,842
And this really cool font
for a logo.

1278
01:07:01,452 --> 01:07:04,977
And it was in the metal section
in the store. This was in 1980.

1279
01:07:05,456 --> 01:07:07,129
So, I, I... "All right,
all right, it's a metal band.

1280
01:07:07,153 --> 01:07:08,763
And look at that guy
on the cover.

1281
01:07:08,937 --> 01:07:10,678
Holy shit! Look at that dude."

1282
01:07:10,852 --> 01:07:14,595
Eddie trans... He, he, like,
transformed Iron Maiden.

1283
01:07:14,769 --> 01:07:16,902
It's like, obviously,
he became that icon.

1284
01:07:17,076 --> 01:07:19,948
Just like Megadeth has their
icon. Everyone was looking for, like,

1285
01:07:20,123 --> 01:07:22,723
"Who are we going to have for our
'symbol' of the band?" You know?

1286
01:07:22,777 --> 01:07:25,606
The inspiration for our mascot,
Vic Rattlehead, is really simple.

1287
01:07:25,780 --> 01:07:28,740
I think a lot of people
have looked at it and missed it.

1288
01:07:28,914 --> 01:07:32,352
It's so in your face. It's, "See no
evil, speak no evil, hear no evil."

1289
01:07:32,526 --> 01:07:34,093
That's it. I drew the guy,

1290
01:07:34,876 --> 01:07:36,052
then we...

1291
01:07:37,227 --> 01:07:40,882
put the bones behind it
for being kind of like a pirate.

1292
01:07:41,057 --> 01:07:43,320
And then we changed
his head to it.

1293
01:07:43,494 --> 01:07:45,800
So that, you know,
you're stuck to this lifestyle

1294
01:07:45,974 --> 01:07:47,454
because, you know,
as troubadours,

1295
01:07:47,628 --> 01:07:50,153
we really are marauders
going from town to town.

1296
01:07:50,327 --> 01:07:53,547
I think an album cover artwork,
its purpose is to say,

1297
01:07:53,721 --> 01:07:55,288
"You can't hear me,
but look at me.

1298
01:07:55,462 --> 01:07:57,116
I'm cool enough,
you wanna hear me."

1299
01:07:57,290 --> 01:08:00,076
It wouldn't be much different
from how movie theaters

1300
01:08:00,250 --> 01:08:01,773
would drag people in, you know?

1301
01:08:01,947 --> 01:08:06,212
Um, or billboards or, you know,

1302
01:08:06,386 --> 01:08:08,040
film posters,
especially the '80s...

1303
01:08:08,214 --> 01:08:10,260
Well, late '70s, early '80s,

1304
01:08:10,434 --> 01:08:13,828
always dripping with blood,
and people love that kind of thing.

1305
01:08:14,002 --> 01:08:16,092
There's been a band
called Ghost,

1306
01:08:16,266 --> 01:08:17,963
which I'd... I took a liking to,

1307
01:08:18,137 --> 01:08:22,098
and then I saw the cover,
their first album.

1308
01:08:22,272 --> 01:08:24,535
I saw and I'm like,
"Wow, this is Salem's Lot."

1309
01:08:24,709 --> 01:08:27,015
I just loved
the whole aesthetic of that,

1310
01:08:27,538 --> 01:08:31,411
of that group, you know? It
just has everything that I love.

1311
01:08:31,585 --> 01:08:34,806
I remember walking through
Sears department store

1312
01:08:34,980 --> 01:08:37,852
and seeing Kiss Love Gun.
It just came out.

1313
01:08:38,026 --> 01:08:41,552
I remember it was like
this music group of monsters.

1314
01:08:41,726 --> 01:08:45,556
And so I bought it just on the
cover, and it interchanged my life.

1315
01:08:45,730 --> 01:08:50,996
The Brain Drainalbum cover of
the Ramones is art work of a ghost.

1316
01:08:51,170 --> 01:08:54,391
It would attract the buyer
to the album

1317
01:08:54,565 --> 01:08:58,525
that obviously was a horror or sci-fi
fan, or metal, or punk. Whatever it is.

1318
01:08:58,699 --> 01:09:02,094
Well, Cannibal Corpse definitely
has the most grotesque

1319
01:09:02,268 --> 01:09:04,183
horror album covers ever.

1320
01:09:04,357 --> 01:09:07,404
You know, people being
disemboweled and all kinds of crazy stuff.

1321
01:09:07,578 --> 01:09:09,536
They, they probably take
the cake as far

1322
01:09:09,710 --> 01:09:12,713
as gory album covers.

1323
01:09:12,887 --> 01:09:16,630
When I recently got Cannibal
Corpse Tomb of the Mutilatedon vinyl,

1324
01:09:16,804 --> 01:09:21,157
it's one of the most horrific and
shocking album covers that you'll ever see,

1325
01:09:21,331 --> 01:09:24,334
and I love it
because it's shocking as hell.

1326
01:09:24,508 --> 01:09:27,989
Yeah, I think about the covers
we have, some of them are just...

1327
01:09:29,339 --> 01:09:31,882
Butchered at Birth, I mean, come
on. And, and that pisses people off

1328
01:09:31,906 --> 01:09:33,169
like to no end, you know?

1329
01:09:33,343 --> 01:09:34,798
You start messing
with babies and stuff.

1330
01:09:34,822 --> 01:09:37,085
Ozzy Osbourne, Blizzard of Ozz

1331
01:09:37,260 --> 01:09:38,739
is one that sticks in my mind

1332
01:09:38,913 --> 01:09:40,698
as far as just being
an amazing album.

1333
01:09:40,872 --> 01:09:42,917
Uh, Bark at the Moonis like,

1334
01:09:43,091 --> 01:09:46,007
obviously him as a werewolf
was pretty fucking cool.

1335
01:09:46,182 --> 01:09:49,097
Diary of a Madmancover had the
upside-down cross at the background.

1336
01:09:49,272 --> 01:09:51,361
Ozzy's bloody. He's got
a little kid over there.

1337
01:09:51,535 --> 01:09:53,841
So that was
a little, a little frightening.

1338
01:09:54,015 --> 01:09:56,148
Album covers are
just like posters, you know?

1339
01:09:56,322 --> 01:09:58,063
They're like movie posters.
They're like,

1340
01:09:58,237 --> 01:10:00,326
"Hey, if there is,
if it's a good album cover,

1341
01:10:00,500 --> 01:10:03,242
it's gonna give you a flavor of
what you're gonna be listening to."

1342
01:10:03,416 --> 01:10:05,592
I think the late '70s

1343
01:10:05,766 --> 01:10:09,205
and right through the '80s
became such a fertile time.

1344
01:10:09,379 --> 01:10:12,904
You had people on one hand
doing horror music,

1345
01:10:13,078 --> 01:10:15,646
and you had people on the
other hand doing horror film.

1346
01:10:15,820 --> 01:10:19,258
And then somewhere in the middle,
where these two circles crossed,

1347
01:10:19,432 --> 01:10:20,694
you had a hybrid.

1348
01:10:20,868 --> 01:10:22,696
The one that kicked it off
for me was

1349
01:10:22,870 --> 01:10:24,394
Phantom of the Paradise.

1350
01:10:24,568 --> 01:10:26,134
That was heavy metal,

1351
01:10:26,309 --> 01:10:28,920
rock and roll, horror.

1352
01:10:29,094 --> 01:10:31,575
And that, to me, was

1353
01:10:31,749 --> 01:10:34,839
the piece that said it
that everybody had to go to.

1354
01:10:35,013 --> 01:10:37,798
Then you had things like Kiss
Meets the Phantom of the Park.

1355
01:10:37,972 --> 01:10:39,800
That was 1978.

1356
01:10:39,974 --> 01:10:42,281
So it wasn't really metal,
but it was Kiss

1357
01:10:42,455 --> 01:10:45,458
and it was a lot of their stuff,

1358
01:10:45,632 --> 01:10:47,199
so that kind of kicked it off.

1359
01:10:47,373 --> 01:10:48,722
But they have a film,

1360
01:10:48,896 --> 01:10:52,160
the first metal exploitation
horror film.

1361
01:10:53,161 --> 01:10:55,381
1980, Terror on Tour.

1362
01:10:55,555 --> 01:10:58,558
Then 1984, Alice Cooper,
Monster Dog.

1363
01:10:58,732 --> 01:11:01,082
Hard Rock Zombies, 1985.

1364
01:11:01,257 --> 01:11:04,260
Also, about 1986,
Maximum Overdrive,

1365
01:11:04,434 --> 01:11:06,958
Rock 'n' Roll Nightmare,
Black Roses,

1366
01:11:07,132 --> 01:11:10,135
Shock 'Em Dead,
A Nightmare on Elm Street 3.

1367
01:11:10,309 --> 01:11:13,747
I tend to like um, you know, that,
the whole Freddy Krueger thing.

1368
01:11:13,921 --> 01:11:15,619
I thought it was really
a great series.

1369
01:11:15,793 --> 01:11:18,186
And I remember
being so jealous at George Lynch

1370
01:11:18,361 --> 01:11:22,234
and, and Dokken for having
a song in that series.

1371
01:11:22,408 --> 01:11:24,821
They'd already titled the movie.
A lot of people think we came up

1372
01:11:24,845 --> 01:11:26,760
with the song "Dream Warriors,"
but we didn't.

1373
01:11:26,934 --> 01:11:29,334
And that was the first time
somebody ever come to me and say,

1374
01:11:29,807 --> 01:11:33,027
"You write a song, but it has
to be called 'Dream Warriors, '

1375
01:11:33,201 --> 01:11:35,900
and the title 'Dream Warriors'
must be in the chorus."

1376
01:11:36,074 --> 01:11:38,685
Dokken's "Dream Warriors,"
they actually incorporated,

1377
01:11:38,859 --> 01:11:40,315
there's footage
in the video for that song

1378
01:11:40,339 --> 01:11:42,341
- of Freddy Krueger...
- Right.

1379
01:11:42,515 --> 01:11:45,233
And that was actually, that was
really something that was paired up,

1380
01:11:45,257 --> 01:11:46,824
I think, pretty, uh, directly,

1381
01:11:46,998 --> 01:11:48,565
as opposed
to where the other films

1382
01:11:48,739 --> 01:11:50,697
may have just licensed songs
or whatever.

1383
01:11:50,871 --> 01:11:52,917
Yeah, "The Man Behind the Mask"
from Alice Cooper,

1384
01:11:53,091 --> 01:11:54,788
and the Friday the 13thmovie.

1385
01:11:54,962 --> 01:11:57,095
When you had
your new horror characters,

1386
01:11:57,269 --> 01:11:59,445
your Jasons
and your Michael Myers,

1387
01:11:59,619 --> 01:12:01,447
the new slasher films

1388
01:12:01,621 --> 01:12:03,841
sort of happened the same time
as metal did.

1389
01:12:04,450 --> 01:12:05,843
So there was a connection there.

1390
01:12:06,017 --> 01:12:10,238
If you saw
an action scene with Jason

1391
01:12:10,413 --> 01:12:14,895
and Freddy Krueger fighting, well, it
certainly wasn't gonna be violin music.

1392
01:12:15,635 --> 01:12:18,856
It was going to be...

1393
01:12:19,030 --> 01:12:22,338
aggressive kind of, uh, music.

1394
01:12:22,512 --> 01:12:24,577
That, and it worked together.
It just works together.

1395
01:12:24,601 --> 01:12:26,733
The bands are influenced
by horror movies

1396
01:12:26,907 --> 01:12:30,520
also because many horror movies,
they use the heavy metal.

1397
01:12:30,694 --> 01:12:34,654
Uh, included Dario, Dario Argento
use a lot of heavy metal for his film.

1398
01:12:34,828 --> 01:12:38,484
Dario Argento used it
really well and early.

1399
01:12:39,442 --> 01:12:41,095
And if you see his movie called
Phenomena,

1400
01:12:41,269 --> 01:12:44,795
he used heavy metal in that
really to a great effect.

1401
01:12:44,969 --> 01:12:47,754
If you listen to the soundtracks, or
if you go through the soundtracks

1402
01:12:47,928 --> 01:12:49,234
of The Return
of the Living Dead,

1403
01:12:49,408 --> 01:12:51,018
it was basically
a compilation of rock

1404
01:12:51,192 --> 01:12:54,761
and... punk songs.

1405
01:12:55,240 --> 01:12:57,198
When I watch
The Return of the Living Dead,

1406
01:12:57,373 --> 01:12:58,809
I still get goose bumps

1407
01:12:58,983 --> 01:13:02,029
when the skeleton comes up
and starts saying,

1408
01:13:02,203 --> 01:13:04,815
"Do you want a party?"

1409
01:13:04,989 --> 01:13:08,079
It was like, "Okay,
now chaos is gonna ensue."

1410
01:13:08,253 --> 01:13:10,864
Soundtracks for films

1411
01:13:11,038 --> 01:13:14,085
of the singles
were selling as well,

1412
01:13:14,259 --> 01:13:16,740
if not better than soundtracks

1413
01:13:16,914 --> 01:13:19,786
that were the composed score
to the, to the film.

1414
01:13:19,960 --> 01:13:21,571
Music is like the,

1415
01:13:22,093 --> 01:13:25,488
the unsung hero
of horror movies.

1416
01:13:25,662 --> 01:13:28,099
Especially you look at Psycho,
you look at Jaws,

1417
01:13:28,273 --> 01:13:31,363
you look at Halloween,
you look at Friday the 13th,

1418
01:13:31,537 --> 01:13:34,279
they really kind of
push the boundaries,

1419
01:13:34,453 --> 01:13:37,238
and I think that's one of the
reasons why horror is always

1420
01:13:37,413 --> 01:13:40,067
so at the forefront of,
musically,

1421
01:13:40,241 --> 01:13:42,592
just being able to kind of
get away with murder.

1422
01:13:50,164 --> 01:13:53,211
Every week of the year,

1423
01:13:53,777 --> 01:13:55,909
you can go
to a horror convention.

1424
01:13:56,083 --> 01:13:57,781
Can't go
to a romance convention,

1425
01:13:57,955 --> 01:13:59,391
can't go
to a Western convention,

1426
01:13:59,565 --> 01:14:02,176
can't even go
to a Star Warsconvention

1427
01:14:02,350 --> 01:14:03,439
every week of the year.

1428
01:14:03,613 --> 01:14:04,657
But every week of the year

1429
01:14:04,831 --> 01:14:06,964
in the United States, someplace,

1430
01:14:07,138 --> 01:14:08,531
there's a horror convention.

1431
01:14:08,705 --> 01:14:10,968
How and when
did horror conventions begin?

1432
01:14:11,142 --> 01:14:13,405
Well, I mean, I can tell you
when they began for me.

1433
01:14:13,579 --> 01:14:15,625
They began for me in the '80s,
uh, when magazines

1434
01:14:15,799 --> 01:14:18,279
like Fangoria,
Chiller Convention

1435
01:14:18,454 --> 01:14:20,499
and all of those
East Coast entities

1436
01:14:20,673 --> 01:14:22,303
started putting on a show
so everybody could be together.

1437
01:14:22,327 --> 01:14:25,373
But before that,
with Famous Monsters of Filmland

1438
01:14:25,548 --> 01:14:27,463
with James Warren
and Forrest J Ackerman,

1439
01:14:27,637 --> 01:14:29,552
they began in the 1970s,

1440
01:14:29,726 --> 01:14:31,606
when they held their
very first-ever convention,

1441
01:14:31,641 --> 01:14:34,557
I think in 1974
in New York City.

1442
01:14:34,731 --> 01:14:36,291
As they started to come up,
you're like,

1443
01:14:36,428 --> 01:14:39,126
"Wow, we have a history
of horror." You know?

1444
01:14:39,300 --> 01:14:41,496
And that's why I think, you
know, things like Monsterpalooza

1445
01:14:41,520 --> 01:14:43,609
are thriving now
because they're showing you,

1446
01:14:43,783 --> 01:14:45,823
like, these are the people
who have done the makeup.

1447
01:14:45,959 --> 01:14:47,439
These are people
who are in the films.

1448
01:14:47,570 --> 01:14:49,090
And then here are
the films themselves.

1449
01:14:49,136 --> 01:14:51,138
So you have
a full-rounded presentation,

1450
01:14:51,312 --> 01:14:52,376
and that's something
for everyone.

1451
01:14:52,400 --> 01:14:53,967
My partner, Eben, is

1452
01:14:54,141 --> 01:14:56,622
the one that is
the brain trust of Mad Monster,

1453
01:14:56,796 --> 01:15:00,147
and his vision was to make
an old-school convention

1454
01:15:00,321 --> 01:15:03,194
because what we are selling
and what we're buying

1455
01:15:03,368 --> 01:15:05,849
is not stuff, it's memories.

1456
01:15:06,023 --> 01:15:09,417
I put to the rock and roll and
the horror movies thing together.

1457
01:15:10,375 --> 01:15:11,419
Sure, I am.

1458
01:15:11,594 --> 01:15:12,899
A friend of mine, Kevin Barbary,

1459
01:15:13,073 --> 01:15:14,771
who was
already attending conventions

1460
01:15:14,945 --> 01:15:17,425
way before... I ever did.

1461
01:15:17,600 --> 01:15:20,080
He brought the idea to us
to have a convention

1462
01:15:20,254 --> 01:15:22,605
up here where we added
a music festival

1463
01:15:22,779 --> 01:15:24,345
to the horror convention
as well.

1464
01:15:24,520 --> 01:15:27,000
This convention, I liked it
'cause we got to play

1465
01:15:27,740 --> 01:15:31,178
and, um, all great friends of
mine, and it was great to see 'em.

1466
01:15:31,352 --> 01:15:33,485
And it's cool
to have the show too.

1467
01:15:33,659 --> 01:15:38,098
I never had any interest
in throwing a festival before.

1468
01:15:38,621 --> 01:15:40,753
I just enjoyed showing
my friends horror films.

1469
01:15:40,927 --> 01:15:43,408
We're not like
the biggest festival,

1470
01:15:43,582 --> 01:15:46,803
but I think
we are a unique festival.

1471
01:15:46,977 --> 01:15:49,457
I think we show
killer fucking movies.

1472
01:15:49,980 --> 01:15:53,374
I know we have
killer fucking bands

1473
01:15:53,549 --> 01:15:55,420
year in and year out.

1474
01:15:55,594 --> 01:15:57,204
That's Housecore.

1475
01:15:57,378 --> 01:16:00,643
We're about to bring up
some badasses to the stage.

1476
01:16:00,817 --> 01:16:01,817
Who are...

1477
01:16:02,688 --> 01:16:04,168
dudes highly respected

1478
01:16:04,342 --> 01:16:07,954
in the worlds
of rock and roll and horror.

1479
01:16:08,128 --> 01:16:10,348
This will be
my second year in a row

1480
01:16:10,522 --> 01:16:13,090
hosting Kirk Hammett's
Fear FestEvil.

1481
01:16:13,264 --> 01:16:16,659
It's an honor, man. It's like my
community service to get to do that

1482
01:16:16,833 --> 01:16:18,835
because I'm able to get up
on stage and talk

1483
01:16:19,009 --> 01:16:21,925
about how much
these two worlds mean to me.

1484
01:16:22,099 --> 01:16:24,144
The Kirk Hammett's show, um,

1485
01:16:24,318 --> 01:16:27,017
yes, I was on stage
with those guys, so...

1486
01:16:27,191 --> 01:16:30,237
A lot of the metal guys,
you know, have been inspired

1487
01:16:30,411 --> 01:16:32,239
by some of the movies I do.

1488
01:16:32,413 --> 01:16:33,937
Fear FestEvil was great.

1489
01:16:34,111 --> 01:16:36,853
Um, I got to go up
with my buddy Joel Harlow,

1490
01:16:37,027 --> 01:16:40,247
the fucking genius
makeup affects guy.

1491
01:16:40,421 --> 01:16:42,075
He's Johnny Depp's guy.

1492
01:16:42,641 --> 01:16:46,471
He did a live application
on stage in front of an audience

1493
01:16:46,645 --> 01:16:48,473
and turned me
into Jack the Ripper.

1494
01:16:48,647 --> 01:16:50,867
I would just sit in a chair
just so I could get made up,

1495
01:16:51,041 --> 01:16:53,652
look at myself in the mirror,
and then take a picture of it

1496
01:16:53,826 --> 01:16:55,266
and go, "Wow,
look what I did today."

1497
01:16:55,349 --> 01:16:56,949
Like it's the coolest
thing in the world.

1498
01:16:57,090 --> 01:17:00,006
I think like in Kirk's case,
when I first met him,

1499
01:17:00,180 --> 01:17:02,182
he gave me a signed copy
of his book

1500
01:17:02,356 --> 01:17:03,836
Too Much Horror Business,

1501
01:17:04,010 --> 01:17:05,751
and I right away read that book,

1502
01:17:05,925 --> 01:17:09,059
and I learned that Kirk
as a child, you know,

1503
01:17:09,233 --> 01:17:12,149
grew up with an intense interest
in horror films.

1504
01:17:12,323 --> 01:17:14,368
I was invited to his show,

1505
01:17:15,108 --> 01:17:17,371
uh, several years ago
in San Francisco

1506
01:17:17,545 --> 01:17:20,070
and had an absolutely
wonderful time there.

1507
01:17:20,244 --> 01:17:24,596
And then, I had the opportunity
to see a large portion

1508
01:17:24,770 --> 01:17:27,643
of his magnificent collection.

1509
01:17:27,817 --> 01:17:29,166
I don't know if I ever realized

1510
01:17:29,340 --> 01:17:30,907
what kind of
a collection he has,

1511
01:17:31,081 --> 01:17:33,823
and I think I've still only seen
just a portion of it.

1512
01:17:33,997 --> 01:17:37,522
I was privileged to attend
the convention.

1513
01:17:38,523 --> 01:17:41,004
And a concert that he put on
where he performed on stage.

1514
01:17:41,178 --> 01:17:43,963
And, and it was really
quite an experience.

1515
01:17:44,137 --> 01:17:46,377
I know there, there are people
out there who love horror.

1516
01:17:46,531 --> 01:17:48,359
I know there are people
who love heavy metal.

1517
01:17:48,533 --> 01:17:50,173
And I know there are people
who love both.

1518
01:17:50,230 --> 01:17:53,930
And basically,
I'm reaching out to those people

1519
01:17:54,104 --> 01:17:57,455
and saying, "Hey, man, I'm into
it too. And I got a lot of cool stuff.

1520
01:17:57,629 --> 01:18:00,240
You can just come over and
check it out. And you know what?

1521
01:18:00,414 --> 01:18:02,001
I got a great guild
that I have assembled

1522
01:18:02,025 --> 01:18:04,288
of some really great cool bands

1523
01:18:04,462 --> 01:18:06,943
filled with guys
who love horror movies as well.

1524
01:18:07,117 --> 01:18:08,596
And, you know,
these are my buds.

1525
01:18:08,771 --> 01:18:10,729
And at the end,
we're gonna have a big old jam

1526
01:18:10,903 --> 01:18:12,775
because we just all love
the same stuff."

1527
01:18:12,949 --> 01:18:14,167
And what it really is,

1528
01:18:14,341 --> 01:18:15,908
Fear FestEvil's
just a celebration

1529
01:18:16,082 --> 01:18:18,650
of both things,
horror and heavy metal.

1530
01:18:18,824 --> 01:18:21,784
I go to several conventions
a year.

1531
01:18:21,958 --> 01:18:26,223
And there really does seem to be a real
strong link between heavy metal and horror.

1532
01:18:26,397 --> 01:18:29,400
Lots of, uh,
what we would call metal heads

1533
01:18:29,574 --> 01:18:30,880
come to my table.

1534
01:18:31,054 --> 01:18:33,752
I see them everywhere, though.

1535
01:18:33,926 --> 01:18:35,246
Yeah, I see it
all over the world.

1536
01:18:35,406 --> 01:18:39,279
Every person that is not wearing
a horror T-shirt

1537
01:18:39,453 --> 01:18:42,152
is wearing a heavy metal
T-shirt, that's for sure.

1538
01:18:42,326 --> 01:18:47,026
It is the same kind of people,
I think the same clientele

1539
01:18:47,200 --> 01:18:49,289
that, that goes
to both of these things.

1540
01:18:49,463 --> 01:18:51,901
Horror movies
and heavy metal concerts.

1541
01:18:52,075 --> 01:18:54,991
They are quite, quite wonderful,

1542
01:18:55,513 --> 01:18:58,168
uh, and, uh, I love them all.

1543
01:18:58,864 --> 01:19:00,387
From the bottom of my heart...

1544
01:19:01,475 --> 01:19:02,475
thank you.

1545

01:30:10,274 --> 01:30:13,756
We're the extreme edges

01:30:13,930 --> 01:30:17,586

1780

1783

1784

People are in the mosh pit,

1799
01:31:15,252 --> 01:31:17,036

1800

It's kind of the same thing.

It's kind of like a fantasy.

1805

A good heavy metal song...

1806

should be like

1807
01:31:34,010 --> 01:31:38,318
Exciting to watch or listen to

I'm not really sure

1809

but once you get there,
you're glad to be there.

1810
01:31:43,672 --> 01:31:47,414
People are curious
about the morbid,

1811

skittish about the morbid,

1812
01:31:49,678 --> 01:31:52,507
and decided about the morbid,

1813

1814

But their fans out there

1815

1816

1817

So many different connections.

1818

The music and the horror genre

1819

The real hardcore

1823

1824

They kind of feel like a little bit

1825

1826

I did a music video

1828

"Be Chrool to Your Scuel."

1830

Every Saturday,

1831

And so I see a connection

1832

1833
01:32:56,048 --> 01:32:59,922
Horror is the dark side of,
of, of movies or storytelling,

1834

Heavy metal has

1836

There's no puppy dogs

1839

1840

You go to a Slayer show,

1841

and the anticipation

1842

when you're standing on the floor, where

1843

1844
01:33:25,034 --> 01:33:27,036

something's gonna happen

1845
01:33:27,210 --> 01:33:28,690
that's gonna scare the shit

1846

As humans, I don't know why

1847

1848

1849
01:33:38,003 --> 01:33:39,918
Listen to the sound of metal.

1850
01:33:40,092 --> 01:33:42,312
It's so focused on tri tones

1851

and tensions that,
you know, it, it...

1852

1854

metal sounds terrifying.

1855

1856

1857

1862

1864

I think when you take a look at the,

1865

1866

1867

1868

1869

1870

1871

1872

1873

1874

To keep the history alive, I think

1875

If you talk about exorcising the

1876

1877

1878

1879

1880

I think that horror and...

1884

These very dark images.

1885

I think it's just,

1886

Metal and horror,

Um, a crossover between the two

Those attracted to the dark

1892

1893

The two art forms go hand

1894

1897

1899
01:36:46,365 --> 01:36:47,453

1900
01:36:48,063 --> 01:36:49,629
from the other side.

I just always liked
being scared.

1902

I like the creativity
that's behind,

1903
01:37:35,240 --> 01:37:37,068
uh, being able

01:37:37,242 --> 01:37:38,741
Always loved a really good
horror movie that could

1905

kind of stick

-I mean, at certain times,
they're suspense... -Death metal!

1910

And it's just a lot of fun

1917

1947

it's, it's straight up horror

And they just go hand in hand.

1949

you could turn the,
you could turn the sound off.

1950

And put a,

1951

1952

They both kind of feel off-limits

Like something that you're not

1954

but, you know, you do anyways.

Favorite of all time?
I would have to say

1956

Murder and Dying Fetus.

All right,
put my baby up here

Okay, okay. Look, I understand
you're not drinking.

13

And I respect that.

14

But come on.

15

16

17

I can't do this anymore, Rio.

18

19

Be a hypocrite.

20

Sleep with you
on Saturday night

21

22

Babe, with all this

All right.
Well, we can't have sex.

What's next?

25

26

Can't you serve Jesus

27

Okay, this is our third

31

32

And if you walk out

I'm not the same.

36
00:01:40,827 --> 00:01:43,344
And I respect that.
I understand.

37
00:01:43,378 --> 00:01:44,689
I understand.
And I respect that, baby.

38
00:01:44,723 --> 00:01:46,586
Okay?

39
00:01:46,620 --> 00:01:48,620
We've been talking about this
for months and months.

40
00:01:50,827 --> 00:01:53,413
And the truth is
we're just unequally yoked.

41
00:01:53,448 --> 00:01:55,103
Okay?
Wow.

42
00:01:55,137 --> 00:01:57,517
It's not working.

43
00:01:57,551 --> 00:01:59,586
Okay, well,
speaking of not working,

44
00:01:59,620 --> 00:02:01,758
you were furloughed
six weeks ago.

45
00:02:01,793 --> 00:02:03,000
So I don't know
if this is the best time

46
00:02:03,034 --> 00:02:06,310
to be out looking for a place
with no income coming in.

47
00:02:06,344 --> 00:02:08,413
Yeah.

48
00:02:08,448 --> 00:02:11,482
I'll figure it out.
Okay.

49
00:02:11,517 --> 00:02:13,931
Well, when you don't,

50
00:02:13,965 --> 00:02:17,655
you know you'll be back here
anyway.

51
00:02:17,689 --> 00:02:20,344
Montana, listen, let's just--

52
00:02:20,379 --> 00:02:22,758
let's just go in the room
and just...

53
00:02:22,793 --> 00:02:24,344
one last time.

54
00:02:27,965 --> 00:02:32,620
So you really
going to leave?

55
00:02:32,655 --> 00:02:34,517
I was just playing
about the furlough thing.

56
00:02:42,896 --> 00:02:44,448
God, please don't
have me out here

57
00:02:44,482 --> 00:02:46,275
looking crazy for trusting You.

58
00:02:49,551 --> 00:02:51,655
You said my help
comes from You,

59
00:02:51,689 --> 00:02:53,655
so I'm stepping out on faith.

60
00:02:56,793 --> 00:03:00,793
'Cause You know what I
have need of before I even ask.

61
00:03:05,793 --> 00:03:10,586
♪ God, you gave me

62
00:03:10,620 --> 00:03:16,551
♪ What I really needed most

63
00:03:16,586 --> 00:03:21,896
♪ You sent your only son

64
00:03:21,931 --> 00:03:26,793
♪ To redeem the whole world

65
00:03:26,827 --> 00:03:31,413
♪ Heaven's best,
a holy king ♪

66
00:03:31,448 --> 00:03:35,620
♪ A gift to us

67
00:03:35,655 --> 00:03:38,517
♪ Everything I need

68
00:03:38,551 --> 00:03:45,000
♪ At Christmas

69
00:03:45,034 --> 00:03:48,413
♪ Oh

70
00:03:59,275 --> 00:04:01,448
Oh, shoot.

71
00:04:02,448 --> 00:04:05,000
Amen.

72
00:04:08,620 --> 00:04:10,827
all: ♪ Rejoice

73
00:04:10,862 --> 00:04:15,655
♪ Rejoice,
Emmanuel shall come ♪

74
00:04:15,689 --> 00:04:19,379
♪ Shall come, oh, Israel

75
00:04:19,413 --> 00:04:20,793
♪ Oh, Israel

76
00:04:20,827 --> 00:04:23,896
♪ Oh!
all: ♪ Rejoice

77
00:04:23,931 --> 00:04:28,379
♪ Rejoice, Emmanuel
♪ Emmanuel

78
00:04:28,413 --> 00:04:30,379
♪ Shall come

79
00:04:30,413 --> 00:04:32,655
all: ♪ Oh, Israel

80
00:04:32,689 --> 00:04:35,965
♪ Oh, Israel

81
00:04:36,000 --> 00:04:37,551
all: ♪ Rejoice

82
00:04:37,586 --> 00:04:41,275
♪ Rejoice
all: ♪ Rejoice, Emmanuel

83
00:04:41,310 --> 00:04:42,793
♪ Emmanuel

84
00:04:42,827 --> 00:04:45,275
all: ♪ Shall come,
shall come, oh Israel ♪

85
00:04:45,310 --> 00:04:49,931
♪ Oh, Israel
all: ♪ Oh, Israel

86
00:04:49,965 --> 00:04:53,965
♪ Oh, come, Emmanuel
♪ Come, Emmanuel

87
00:04:54,000 --> 00:04:55,724
all:
♪ And ransom captive Israel

88
00:04:55,758 --> 00:05:01,413
♪ And random captive,
captive Israel ♪

89
00:05:01,448 --> 00:05:03,068
all:
♪ Mourns in lonely exile here

90
00:05:03,103 --> 00:05:06,344
♪ Mourns
in lonely exile here ♪

91
00:05:06,379 --> 00:05:09,034
all:
♪ Until the son of God...

92
00:05:09,068 --> 00:05:12,827
♪ Hey
all: ♪ Appear

93
00:05:12,862 --> 00:05:16,000
♪ Oh, rejoice
all: ♪ Rejoice

94
00:05:16,034 --> 00:05:20,965
♪ Rejoice, Emmanuel
♪ Rejoice, Emmanuel

95
00:05:21,000 --> 00:05:23,896
all: ♪ Shall come, shall come,
oh, Israel ♪

96
00:05:23,931 --> 00:05:28,793
♪ Oh, rejoice!
all: ♪ Rejoice!

97
00:05:30,620 --> 00:05:34,896
Now that Montana has taken us
to the very throne of glory,

98
00:05:34,931 --> 00:05:37,517
despite being late again...

99
00:05:37,551 --> 00:05:39,896
Are there any prayer requests?

100
00:05:39,931 --> 00:05:41,448
Brother Odom,
Brother Odom, Brother Odom.

101
00:05:41,482 --> 00:05:42,896
Sister Ophelia.

102
00:05:42,931 --> 00:05:45,034
Ooh, I just want
to give an honor to God.

103
00:05:45,068 --> 00:05:47,344
Let me get an Amen.
all: Amen.

104
00:05:47,379 --> 00:05:49,724
- Who is the...
- Girl, where were you?

105
00:05:49,758 --> 00:05:51,413
Brother Odom just told us

106
00:05:51,448 --> 00:05:52,689
he was going to kick you out
the choir if you late again.

107
00:05:52,724 --> 00:05:53,724
I was late because
I was at my--

108
00:05:53,758 --> 00:05:56,448
Montana.

109
00:05:56,482 --> 00:05:58,034
Do you have a testimony,

110
00:05:58,068 --> 00:06:02,034
since you're talking while
Sister Ophelia is testifying?

111
00:06:02,068 --> 00:06:04,034
Oh.

112
00:06:09,896 --> 00:06:11,551
Some of you know
that six weeks ago,

113
00:06:11,586 --> 00:06:13,551
I was laid off from my job.

114
00:06:15,448 --> 00:06:17,448
And I just decided tonight

115
00:06:17,482 --> 00:06:20,137
that I'm going to stop
living with my boyfriend

116
00:06:20,172 --> 00:06:22,068
and get my own apartment.

117
00:06:22,103 --> 00:06:24,413
- Okay.
- Mm.

118
00:06:24,448 --> 00:06:27,034
But there are so many things
that would have to take place

119
00:06:27,068 --> 00:06:32,413
for that miracle to happen,
so please, please pray for me.

120
00:06:32,448 --> 00:06:34,551
Yes, yes.
Amen, choir?

121
00:06:34,586 --> 00:06:35,793
all: Amen.

122
00:06:35,827 --> 00:06:37,896
We know that God
answers prayers.

123
00:06:37,931 --> 00:06:39,896
And Montana, we will
certainly keep you in ours.

124
00:06:39,931 --> 00:06:41,517
Won't we, choir?
all: Amen.

125
00:06:41,551 --> 00:06:42,862
Amen, Amen.

126
00:06:42,896 --> 00:06:45,413
On that note,
that's all for tonight,

127
00:06:45,448 --> 00:06:48,862
and I'll see everyone
bright and early.

128
00:06:48,896 --> 00:06:50,413
Early.

129
00:06:50,448 --> 00:06:53,586
Early, Montana,
at service tomorrow.

130
00:06:53,620 --> 00:06:55,034
You're dismissed.

131
00:06:55,068 --> 00:06:57,103
Sister Ophelia,
a word with you, please?

132
00:06:59,827 --> 00:07:02,862
You moved out
and didn't tell me?

133
00:07:02,896 --> 00:07:05,034
Well, when you do things
God's way?

134
00:07:05,068 --> 00:07:07,517
He'll always have your back.

135
00:07:07,551 --> 00:07:09,000
Girl.

136
00:07:09,034 --> 00:07:10,758
together: Work on your faith.

137
00:07:10,793 --> 00:07:12,206
See, we said that
at the same time,

138
00:07:12,241 --> 00:07:13,862
so you know that means
it's confirmation.

139
00:07:13,896 --> 00:07:15,965
No, you just say
that all the time.

140
00:07:16,000 --> 00:07:17,068
Whatever.

141
00:07:19,551 --> 00:07:22,241
You should come.

142
00:07:22,275 --> 00:07:24,793
Trent's going to be there.

143
00:07:24,827 --> 00:07:26,586
Okay, I just broke up
with my boyfriend.

144
00:07:26,620 --> 00:07:30,793
And even if I was desperate,
Trent is...not it.

145
00:07:30,827 --> 00:07:32,758
Plus my pockets are on E.

146
00:07:32,793 --> 00:07:34,517
So where you
going to stay tonight?

147
00:07:34,551 --> 00:07:36,517
- I'll get a room.
- With your pockets on E?

148
00:07:36,551 --> 00:07:38,517
Girl, come on.

149
00:07:38,551 --> 00:07:40,517
Look, I'm going to spot you
for mocktails tonight,

150
00:07:40,551 --> 00:07:42,068
I'll drive, and then
you can just stay with me

151
00:07:42,103 --> 00:07:44,103
until you find a place.
See?

152
00:07:44,137 --> 00:07:45,931
The Lord provides.

153
00:07:47,034 --> 00:07:48,206
Can you give me a job, too?

154
00:07:48,241 --> 00:07:50,103
I said the Lord provides,
not me.

155
00:07:50,137 --> 00:07:53,931
Let's go.
No. He's not fast enough.

156
00:07:55,896 --> 00:07:56,827
How are you,
Mother Chamberlain?

157
00:07:56,862 --> 00:07:58,758
As pleasant as a peach, dear.

158
00:07:58,793 --> 00:08:00,034
Thank you.

159
00:08:00,068 --> 00:08:02,586
Sweetie, can
I talk to you for a moment?

160
00:08:02,620 --> 00:08:03,586
Uh-huh.

161
00:08:15,379 --> 00:08:18,931
I'm so sorry,
Mother Chamberlain.

162
00:08:18,965 --> 00:08:20,241
Can I help you with something?

163
00:08:20,275 --> 00:08:22,689
We sing in the choir together
every week, dear.

164
00:08:22,724 --> 00:08:26,241
Didn't I ask you to stop
calling me Mother Chamberlain?

165
00:08:26,275 --> 00:08:29,586
Okay, Ms. Estelle.

166
00:08:29,620 --> 00:08:32,931
Just Estelle.

167
00:08:32,965 --> 00:08:35,931
I've been watching you
over the past year,

168
00:08:35,965 --> 00:08:38,275
and dear,
you're not like the others.

169
00:08:38,309 --> 00:08:40,688
I'm hiring
for a position in my home,

170
00:08:40,724 --> 00:08:44,931
and I was wondering
if you would be interested.

171
00:08:44,965 --> 00:08:47,068
You mean your home,

172
00:08:47,103 --> 00:08:49,862
as in the huge mansion
in Cascade?

173
00:08:49,896 --> 00:08:52,689
Yes.

174
00:08:52,724 --> 00:08:54,068
Have you ever been a nanny?

175
00:08:54,103 --> 00:08:56,586
I've never been a nanny,
um,

176
00:08:56,620 --> 00:08:58,689
but in the time
that I've been laid off, I-I...

177
00:08:58,724 --> 00:09:01,827
just finally finished
my teaching certification.

178
00:09:01,862 --> 00:09:03,379
And I do teach
at Children's Church

179
00:09:03,413 --> 00:09:05,172
every third and fourth Sunday.

180
00:09:05,206 --> 00:09:06,689
Splendid.

181
00:09:06,724 --> 00:09:08,241
I need someone to help
my two grandchildren

182
00:09:08,275 --> 00:09:09,344
with their homework

183
00:09:09,379 --> 00:09:12,206
and make sure they're
not tearing down Atlanta.

184
00:09:12,241 --> 00:09:14,310
I mean,
they're not babies anymore,

185
00:09:14,344 --> 00:09:17,827
but they could use
a mother's touch.

186
00:09:17,862 --> 00:09:20,931
I am looking for a full-time
teaching job next year,

187
00:09:20,965 --> 00:09:24,310
so this would have
to be temporary.

188
00:09:24,344 --> 00:09:27,931
That sounds like just
the right amount of time.

189
00:09:27,965 --> 00:09:31,275
Oh, I forgot to mention,
this is a live-in job,

190
00:09:31,310 --> 00:09:33,896
so part of your
compensation package

191
00:09:33,931 --> 00:09:37,206
will be a room and meals.

192
00:09:37,241 --> 00:09:40,620
Oh.

193
00:09:40,655 --> 00:09:41,896
Um...

194
00:09:41,931 --> 00:09:45,620
Things are going
to change for you, dear.

195
00:09:45,655 --> 00:09:47,655
I can feel it in my spirit.

196
00:09:52,724 --> 00:09:55,620
Here's the address.
Stop by tomorrow after church.

197
00:09:55,655 --> 00:09:57,793
I want you to meet my son.

198
00:09:57,827 --> 00:10:00,206
- Your son?
- Yes, the kid's father.

199
00:10:00,241 --> 00:10:03,620
You've only been at Life Church
for a year.

200
00:10:03,655 --> 00:10:05,241
He hasn't been to church
in five.

201
00:10:05,275 --> 00:10:07,655
Well, thank you so much,
Estelle,

202
00:10:07,689 --> 00:10:10,103
and I will definitely
see you tomorrow.

203
00:10:10,137 --> 00:10:12,655
Okay.

204
00:10:24,068 --> 00:10:25,931
Okay, give me the scoop.

205
00:10:25,965 --> 00:10:27,793
All right, so the Chamberlain
family are filthy rich...

206
00:10:27,827 --> 00:10:28,827
Mm-hmm.

207
00:10:28,862 --> 00:10:30,379
Because guarantee,

208
00:10:30,413 --> 00:10:31,758
you have one of their hair care
products in your bathroom.

209
00:10:31,793 --> 00:10:33,310
So what about the son?

210
00:10:33,344 --> 00:10:35,034
Why hasn't he been in church
in five years?

211
00:10:35,068 --> 00:10:36,827
That's how long it's been
since his wife died.

212
00:10:36,862 --> 00:10:38,655
She died of breast cancer.

213
00:10:38,689 --> 00:10:40,103
I know.

214
00:10:40,137 --> 00:10:41,965
And because he was trusting God
for healing,

215
00:10:42,000 --> 00:10:43,655
hasn't been back
to church since.

216
00:10:43,689 --> 00:10:46,034
- Dang.
- I know.

217
00:10:46,068 --> 00:10:50,034
So a single father trying to
raise two kids all by himself.

218
00:10:50,068 --> 00:10:52,310
Whew,
no wonder they need a nanny.

219
00:10:52,344 --> 00:10:54,689
- You gonna be their nanny?
- Estelle--

220
00:10:54,724 --> 00:10:56,793
- You call her Estelle?
- She insisted.

221
00:10:56,827 --> 00:10:58,655
And then--I know.

222
00:10:58,689 --> 00:11:01,000
And then she offered me a job
and told me that I can move in.

223
00:11:01,034 --> 00:11:02,137
Won't He do it?

224
00:11:02,172 --> 00:11:04,034
All right.

225
00:11:04,068 --> 00:11:07,000
Let's see if this works out
before you start testifying.

226
00:11:11,137 --> 00:11:13,689
Quentin is also fine.

227
00:11:13,724 --> 00:11:16,275
Half of the church
had a crush on him.

228
00:11:16,310 --> 00:11:20,241
But he does have this high,
siditty girlfriend, Chloe.

229
00:11:20,275 --> 00:11:21,379
Wait.

230
00:11:21,413 --> 00:11:24,034
The heir, socialite,
whatever she is?

231
00:11:24,068 --> 00:11:25,413
The one that prances in
seconds before the sermon

232
00:11:25,448 --> 00:11:27,241
like she's God's gift
to the universe?

233
00:11:27,275 --> 00:11:28,862
Girl, yes.

234
00:11:28,896 --> 00:11:31,034
Well, why doesn't she
spend time with the kids?

235
00:11:31,068 --> 00:11:33,034
Obviously she doesn't want
a diva like her

236
00:11:33,068 --> 00:11:34,758
being a role model
to her grandchildren.

237
00:11:34,793 --> 00:11:37,448
Well, if they don't like me,
I'm out on the street.

238
00:11:37,482 --> 00:11:40,896
They'll like you, I promise.
This will be great for you.

239
00:11:40,931 --> 00:11:42,448
♪ Oh, Christmas tree

240
00:11:42,482 --> 00:11:45,275
♪ Oh, Christmas tree

241
00:11:45,310 --> 00:11:49,896
♪ How lovely
are thy branches ♪

242
00:11:49,931 --> 00:11:54,034
♪ Oh, Christmas tree,
oh, Christmas tree ♪

243
00:11:54,068 --> 00:11:58,448
♪ How lovely
are thy branches ♪

244
00:11:58,482 --> 00:12:02,793
♪ Your boughs so green
in summertime ♪

245
00:12:02,827 --> 00:12:04,310
♪ Stay bravely green
in wintertime ♪

246
00:12:04,344 --> 00:12:05,965
Okay.

247
00:12:06,000 --> 00:12:07,034
All right.
I had to get gas.

248
00:12:07,068 --> 00:12:09,344
I had to get gas.

249
00:12:09,379 --> 00:12:11,448
I had to get gas
and I didn't want

250
00:12:11,482 --> 00:12:14,896
my car to stop on the freeway
so I just had to--

251
00:12:14,931 --> 00:12:16,793
Oh, God.
Here she comes.

252
00:12:20,000 --> 00:12:21,482
Hi.
Oh, my God.

253
00:12:21,517 --> 00:12:23,275
I am so, so sorry I'm late.

254
00:12:23,310 --> 00:12:27,310
I ran into a bunch of traffic
on my way from church.

255
00:12:27,344 --> 00:12:29,068
I apologize.

256
00:12:30,931 --> 00:12:32,448
Come in.

257
00:12:32,482 --> 00:12:34,965
Thank you so much.

258
00:12:35,000 --> 00:12:37,206
Wow.
Oh, my gosh.

259
00:12:37,241 --> 00:12:38,793
It's beautiful in here.

260
00:12:41,000 --> 00:12:43,034
This is such
a great opportunity.

261
00:12:43,068 --> 00:12:44,724
Thank you, again.

262
00:12:47,448 --> 00:12:50,448
♪ Do, re, me

263
00:12:50,482 --> 00:12:53,517
The acoustics in here
are great.

264
00:12:53,551 --> 00:12:55,827
Mm. My
late daughter-in-law Shandra,

265
00:12:55,862 --> 00:12:59,827
she swore by the acoustics
in this room.

266
00:12:59,862 --> 00:13:04,310
Quentin would play the piano,
and she would sing.

267
00:13:04,344 --> 00:13:06,344
Whole story is just so sad.

268
00:13:08,068 --> 00:13:09,482
Wait here.

269
00:13:09,517 --> 00:13:11,137
I'll go get Quentin.
Okay.

270
00:13:19,310 --> 00:13:21,827
Oh.

271
00:13:21,862 --> 00:13:24,827
Oh, my gosh.

272
00:13:24,862 --> 00:13:25,827
Hi.

273
00:13:25,862 --> 00:13:28,000
Wow.

274
00:13:28,034 --> 00:13:29,517
Mm.

275
00:13:32,344 --> 00:13:34,586
Nobody touches that piano.

276
00:13:34,620 --> 00:13:36,931
Oh, right.

277
00:13:36,965 --> 00:13:38,517
Um...

278
00:13:38,551 --> 00:13:40,034
Estelle told me
to wait over there--

279
00:13:40,068 --> 00:13:41,344
You know my mother
well enough

280
00:13:41,379 --> 00:13:42,413
to call her by her first name?

281
00:13:42,448 --> 00:13:43,551
She insisted.

282
00:13:43,586 --> 00:13:45,517
I'm sorry.
You must be Mr. Chamberlain.

283
00:13:45,551 --> 00:13:47,137
I'm Montana Ellis. I'm
in the choir with your mother.

284
00:13:47,172 --> 00:13:49,000
Hello?

285
00:13:49,034 --> 00:13:51,000
I'm supposed
to be meeting you.

286
00:13:51,034 --> 00:13:52,172
No, no, no, no.

287
00:13:52,206 --> 00:13:54,275
Color additives
only need FDA approval

288
00:13:54,310 --> 00:13:55,482
before going to market.

289
00:13:55,517 --> 00:13:57,344
Yeah, yeah,
you should know this.

290
00:13:59,068 --> 00:14:00,931
Yeah, let me call you back.

291
00:14:00,965 --> 00:14:03,137
Uh, why are you here, again?

292
00:14:03,172 --> 00:14:05,379
For the nanny position?

293
00:14:05,413 --> 00:14:07,310
Your mother wanted us to meet.

294
00:14:07,344 --> 00:14:09,586
Do you have any questions
for me?

295
00:14:09,620 --> 00:14:10,896
Maybe if you looked
a little more like a nanny,

296
00:14:10,931 --> 00:14:12,310
I might have a question or two.

297
00:14:13,965 --> 00:14:16,310
So what's a nanny
supposed to look like?

298
00:14:16,344 --> 00:14:20,448
I see you're already
getting acquainted.

299
00:14:20,482 --> 00:14:22,241
What do you think?

300
00:14:22,275 --> 00:14:24,482
What do I think?
This is your idea.

301
00:14:24,517 --> 00:14:27,034
And after the kids'
latest shenanigans,

302
00:14:27,068 --> 00:14:29,517
you agreed with me.

303
00:14:29,551 --> 00:14:31,413
I did, I did.

304
00:14:31,448 --> 00:14:33,931
Montana, let me show
you around the house

305
00:14:33,965 --> 00:14:35,241
and to your room.

306
00:14:35,275 --> 00:14:36,379
So I'm hired?

307
00:14:36,413 --> 00:14:38,965
